Title: Love Mocktail: Milana and I have been together for over five years, says Krishna
Content: Their near-and-dear ones have known that Krishna and Milana Nagaraj have been more than just friends for a while, which is also why she turned co-producer for his directorial debut, Love Mocktail . But for the outside world, they were only friends. In the run-up to the film’s release, though, Krishna was often heard speaking at length about Milana’s involvement in its making, which extended way beyond her roles as actor and producer. Naturally, it got people wondering why she would show so much interest in the film. And now, they have decided to come clean.At a recent press meet about their film, Krishna and Milana finally spilt the beans about their relationship. “Milana and I have been together for five and a half years. Our families are aware of our relationship and have given us their blessings. We were waiting for the right time to make the announcement. In fact, before the release, friends suggested that we open up about our relationship, but we did not want that to become the talking point instead of our film. Milana has stood by me through thick and thin, something that I value greatly,” he says.Milana adds, “We have not set a date for our big date. There is pressure from both families, but Krishna and I are busy with our film commitments.”

Title: Siddharth Menon: I try to do the small things Tanvi likes right
Content: Actor-singer Siddharth Menon met Marathi kathak dancer-actress Tanvi Palav at a youth festival, where she was already a three-time gold medallist star. It was the first time he was at the event and because she seemed a veteran here, he used to call her chechi, though she was actually younger to him. They were friends for 15 years before they tied the knot on December 22. “There was no formal proposal, but it was sort of a natural thing to do and the right time to do it,” says Siddharth, who says he’s never celebrated Valentine’s Day in his life.He says that he is a romantic person and does not need a special day to celebrate. “I’m a filmi person. Small things matter to her and I try to do them right,” says Siddharth, who has Malayalam-film Kolaambi set for release and is in the final stages of signing a musical theatre show. “I don’t have formal training in singing, but Tanvi, who has learnt classical arts, loves the raw nature of my voice. She receives many film offers, even in Malayalam, but she is passionate about pursuing dance and taking it forward. Our big dream is to do a combined programme, where I sing for her performance.”

Title: Hemant Menon: Nilina and I hope to recreate last year's V-Day memories
Content: This Valentine’s Day has a special resonance for actor Hemanth Menon and wife Nilina Nair. It marks the first anniversary of their first real date and is filled with happy memories, which they hope to recreate this year.Actor Hemanth Menon and Nilina Nair, a cosmetology dentist and thricologist, got married on September 9. “Ours was an arranged-cum love marriage. The proposal had come through a formal channel, but we got to meet and spend time before we took the plunge,” says Hemanth, who has two Malayalam and two Tamil films coming up. “The most happy memory of our courtship was the whole day we spent together on Valentine’s Day. We had spoken to each other a lot, but it felt special to meet and interact. Nilina was studying and came down from Bengaluru, and we met in Kochi. We hung out together, went to Fort Kochi and finished the night at a hotel party with a close circle of friends. We hope to build on these memories this Valentine’s Day.”

Title: Valentine's Day special: Actors Balu Varghese and Aileena Catherin Amon share their love story
Content: On 2019 Christmas eve, which was also a day before Aileena Catherin Amon 's birthday, her family was in celebration mode. That’s when a group of carollers, all wearing Santa masks, walked in to their courtyard, singing. When Aileena came out with the money to tip them, one among them removed his mask.She says, “To my surprise, it was Balu! And he proposed to me, then and there. And what’s more, the rest of the carollers were his family and friends, dressed up as Santa Claus ! I was really amazed. I had shared a story on my social media page, tagging Balu invisibly to the song ‘All I want for Christmas is you.’ Only he could see and it gave him such an idea,” she says. Apparently, this is the reason why Balu tried to pull off such a proposal.The duo became friends during the shoot of the film Hi I am Tony, in 2014. Gradually, they realised they have the same wavelength. Balu says, “When were got into a relationship and I revealed it at home, my amma told me that when she had met Aileena during the puja function, she had felt she wanted such a daughter-in-law.” The couple, who got married recently, has not yet planned anything for their maiden Valentine's Day. "I am busy with the shoot of the film Operation Java and have them scheduled at night," says Balu.

Title: demo piece: Demo Piece will make you value your parents: Vivek A
Content: Debutant director Vivek A is sure that the stars of his film, Demo Piece Sonal Monteiro and Sparsha Rekha — will draw audiences to the theatres. While Kannada TV’s Bharath makes his big screen debut, veteran actress Rekha fills in as his onscreen mom and Sonal as his romantic interest. But that apart, the film’s biggest USP, says Vivek, is that it will strike a chord with audiences across age groups. “Demo Piece revolves around the protagonist, Harsha, played by Bharath. In most families, you will come across a situation of parents doing their best to send their ward to college, only to have them fool around and not make the most of that opportunity. This is an aspect that we have explored in the film, apart from gambling, which is also a big draw for youngsters. Most importantly, though, on this day of love, what Demo Piece will remind everyone is just how valuable their parents really are to them and they will walk out of the theatre with a renewed urge to give them their due,” says Vivek, who has also produced the film along with Rekha, under the Raykha Movies banner.

Title: Aryann Santosh’s new film has a Valentine’s Day connect
Content: Actor Aryann Santosh is set to make his comeback with Dear Sathya. This film has newbie Archana Kottige as his female lead. The actor shares the first look of the lead pair from the film on Valentine’s Day with BT. “The film has a strong Valentine’s Day connect. The entire love story revolves around the day. I play Sathya, while Archana plays a girl named Anjali. Both the characters are dreamers. While Sathya wants to open a native Karnataka cuisine outlet in Japan Anjali harbours dreams of becoming an air hostess. There is a very cute love track that revolves around the two,” shares the actor.

Title: Sachin Warrier tells us about his Valentine's Day plans
Content: “Within a few months of meeting Pooja, I knew she was the one,” says singer-composer Sachin Warrier . And one day over the phone, he couldn’t resist asking her, ‘You know where this is headed, right?’ says the Muthuchippi singer. And Pooja said, ‘Yes!’ “During this time, her family was considering proposals, and I too was ready to get married and settled. So, there was no time to waste (laughs). I told her we would speak in detail in person and when we did, I asked why not tell our families about this. We soon did and got married,” remembers Sachin.About their most romantic memory, Sachin says, “Once, I happened to make Pooja her favourite desert, Turkish Delight. I figured out the recipe online and did it, and I guess that’s our most romantic memory together, so far.” On V Day this year, he am performing at a college in Kottayam. “So, we will be on a road trip date, checking out restaurants,” he reveals.

Title: This comedy play sheds light on women’s freedom of expression
Content: The desi version of the ancient Greek comedy Lysistrata , is here to crack you up. A Chandrato Collective presentation, this Hindi-Bhojpuri musical sheds lights on some hard-hitting truths of society, with a dash of humour.“The original play is based on wartime Greece. We have used that context in a rural Indian setup. The plot revolves around two neighbouring villages in Bihar that are at loggerheads after a sand-mining company takes over a plot of land located between the two villages. What starts as a fight between the men takes a funny turn when the women of both the villages decide to pitch in,” says director Sri Vamsi Matta.The play predominantly deals with women asserting their presence in society and expressing their sexual choices and freedom. “We have chosen this story keeping in mind how women still have to fight for their right to express themselves freely and voice their concerns. Besides this, land-grabbing issues are also highlighted in the play,” adds Vamsi. The show will be presented in nautanki format. “It is an entertaining piece, complete with songs, prose, poetry and more,” Vamsi sums up

Title: I’m the better kisser; that’s proven, says Mahat
Content: Newlyweds, Mahat and Prachi Mishra , were all upbeat about doing an early-morning Valentine’s Day shoot with us on the beach. February is a big month for them — it’s not just their birth months, but now also the month that brought them together as husband and wife. The just-married couple opens up to us on their love, courtship, cuddles, and kisses....We never plan anything for Valentine’s Day celebration. We keep saying ‘love you’ every other day. Also, her birthday is on February 11 and mine is on the 18th of this month. We reserve all the romantic things for our birthdays. From this year, February 1 is also special as we got married on that day. I guess we will face budget problems from next year as February is going to be a big month for us (laughs).Yes, our birthdays overshadow Valentine’s Day. But we go out for dinner. This year, maybe, we will head out to party as it’s been a while since we partied.Every birthday, we do something special for each other. But more than giving surprises, it is just the thought of her being with me during testing times is the best feeling ever. I feel special when she comforts me when I am down. I have been in the industry for 11 years and there was a moment in 2017 when I almost gave up on the film industry. Acting has been my dream and everyone around me knows how passionate I am about it. I was in a low phase at that time and that’s when I met Prachi. She encouraged me and gave me the confidence that I would make it big. That’s when I felt that she was the right girl for me. That apart, we have done a lot of things… this birthday, I set up the room with 200 balloons, with 200 pictures of us. Needless to say, she was impressed (smiles).Oh yes, Mahat is the romantic person in our relationship. After all, he’s the ‘hero’, right? Even during our sangeet, he performed with 10 other dancers. I feel overshadowed by these… but that’s cute. During the initial few months of our courtship, he went out of the way to buy me stationery from a particular shop in Dubai as I love them. He gave me a handwritten note and card, too. I thought that was romantic as he was thoughtful in picking up something that I really liked.And she has done a lot of things, too. I broke my phone once and she got a phone for me almost immediately. It was packed cutely and she had attached a note, too.: Well, I have done a lot more (laughs). When he was in the Bigg Boss house, I used to shop a lot for him as I wanted him to look good on screen. I bought them in Dubai, and sent them via cargo. That’s romantic, right?I am a home-bird. I like to sit at home, watch a movie and have pizza. I like to converse with my partner and in a cozy environment.I am more of an outgoing person. I’d like to go to a nice couple’s spa, get some nice lunch or dinner, do stargazing, eat unhealthy food and have a glass of wine, maybe?Well, lots of lies (laughs).Yes, he promised to take me to different places and said that he would cook for me.I cooked for you once, I think (laughs).Ours was a long-distance relationship, so we used to surprise each other often by taking short trips. Whenever we get time, we go on long drives. I cook for him. He also makes the best paneer butter masala.Any relationship, be it a long-distance or otherwise, will work only when the couple doesn’t give up on each other. She stood by my side and vice versa.Watching movies!We also love to travel together. He clicks amazing pictures of me. He’s a cleanliness freak… so we enjoy cleaning the house together.I get angry, but my anger lasts for five minutes. And Prachi’s will go on for five hours. That’s the after-effect of my anger. She will make me apologise for five hours.He’s the first person to apologise as he’s wrong most of the time. When I am wrong, I will act innocent and sweet. Usually, Coco (our Beagle) comes and saves us. She’s the pacifier.Oh yes. No matter how mad we are at each other, she will sit between us and ease off the temper.Coco!Prachi, I am the better kisser. That’s proven.Ok, fine. Mahat is!When there is love, you will keep it alive. Yes, it might get monotonous and boring, but you will ensure you do something to keep your partner happy. We get bored with our work, but don’t we dress up and go to work since we love our job? It’s the same thing.I think it’s important for a couple to stay friends in a relationship.Yes, Prachi is more of a friend than my lover. We could be in bed for an entire day having random conversations.I was shivering when I tied the knot. I’d spent two whole months planning the wedding to get to that moment. So, it was special. Also, I got emotional when my mother performed nalungu for me. I got emotional after seeing her so happy.For me, it was the sangeet. He’s an actor, but he took efforts to dance to the songs I liked, and put up a spectacular show for me. He made his entire family give me roses. I felt special, alive and was mesmerised.I am still the third wheel in their relationship. We got a new bed for her, but she likes to sleep between us. At night, I would feel a warm breath near my cheeks. But it is not Mahat, it will always be Coco (laughs).Before marriage, I used to hug Coco and sleep. Both of us felt very bad when we bought her her bed. But she literally pushes us and sleeps in the centre. Coco is the best (laughs).

Title: Sangeeth Sivan: As soon as the boy smiled, I knew he was the right one to play Unnikuttan
Content: The film Yodha was born out of a wish on the part of myself and brother Santhosh to make a movie based on martial arts. We were inspired by those like The 36th Chamber of Shaolin. However, at that time, the farthest place that Malayalam could afford to place it outside of the State, was Nepal.Once there, we saw a girl who was supposed to have special powers. The Hinduism practised over there was very tantric, with sacrifices, black magic and the like. We also learnt about an evil group named Boksha and wanted to introduce it in some way into our story. The girl became a boy in our story and we also borrowed the Buddhist concept of incarnation. We had in our mind the film called Crocodile Dundee, which tells the story of a local Australian bushman, who goes to the US and becomes a hero there with his native skills. We thought, why not make our character go from Kerala to Nepal, to become a hero?Many who heard our story were not convinced that it would work as they felt that the the Kerala connection wasn’t strong. We approached many scriptwriters but it was Sasidharan Arattuvazhi who took just a week to incorporate the Kerala elements into the story!We took in all actors who were willing to shave their heads, to become monks (laughs). We cast a karate practitioner who was also an expert in Buddhist customs as the villain. While searching for a suitable boy who can play Rimpoche aka Unnikuttan, I asked our villain, ‘Do you have sons?’ He said, ‘I have two sons.’We were impressed with the photo of one of them, Sidharth Lama, who had this enviable mop of thick hair! When I met the boy and he smiled, I knew he was the one. He was smart and agreed to shave his head too! That’s how we zeroed in on Rimpoche aka Unnikuttan. His famous line Akosutto was Santhosh’s contribution.Yet another addition from Roja’s team was A R Rahman , who was at that time, Dileep. We had done a few jingles with him. However, after hearing his scores for Roja, Santhosh said he was definitely the next big thing. He came on board and put together some interesting scores like Padakali.When you have actors like Mohanlal and Jagathy Sreekumar on screen, one needs to think of situations that would do justice to their calibre. So, for the music competition, we thought of an idea based on tongue twister songs. Bichu Thirumala, our lyricist, had a good knowledge of folk songs. He sang a basic form of this for Rahman, who asked for references to create such a track. Yesudas and M G Sreekumar sang it, and it was not easy to record. Bichu offered to change the lyrics, if the singers found it too hard to mouth. However, Dasettan was like, ‘No no, it’s a competition, right? Let’s not change it.’We originally titled the film Buddha, but changed it to Yodha, as we didn’t want to ruffle any feathers. I remember that while the film was getting censored, they checked to see if there were any references to Buddha or his teachings in the film.The movie released with Mammootty’s Pappayude Swantham Appoos, which ran for around 150 days. Yodha was in theatres for around 100 days, and didn’t do as well as we expected. But all we wanted to do was make a martial arts movie based in Kerala. Whether it worked or not did not matter.

Title: Surabhi Lakshmi: For a while after National Awards, filmmakers didn’t know where to place me
Content: After she brought National Award for the Best Actress to Kerala post a gap of 14 years in 2017, Surabhi Lakshmi had said, ‘My schedule is packed now with interviews, but what I actually wish for is to stay busy doing good characters in films.’ Three years later, we now see the actress in many commercial as well as critically acclaimed movies. She also has quite a few interesting projects coming up in Malayalam, including Dulquer Salmaan starrer Kurup Poriveyil with Indrans, Kallan Dsouza as Soubin Shahir’s heroine, director K Harikumar’s Jwalamukhi and more. Alongside speaking about her movies, Surabhi tells us how it wasn’t an easy road for her even after winning the prestigious award:While I was acting in director Jayaraj’s film Gulmohar, Srinath Rajendran was an assistant director in it. He was on the set soon after completing his engineering. He had called me to act in his directorial debut Second Show. However, the role was that of a very modern woman who wears sleeveless dresses and also smokes. At that time, for a kulipinnalkaari from Narikkuni village in Kozhikode, it was hard to imagine doing something of the sort. At that time, I only used to wear salwars, not even jeans. I told him I have no confidence or experience to pull it off at that point, and probably I might do something like that in a few years down the lane. There were no other roles that I could take up too, in it. So, he said we can work together in my next, and that’s how Kurup came along. I play DQ’s Kunjammayi, who is from Mumbai.It is my third film with Dulquer, after doing one combination scene each in the films ABCD and CIA. He has been an extremely humble man, who heartily laughs even for silly jokes, and makes everyone comfortable.It’s the second movie from the director of State Award winning film Kaliyachan. I play Indrans’ wife, who is bedridden being paralysed from waist below. All the performance is to be done, lying down. As Indrans is an actor who serves a good give and take platform, it is easy to act with those like him. Director Farooq Abdul Rahman is also great to work with.While studying for M A Theatre in Kalady Sri Sankara University, where those like Dileesh Pothen were my batch mate, I have directed about 26 plays as part of the curriculum. Direction of the music video Kaumaram wasn’t a planned one. The lyrics is by my friend Shyla chechi, its sung by Dr Shani and composed by Gayathri Iyer. The project shows five stages in a woman’s life, and what I directed is Kaumaram, which shows the feelings of a 16-year-old girl. It was produced by a group of friends, and as we aren’t high end professionals, we got a taste of all departments. I could also see how much pressure a director takes. As an actor, I think only about my performance, but that isn’t the case of a director.Will I direct movies? Well, filmmaking is in my mind, however, I don’t know how or when it will happen. I also think I should do my current job, acting, properly, first.I was predominantly a TV actress when I got it. I feel, if someone who was a mainstream actress would have got the award, movies and stories would have been made for them. Soon after I got the award, there was a phase in which filmmakers didn’t know where to place me. Can I be a heroine, mom, lover… they didn’t know. After I repeatedly made it clear that I am ready to take up any role, regardless of its size and after doing a few such roles, people started calling me. On the whole, I can’t claim to have had major changes in the way roles were offered to me, though small movies and good character roles are coming my way.Chachaji is a small movie that’s coming up. Kallan Dsouza by Jithu K Jayan has me as Soubin’s pair, and it also has Dileesh Pothen and Hareesh Kanaran as part of cast. I am currently shooting for K Harikumar’s film Jwalamukhi, which is about a woman who burns corpses. In India there are only three or four women doing that, including one woman from Thrikkakkara, named Saleena. However, the story isn’t based on their individual lives.

Title: It’s Hashtag Love for Raiza Wilson, next!
Content: While she is still basking in the glory for her look in FIR, Raiza Wilson has signed her next – Hashtag Love . This romantic film will feature Raiza and Walter Philips (of Meendum Oru Kaadhal Kadhai) in the lead roles. The film will be directed by Bosco , who had earlier worked as an assistant to Atlee.Talking about the film, Raiza says, “I play a bubbly, happy and innocent girl... something that I am excited about as I haven’t done this kind of a role yet. It is a heartfelt love story, with a twist. The script is youthful and relatable.” Even though she’s done Pyaar Prema Kaadhal, a romantic film, she says that this one is different. “It is more romantic and idealistic. There’s more of admiration, luck and destiny rather than realistic compatibility. The film has a lot to do with the concept of finding one’s soulmate,” says Raiza.Walter, who is back to films after a break, says, “I play John, a wedding photographer, who takes pictures with vintage cameras. How we both meet and fall in love forms the crux of the story. There is also a flashback portion, which shows a bit of my character’s past. We will begin the shoot from the first week of March, in Chennai. Thanu sir is producing the film.’’

Content: Kangana Ranaut fans were in for a surprise on August 21 as the actress announced her arrival on Twitter. And within 10 days of her debut on the micro-blogging site, Kangana has clocked 1 million followers. Title: Debaditya's new film on Sunita Hazra’s life
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Mike Pompeo: Four US Senators write to Pompeo seeking assessment on Kashmir and minority rights
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The US Seantors in their letter to Pompeo cited the Internet restrictions in the Valley

WASHINGTON: A bipartisan group of four US Senators have written a letter to US secretary of state Mike Pompeo requesting an assessment of the human rights situation in Kashmir and of the rights of religious minorities in India.

The letter, coming ten days before President Trump’s two-day state visit to India, is seen by some quarters as an effort to embarrass New Delhi, which is making strenuous efforts to show the situation in Kashmir is returning to normal by taking a second group of foreign envoys to the region this week.

Claiming to be “longtime friends of India,” the Senators wrote: “More than six months after Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government unilaterally revoked the autonomy of Jammu and Kashmir, the government continues to block most internet in the region. India has now imposed the longest-ever internet shut down by a democracy, disrupting access to medical care, business, and education for seven million people. Hundreds of Kashmiris remain in ‘preventive detention,’ including key political figures.”

“In addition, the Indian government has taken other troubling steps that threaten the rights of certain religious minorities and the secular character of the state. This includes the passage of the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act, which is being challenged in India’s Supreme Court,” they added, seeking a State Department assessment of a number of issues within India including: the number of individuals detained by the government for political purposes and the treatment of those individuals; current restrictions on communications in Jammu and Kashmir; the current accessibility of Jammu and Kashmir; and restrictions on religious freedoms in Jammu and Kashmir.

The Trump administration has been extremely circumspect about the Modi government’s actions with regards to Jammu and Kashmir and CAA/MRC issues, largely treating it as a domestic matter for New Delhi to sort out while expressing concern about human rights and civil liberties aspects.

Signatories to the letter are Republicans Lindsey Graham and Todd Young, and Democrats Chris Van Hollen and Dick Durbin.

Pink is said to be the colour when someone might just pop the question, red is a deeper hue and stands for strong relationship. From wearing these hues on your outfit, footwear, on your nails and in your make-up, here are ways to go amorous with these hues in your ensemble...

Title: #ValentinesDay: How about cooking with roses?
Content:
Quinoa, coarsely ground – ¼ cup

Rose petals, dried and edible – ¼ tbsp

Dried rose petal powder, edible – 2 tsp

Coconut milk, unsweetened – 6 cups

Cinnamon powder – ½ tsp

Jaggery, organic, grated – 1 tbsp

Salt – a pinch

Muslin cloth – ¼ meter

Potatoes, parboiled and peeled – 1 large

Clarified butter – 1 ½ tbsp

Sugar – ½ cup

Mawa (khoya) – 150 g

Full cream milk – ¾ cup

Gulkand – ½ tbsp

Rose petals, edible, dried, finely chopped – 1 ½ tbsp

Rose powder, edible – 2 tsp

Rose water – 10 ml

Green cardamom powder – ¼ tsp

Almonds blanched, peeled, slivered – 10 g

Pistachio nuts blanched, peeled and slivered – 5 g

Full fat milk – 2 litres

Rice – 120 g

Grain sugar – 40 g

Rose water – 3 to 4 drops

Dried rose petals – 10 g

Almonds – 100 g

Almond slivers – 25 g

Milk, full cream – 4 cups

Sugar – ½ cup

Saffron – ¼ tsp

Almond meal – ½ cup

Dried rose petals – ¼ cup

It’s Valentine’s Day today and we are sure that flowers, especially roses, are sure to be on the mind. But this time do more than just take a deep breath of the pretty bouquet. Take roses into the kitchen and get cooking with them. The petals, fresh and dried, make for a delightful addition to the kitchen. Go ahead and prepare a romantic meal with these ideas...Chef Reetu Uday Kugaji shares how to prepare this sweet delight.Boil and simmer ½ cup of water with grated jaggery. Strain, keep aside. Boil coconut milk, add the drained quinoa, cinnamon powder. Simmer and stir occasionally. Add rose petals and rose petal powder and salt. Simmer again and switch off the flame. Ensure that the pudding is thick. Cool and add jaggery syrup. Mix well. Pour the pudding into bowls, cool them completely and refrigerate for an hour. Garnished with rose petals, slivered almonds and pistachio nuts.This halwa has potatoes, gulkand, gulab (edible rose petals) and khoya, flavoured with green cardamom powder. It’s drizzled with rose water garnished with dried edible rose petals and slivered nuts. Chef Reetu Uday Kugaji shares her recipe.Grate the potatoes, keep aside. Heat the clarified butter, add the potatoes, sauté for a few minutes, stirring continuously. Add the sugar, grated mawa and sauté till it mixes. Add milk, rose powder and cook till the milk is absorbed. Add the gulkand and chopped dried rose petals. Sprinkle rose water. Add the almonds, pistachio nuts and green cardamom powder and mix well. Garnish with the dried rose petals slivered almonds, pistachio nuts and green cardamom powder.- Do not overcook the halwa.- Parboiling helps in preventing enzymatic browning that occurs in raw peeled potatoes.A traditional fave, Chef Manish Mehrotra show how to make this dessert.Soak rice. Boil milk till it’s reduced to half the volume. Add the soaked rice and cook till it thickens. Add chopped almonds and cook for 15 minutes on low heat till the kheer is thick. Add sugar. Cool, add rose water. Refrigerate till serving. Roast almonds and use as a garnish along with dried rose petals.Try this sweet meal-ender by Chef Manish MehrotraHeat and reduce milk. Add almond meal and sugar. Mix and strain. Add dried rose petals and saffron strands. Cool and pour into kulfi moulds. Demould and garnish with roasted almond flakes.Rose lassi is prepared with fresh yoghurt rose petals and rose syrup. It makes for a cooling beverage. Says dietician Rima Shah, “This drink can be had every day. One may also add rose water to it.”Says food scientist Nagendranath Chiluvuru, “We know that roses have a cooling effect on the skin. Similarly, rose petals have healing powers and are good for the gut. You can also prepare rose tea. It is an aromatic drink, best had without flavouring. It enhances the mood and makes an apt mid-morning cup. Add dried rose petals to hot water and steep it to make a tisane or herbal infusion.”Dietician Mansi Padechia lists why you ought to be surrounded by roses as much as you can, “Not many know this but roses have a lot of water. That is why ancient Chinese medicine used roses to treat digestive disorders, painful injuries and pre-menstrual irregularities. It contains a good amount of vitamin C, which helps skin cells fight free radicals, battle acne and give you a glow.”She shares a few ways to use roses:- Add 10-15 fresh rose petals to a glass of boiling water. It will turn pink, sip on this to improve your metabolism. You can also add a pinch of cinnamon powder to it.- Prepare rose lassi for a cooling beverage add sabza to it.- Sprinkle petals in your bath to relax the body.

Title: A white wedding for Tina Philip and Nikhil Sharma on April 4
Content: TV couple Tina Philip and Nikhil Sharma , who got engaged on August 4 last year, will tie the knot on April 4. (Interestingly the number 4 has a special significance in their life, as they started dating on February 4). It will be a Catholic wedding facing the beach at a Juhu restaurant, followed by a Hindu shaadi on April 8.What sets this couple apart is the fact that they played siblings on the show, ' Ek Aastha Aisi Bhee ' and fell in love, eventually. Tina shares, “I have always dreamt of a wedding on or near the beach because I wanted the ceremony to take place at the meeting point of sky, sea and land. So, I have zeroed in on a restaurant that faces the beach. My family priest from Bengaluru will solemnise the wedding at 5 pm.” She adds, “I have also incorporated certain Hindu traditions for a beautiful cross-culture wedding. The priest will use the holy water from the Ganges to bless us at the end of the ceremony. We will also light the unity candle together to signify the coming together of two individuals from different regions and religions. A reception will be held after the wedding ceremony and there will also be a few games.”For the beach wedding, the actress will wear a white ballroom gown and Nikhil will don a grey tuxedo. For the Hindu ceremony, Tina has chosen a red lehenga, while Nikhil will wear a sherwani. She shares, “Nikhil wants the Hindu wedding to take place at Haridwar’s Ganga Ghat , according to the Vedic rituals, early in the morning. He is currently in Haridwar to sort the formalities and seek permission. We are keeping our fingers crossed for it to happen. If it doesn’t work out, we will have the Hindu wedding in either Delhi — Nikhil’s hometown — or Mumbai, the city where we realised our dreams and met each other.”

Title: Gulki Joshi: I’d rather stay alone than be with the wrong man: Actress Gulki Joshi
Content:
Gulki Joshi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Gulki Joshi plays a cop in her next serial (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Gulki Joshi is one of those few television actresses who isn’t afraid of making her own path and following it despite all odds. A big fan of Sushmita Sen , the television actress not only idolises the dusky beauty but draws inspiration from her as well.Right from her first show Phir Subah Hogi, Gulki has taken up different kinds of roles and tried to portray challenging characters. She said, “So far I’ve done shows which are different from each other and very challenging. I’m very thankful to the industry for offering me a variety of characters to play on screen.”Gulki revealed the reason why she got inclined towards acting. “Acting and doing different roles is a way of extending and expressing myself,” said the actress. Talking about it further, Gulki professed, “I participated in a lot of plays right from college days. Theatre is a very rigorous training and I’ve learnt a lot from theatre. Right from a strand of your hair to how you twist your shoes. Everything conveys something about you, your story, your experiences. Theatre is very important to me, it helps me practice my art better.”Gulki Joshi plays a cop in her next serial (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)With Valentine ’s Day being celebrated today, the actress spoke about love and said, “I don’t plan on getting married anytime soon. I’m very independent, emotionally as well as financially. Also, I’m not a romantic person by nature. In fact, when someone gifts me a bunch of flowers, I get rather confused as to how I should be reacting. Not like I’ve never dated before, I have, but all my former partners have been just like me. And when it comes to work, kabhi na kabhi it takes a toll on your relationship. So right now, I’m concentrating purely on work. When the time is right, a right partner might also come into the picture.”Gulki, who was in Lucknow to shoot for her show Maddam Sir - Kuch Baat Hai Kyunki Jazbaat Hai, also shed some light on the kind of partner she would like to spend her life with. The actress said, “I want my man to be happy with himself. There aren’t many people who know how to be happy with oneself. They seek approval in others, in others opinion and approval of them. I’m very independent and well aware of my strengths and weaknesses. I’m very self-aware so the main criteria for my partner would be that he’s self- aware. I’m already quite happy and satisfied with the way my life is going. My partner has to add to it, not subtract. I’d rather stay alone than be with the wrong man.”— With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

Title: Karan Veer Mehra to return to TV after three years
Content: Actor Karan Veer Mehra , who was last seen in ' TV, Biwi Aur Main ', is all set to come back on the small screen after a gap of three years. He will be seen in the show, ' Tera Kya Hoga Alia '. Karan will play a dynamic journalist, who will be the new lead. He says, “I am excited to be a part of television, again. I am happy that people are exploring newer stories and this show is a black comedy, a genre I enjoy.”Ask what kept him away from television for three years and he replies, “I was busy with other projects and also waiting for the right role. As you become senior, the choices become fewer. However, in the last three years, I got many opportunities on other platforms and it was a learning experience. I am hoping that this role will become stronger during the course of the show and it will connect with the audience.”Having been a part of shows like 'Pavitra Ristha' and ' Amrit Manthan ', Karan feels that the content on television hasn’t changed drastically. He says, “What has worked for many years, still works and what hasn’t worked is still not working. Having said that, I haven’t been part of a show for a long time to make a judgement on the content. But, I feel that the success of any show depends on the writer and I enjoy working with good writers.”

Title: Vodafone Idea Q3 revenue up 2%, but loss at Rs 6,439 crore
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: After reporting the biggest quarterly loss in Indian corporate history in second quarter of 2019-20 (at Rs 50,922 crore), Vodafone Idea said on Thursday its loss in the third quarter stood at Rs 6,439 crore. The telco saw steep competition, high costs and large debt-servicing depressing earnings.

The massive loss in the second quarter was mainly on account of the provisions that the company had made towards the heavy dues that it needs to pay to the government — estimated at over Rs 53,000 crore — following the October 23 Supreme Court order regarding Adjusted Gross Revenues (AGR).

Vodafone Idea said while profitability remains elusive by a large distance, the company managed to grow its revenues in the third quarter by 2.3%. The upward movement came after 14 consecutive quarters of declines. Revenues for the company stood at Rs 11,089 crore.

The company said as it works on improving operational efficiencies and taming costs, it is also taking steps to seek a relief on the AGR order. “We continue to actively engage with the government seeking relief on AGR and other matters. After dismissal of our review petition, we have filed for modification of the supplementary order with the Supreme Court,” Vodafone Idea MD & CEO Ravinder Takkar said.

SC will soon be hearing an appeal where the aggrieved telecom companies — mainly Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea — seek a relief in the payment schedule according to which the court had ordered them to pay.

Title: Mosques may verify ‘ethnicity’ claims of Assamese Muslims
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

GUWAHATI: Neighbourhood mosque committees across Assam could be officially tasked with verifying the "ethnicity" of Assamese-speaking Muslims during the state's first census to distinguish “native” Muslim communities from “immigrant” ones.

The Assam Minorities Development Board's proposal to make mosques the official verification authority comes on the heels of a campaign by the Janagosthiya Samannay Parishad to get the state's 40 lakh Assamese-speaking Muslims to file affidavits to add an ancestral or ethnic surname to their Muslim names.

Board chairman Mominul Awal has already filed an affidavit to change his name to Mominul Awal Goria, the surname representing the ethnic community he belongs to. While adopting a new surname is a personal choice that many Assamese-speaking Muslims might not want to exercise, there is no escaping the census to establish their ethnicity.

Most native Muslims trace their ancestry to the 15th century, but don't have any legacy documents stretching so far back. "The government has yet to finalise the modalities for the census. We know there will be challenges, which is why the practical option is identification and verification by the local mosque jamats in the presence of enumerators from the revenue department," Awal said. "If an immigrant Muslim tries to pass off as a native just by adding an ethnic surname, the local mosque committee will surely be able to call that bluff."

Once the census exercise is notified, Assamese-speaking Muslims wanting to be enumerated would be required to apply online. These applications would be verified by the jamats and officials of the revenue department, Awal said.

The minorities development board has proposed categorising native Muslims into four groups —Goria, Moria, Desi and the Jolha tea tribe. This recommendation has been submitted to the high-powered committee set up by ministry of home affairs to recommend measures to implement Clause 6 of the Assam Accord of 1985.

"Constitutional, legislative and administrative safeguards, as may be appropriate, shall be provided to protect, preserve and promote the cultural, social, linguistic identity and heritage of the Assamese people," the clause states.

The committee's brief is to also define who is an "indigenous Assamese", a nomenclature that has been the bone of contention in a state inhabited by a large number of disparate ethnic communities.

The proposed census for now will be limited to the Brahmaputra Valley, which is where the Goria, Moria, Desi and Jolha communities are concentrated. The Barak Valley in south Assam has other Muslim communities that claim to be "native" but speak Bengali and other languages.

Title: RK Pachauri, who led UN climate body when it won Nobel, dies
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: RK Pachauri , 79, founder director of New Delhi-based think tank The Energy and Resources Institute (Teri) and former chairman of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), passed away on Thursday.

He was battling cardiac ailments and was put on life support in a Delhi hospital on Tuesday. He had undergone open heart surgery at Fortis Escorts Heart Institute after suffering a stroke in Mexico in July last year.

Under his leadership, IPCC got the Nobel Peace Prize jointly with former US vice-president Al Gore. The prize recognised IPCC for its "efforts to build and disseminate greater knowledge about man-made climate change, and to lay the foundations for measures needed to counteract such change." He headed the body from 2002 to 2015.

Pachauri resigned from Teri in 2015 in the wake of allegations of sexual harassment.

Pachauri had multiple cardiac issues and doctors at Fortis Escorts Heart Institute said he had been put on life support three days ago. "Pachauri had also undergone an open heart surgery but his condition didn't improve," said a source, adding that Pachauri was taken home around 7pm on Thursday, where he breathed his last.

Pachauri became chief executive of Teri in 1981 and headed the institute for more than three decades. He had to quit his post of executive vice-chairman in 2015 in the wake of allegations of sexual harassment, stalking and criminal intimidation. In October 2018, a Delhi court had framed molestation charges against Pachauri, who had denied the charges. The court had given him anticipatory bail in 2015.

"Teri is what it is because of Pachauri's untiring perseverance. He played a pivotal role in growing this institution, and making it a premier global organisation in the sustainability space," said Ajay Mathur, director general, Teri, who succeeded Pachauri in 2015.

Pachauri was honoured with Padma Bhushan in 2001 and Padma Vibhushan in 2008.

"Pachauri's contribution to global sustainable development is unparalleled. His leadership of the IPCC laid the ground for climate change conversations today," Teri chairman Nitin Desai said.

An alumnus of the Indian Railways Institute of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering in Jamalpur, Bihar, Pachauri served in various positions in the Indian Railways, including at the Diesel Locomotive Works in Varanasi.

He had served in several organisations in different positions before founding Teri.

Title: Kashmir news: Normalcy is almost back, say envoys after Jammu & Kashmir trip
Content:
Members of a foreign delegation walk on the banks of Dal Lake in Srinagar

NEW DELHI: The 25 envoys who had been taken to Jammu & Kashmir over the past couple of days returned on Thursday evening, with mixed reactions. While a few of the European envoys were less than satisfied, the majority of them appreciated the unprecedented access to different parts of Jammu & Kashmir establishment and society over the past couple of days.On Thursday morning, the envoys were briefed on the prevailing security situation by Lt Gen K J S Dhillon, commander XV Corps, following which the group moved to Jammu. There they met Lieutenant governor G S Murmu, chief secretary B V R Subbu and senior members of the administration. Separately, they met a cross-section of civil society in Jammu as well as Justice Gita Mittal, Chief Justice of J&K HC, who is currently ruling on cases involving detentions."We've got a full picture of what's happening here. It seems normalcy is returning. It doesn't mean that there are no difficulties. But, there is willingness to improve the situation; authorities are eager to make it happen," said FS Lotfe, ambassador of Mexico to India.Hans Dannenberg Castellanos, dean of diplomatic corps in India, added, "Today we had very good meetings with chief justice of J&K HC, chief secretary & LG. All three of them were very thorough in explaining to us the road map on how things would progress."Given the lack of development in J&K, other diplomatic sources felt that the removal of Art 370 was necessary. Normalisation of the situation, they said, is almost complete, the situation is calm. Security, while present, was not so visible as to be intrusive or oppressive. Shops were open in both Srinagar and Jammu, which was an encouraging sign, they said.But a clear roadmap for economic development is crucial, the sources added. Without education and jobs for the youth, it would be hard to prevent radicalisation and extremism in the UT. In their conversations with civil society, media, businesspersons in Srinagar and Jammu, the envoys admitted that while the interlocutors may have been vetted by the authorities, there were enough critical voices among them to make the entire exercise credible.There were some demands for the restitution of 35A, property and domicile rights. But the overwhelming demand was for the restoration of internet and communications. Many envoys said they had a "productive" exchange with Gita Mittal, Chief Justice of the J&K HC, who spoke on gender equality and giving LGBT rights.Sources said the envoys even wandered into areas around Dal Lake which had not been secured.In Video: ‘Situation normal in Srinagar’, say Afghan, Ugandan envoys

Title: Uddhav Thackeray overrules NCP on Elgar Parishad case
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A Maharashtra NCP minister said he was overruled by CM Thackeray in handing the Elgar Parishad case to NIA

MUMBAI: Shiv Sena and NCP appear to be on a collision course over entrusting the Elgar Parishad probe to the National Investigation Agency (NIA). "The CM has the powers," Maharashtra home minister Anil Deshmukh, who is from NCP, said on Thursday. "He overruled my proposal and granted consent to the NIA to take over the probe."

Deshmukh said that before taking a major "policy decision", the state government should have told the Union ministry that there was a need to reconsider its decision. "We should have consulted the advocate general," he said, adding, "I was overruled by the CM."

The Elgar Parishad was a gathering held by Dalit groups and others at Shaniwar Wada in Pune on December 31, 2017, a day before violence broke out between Dalits attending the annual Koregaon Bhima battle commemoration in Shirur taluka of Pune district and villagers from the area.

While the then BJP-Sena government blamed and arrested some "Naxal sympathisers" who had supported the Elgar Parishad, NCP, Congress and some Dalit groups blamed Hindutva forces for the violence.

After coming to office in alliance with Sena, NCP suggested that the Elgar Parishad case built by BJP was false. On January 10, Sharad Pawar wrote to Thackeray saying prominent citizens and innocent persons had been arrested by the Pune police in the case and the investigation should now be entrusted to an SIT headed by a senior IPS officer. The Union government acted swiftly to quash that possibility and issued an order for the NIA to take over the investigation.

NCP lodged a protest against the move. Even the Pune police challenged the proposal before the Pune special court which is hearing the case. The court is expected to pass an order on Friday.

A bureaucrat said that when MHA issued its notification on January 24, the home department submitted it to the law and judiciary department for opinion in view of Pawar and Deshmukh's reservations. The law and judiciary department replied that it was well within the powers of the Union ministry to entrust the investigation to the NIA in view of the gravity of the offence. The file, along with the opinion of the law and judiciary department, was then submitted to Deshmukh, who was not keen to entrust the inquiry to the NIA.

The file, along with the views expressed by Deshmukh, was submitted to the CM, who upheld the opinion given by the law and judiciary department. Accordingly, the home department on Wednesday issued an order saying it had no objection to the NIA talking over the inquiry.

Title: Pakistan tries to create security scare with Geelani rumour
Content: NEW DELHI: Tehreek-e-Hurriyat ex-chairman Syed Ali Shah Geelani 's deteriorating health sparked off rumours in the Valley over the past couple of days with a Pakistan-based separatist group urging Kashmir-based madrasa teachers and students to hold special prayer sessions for his health while also asking people to march towards Eidgah in Srinagar in the event of his death.While the statement issued by All Parties Hurriyat Conference from Muzaffarabad in Pakistan-Occupied Kashmir on Wednesday did raise security concerns in J&K, DGP Dilbag Singh told TOI that it was part of a design by Pakistan-based elements to provoke Kashmiris by citing Geelani's "continued detention" and setting off rumours about his impending death to create a security scare in Srinagar coinciding with the visit by a delegation of 25 envoys."It was a ploy by Pakistan-based elements to mobilise crowds and project Kashmir as 'troubled' before the foreign delegation. However, the propaganda was effectively countered with statements issued by Geelani's own family, his doctor as well as local administration and police denying the rumours of his death and clarifying that he was stable," Singh said.Geelani has been ailing for several years now and has been mostly confined to his home. After speculation was rife on Wednesday evening, authorities discontinued mobile services, which were only resumed on Thursday afternoon when statements were released by Geelani's family members that he was stable.While authorities in J&K told TOI that Geelani was now "fine" after a health emergency, the local administration appears to have prepared for all scenarios, including his death, given his advanced age and medical condition. Sources said Geelani has willed his funeral to be held at Hyderpora in Srinagar, even though the All Parties Hurriyat Conference based in Pakistan urged people to gather for his funeral at the Eidgah ground.In Video: News circulated about Geelani's health condition is 'baseless' Kashmir Divisional Commissioner

Title: Sanjeev Chawla: From garment seller to betting badshah
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Sanjeev Chawla (in mask) in Delhi, after his extradition from UK (ANI)

NEW DELHI: Twenty-five years ago, Sanjeev Chawla sold garments in south-east Delhi’s Jangpura market. It took just a few chance meetings with some punters placing and accepting bets on cricket matches for Chawla to change tracks.

For the son of a cloth seller, Chawla’s fortunes witnessed a meteoric rise in the betting business and he began to visit foreign countries with other bookies on business trips. It did not take him long to be introduced to cricketers at parties. A smooth talker, Chawla soon struck up friendships with the who’s who of cricket at the time. By 1998-1999, he was busy changing the outcomes of major cricket tournaments, including the famous 1999 series in Sharjah, investigators claim.

Chawla’s father was a small-time garments businessman and owned a shop in Bhogal market. Later, he and his brother had taken over the business and expanded it, after which the family shifted from their house in Jangpura to a three-storey bungalow in Noida in the 1990s.

A known face at business gatherings in five-star hotels in south Delhi, Chawla was allegedly introduced to the bigwigs of the match-fixing syndicate by an old friend who owned a well-known cassette company at the time. After a few meetings, Chawla started calling the shots in the betting syndicates based in India. He was soon termed the “god” of cricket betting in India, the police claimed.

A few years into the syndicate and Chawla had bought a house in Greater Kailash-II and rented a sprawling bungalow in London. His wife started a designer clothes brand based out of London. He kept travelling back and forth between UK and India between 1996 and 2000 until his passport was cancelled by the Indian government after he was found to be allegedly involved in match-fixing. However, the UK authorities gave him permission to remain in London till 2003 and, in 2005, he was granted UK citizenship.

Chawla took up a property at Kennington, southeast London, and moved with wife and children into a £1 million rented six-bedroom property in Temple Fortune.

Investigators add that in one of the after-match parties, Chawla was introduced to Rajesh Kalra, the other accused charged by the Delhi Police in the case. After his arrest in 2000, Kalra has been out of the public’s gaze, except for a big incident in 2014 when a criminal gang from south Delhi intercepted a vehicle moving around Rs 14 crore of cash, allegedly Kalra’s, and stole the money. The police recovered most of the money and Kalra has been under the income tax scanner since then.

Kalra had told the cops during interrogation that he had parted ways with Chawla in late 2000 after the ODI match between India and South Africa did not go according to plan, leading to discord between the two.

However, he alleged that Chawla controlled the Indian syndicate from London. Despite Interpol having issued a red corner notice against Chawla on the request of the CBI way back in 2001, he was only arrested in 2016 in London after repeated requests from the Indian government. In between, Scotland Yard had only questioned him about his alleged involvement in a match-fixing deal involving England players.

Title: ‘Nehru didn’t want Patel in govt’: Jaishankar, Guha spar
Content:
Learnt from the book that Nehru did not want Patel in the Cabinet in 1947 and omitted him from the initial Cabinet… https://t.co/pP3kXio9T9 — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1581519462000

Exercise of writing history for politics in the past needs honest treatment. "When Sardar died, a deliberate campa… https://t.co/E9snB3YMOg — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1581519475000

Some Foreign Ministers do read books. May be a good habit for some Professors too. In that case, strongly recommend… https://t.co/22yaeIK7fF — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1581575795000

NEW DELHI: Foreign minister S Jaishankar and historian Ramachandra Guha engaged in a war of tweets, spread out over two days, on whether Jawaharlal Nehru had included the name of Vallabhbhai Patel in his initial list of Cabinet members. Both asked the other to read books on the subject.On Wednesday, the foreign minister had released a biography of V P Menon, a senior civil servant who worked closely with Lord Mountbatten and Patel. He later tweeted in the evening, “Learnt from the book that Nehru did not want Patel in the Cabinet in 1947 and omitted him from the initial Cabinet list. Clearly, a subject for much debate.” He followed it with another tweet: “Exercise of writing history for politics in the past needs honest treatment.”“When Sardar died, a deliberate campaign was begun to efface his memory. I know this, because I have seen it, and at times, I fell victim to it myself,” he wrote while quoting Menon from the biography.Replying to foreign minister S Jaishankar’s tweet on Thursday morning, Guha presented an opposite view. “This is a myth that has been comprehensively demolished by Professor Srinath Raghavan... Besides, promoting fake news about, and false rivalries between, the builders of modern India is not the job of the foreign minister. He should leave this to the BJP’s IT cell,” he tweeted on Thursday morning.Jaishankar responded within two hours, writing, “Some foreign ministers do read books. May be a good habit for some professors too. In that case, strongly recommend the one I released yesterday.”The historian then shared a picture of the letter Nehru wrote to Patel, inviting him to join the first Cabinet of free India, calling him the “strongest pillar” of that Cabinet. “Can someone show this to @DrSJaishankar please?” he wrote around 1pm, also tagging the foreign minister’s verified handle. He also asked the minister to “consult” more books.“Sir, since you have a Ph D from JNU you must surely have read more books than me. Among them must have been the published correspondence of Nehru and Patel which documents how Nehru wanted Patel as the ‘strongest pillar’ of his first Cabinet. Do consult those books again,” he tweeted around 2.30pm.The biography is authored by historian Narayani Basu, who later tweeted, “We could sit around & debate this Cabinet list deal all day. At this point, I’m dropping out of it. It is no use fuelling a political fire, simply to hijack the story of a man who played a key role in modern Indian history & deserves his day in the sun.”
