Title: Govt disagrees with SC’s quota verdict
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Union social justice ministry has come out against the Supreme Court order that reservation for SC/ST in jobs and promotions is at the discretion of state governments, saying they are constitutional provisions which cannot be trifled with.

At the heart of the debate triggered by the apex court judgement are Articles 16 (4) and 16 (4A). The Uttarakhand government of BJP argued they are “enabling” clause and cannot be termed a fundamental right, and the top court agreed that they empower the states to provide for twin quotas if they feel SCs/STs are “not adequately represented”.

Disagreeing with the interpretation, Union social justice secretary R Subrahmanyam told TOI, “When enabling provision is put in the Constitution, it reflects the national will. So, they cannot be trivialised by saying that it is up to the state to implement them or not.”

The remarks from the top bureaucrat manning the social justice ministry constitute the first government dissent against the court’s latest comment on the twin constitutional provisions and their scope.

When the judgement came out and triggered an uproar this week, Modi government chose to tread a safe line by telling the Parliament that the Centre was “committed and dedicated to the welfare of SC/ST/OBC” and that “appropriate steps on the issue will be taken after discussion at the highest level”.

The proponents of social justice believe that the judgement will have a debilitating effect on the rights of marginalised classes as leaving the implementation of quotas to the discretion of states could encourage debate on the “inviolability” of quotas which has been a settled issue till now.

It is felt the judgement can easily trigger political lobbying from anti-quota classes which can put under pressure even the most amenable political parties. They cite the example of Madhya Pradesh where upper castes launched a political party SAPAKs ahead of December 2018 assembly elections in protest against the provisions introduced by the Centre to undo the dilution of SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act.

Political sources in the government agree with the implications of the judgement and say that a remedy would have to be found.

While a review petition is the likely course of action since the Centre was not a party to the case which resulted in the recent judgement, the Jarnail Singh case, which is at the heart of “reservation in promotions”, is still pending in the apex court.

A strong possibility exists that the Centre may seek a review of “quotas not a fundamental right” judgement as part of the Jarnail case – in which the court introduced “creamy layer” in promotion quotas for SC/ST.

Recently, the Centre asked the court to refer its 2018 verdict to a seven-judge bench for review, disagreeing with introduction of exclusionary “creamy layer” for SC/ST.

Till now, the concept of “creamy layer” – which declares the well-off as ineligible for quotas -- has been limited to OBCs and not been part of the SC/ST quota dispensation.

Title: Govt defends LPG price rise after row
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Amid continued Congress jibes and criticism from other parties, the government on Thursday defended the sharp increase in domestic LPG prices and said households will not be affected due to a matching increase in subsidy.

Explaining the math, a government statement said LPG price is determined on the basis of the fuel’s international price in the previous month. In January, the global price had shot up from $448 per tonne to $567, necessitating an increase of Rs 144.50 in the price of a 14.2-kg. cylinder in Delhi, the benchmark domestic market.

As a result, the statement said, the price of domestic non-subsidised LPG cylinder has increased from Rs 714 per cylinder to Rs 858.50. Simultaneously, domestic consumers availing subsidy has been cushioned by increasing the government support from Rs 153.86 per cylinder to Rs 291.48.

“Therefore, out of about 27.76 crore LPG consumers, in respect of about 26.12 crore consumers (who avail subsidy) the increase in price is borne by the government through enhanced subsidy,” the statement said.

Similarly for Ujjwala consumers, the subsidy has been increased from Rs 174.86 per cylinder to Rs 312.48. Here too the impact of price hike is mostly borne by the government.

The price hike, sharpest since January 2014 on Wednesday, had drawn sharp criticism from the Congress, TMC and the BSP. The Congress kept up the pressure on Thursday by demanding a roll-back and wondered if the price revision was “revenge” for the BJP’s defeat in the Delhi polls.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi tweeted a UPA-era picture of BJP leaders, including Smriti Irani, protesting against an increase in LPG price at the time. “I agree with these members of the BJP as they protest the astronomical 150 (sic!) Rs price hike in LPG cylinders,” Gandhi tweeted.

The Mahila Congress held a protest against the steep LPG price hike and submitted a memorandum to the government demanding a roll-back of the increased prices.

Title: Govt readies to implement new transgender law by March 31
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government has set in motion the ground work to implement the law that came into effect on January 10 to protect the rights of transgender persons. The ministry of social justice and empowerment has set March 31 as the deadline to frame rules and consultations are at an advanced stage. The ministry has also assigned Tata Institute of Social Sciences the task of preparing a draft scheme for welfare of transgender persons in consultation with stakeholders by mid March.

Aware of the anxiety of the transgender community members pertaining to certain provisions of the Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights ) Law, the ministry is now working on rules to address concerns like putting in place the process for identity certification based on the right of every transgender person to “self perceived identity” as per the new law.

When asked about the status of rules, Union social justice secretary, R Subrahmanyam told TOI, “We have held consultations and work is on to put in place the rules by March 31. The attempt is that implementation should be smooth and care will be taken that no transgender person faces any kind of distress while seeking identity certification.” Subrahmanyam said he was of the view that since the law provides for the right to self perceived identity, a self certification by a person who identifies as transgender should be good enough for issuing identity certificates.

The law states that a person shall have a right to self-perceived gender identity and transgender person may make an application to the district magistrate for issuing a certificate of identity as a transgender person, in such form and manner, and accompanied with such documents, as may be prescribed. The rules will now prescribe the process to enable implementation.

On the status of the the National Council for Transgender Persons to be set-up under the chairmanship of minister for social justice and empowerment to monitor the implementation of the law, the Subrahmanyam said, “First the rules will be framed and the scheme for welfare of transgender persons will be rolled out and then the council as stipulated under the law will follow.”

The new law gives makes room for protection of transgender persons against offences including physical and sexual abuse by providing for penalties ranging from imprisonment of 6 months to two years and a fine. It also introduces a provision for coverage of medical expenses through a comprehensive insurance scheme for sex reassignment surgery, hormonal therapy and other health issues.

In the budget for 2020-21, Rs 10 crore has been allocated for schemes pertaining to transgender persons. This amount was Rs 5 crore in 2019-20 and Rs 1 crore in 2018-19. The law got the Parliament’s assent in November and was notified in December. While all MPs welcomed the legislation in principle, the opposition raised concerns over lack of clarity in definitions and usages like “self perceived identity”, clauses pertaining to penalty and fine and issuance of certificates of identity.

Title: Enrique Iglesias welcomes his third child with Anna Kournikova secretly
Content: Pop singer Enrique Iglesias and former Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova welcomed their third child on January 30. The couple kept the news under wrap until now as the Grammy Award winner confirmed the same by sharing a picture of him with his newborn.He captioned the post, "My Sunshine 01.30.2020".Anna took to her Instagram to share a lovely picture with Enrique and their baby from the hospital.Enrique's brother Julio Iglesias Jr. hinted about the same in an interview where he said that he is uncle-ready! However, he didn't reveal the sex of the newborn child.The couple has been blessed with twins back in December 2017. They lovingly named them Lucy and Nicholas . Well, congratulations to the couple!In an interview, when the singer was asked how he would feel if his kids pursue career in music, Enrique had said that he wants them to do whatever is going to make them happy. He added he will be a cool dad!

Title: Worst over for NPAs: SBI MD Arijit Basu
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

SBI managing director Arijit Basu (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The worst is over as far as non-performing assets (NPAs) are concerned, a top official of the country’s largest lender said on Thursday. He added overreach by investigative agencies must be avoided.

“When you are working with public money, you need to be overseen and you have to have a Central Vigilance Commission or a CBI, but there should not be overreach. I think the government also in the recent past has taken a lot of measures to assure bankers,” said SBI ( State Bank of India ) managing director Arijit Basu . He said banks are ready to support credit growth in the country.

“Credit growth has slowed down, but on the retail side, which is the individual home loans and personal loans, we are growing at around 18%. Even in corporate loans and SME loans, we find that we have been able to sanction a large number of new term loans, which are getting disbursed,” he said at the Times Now Summit .

He said working capital loans have witnessed moderation, which is a reflection of a certain amount of slowdown but was confident the situation will improve soon. “It is not only the government, but we in the bank management also have given this assurance. There may have been some hesitation but we have passed that and we are now definitely ready to continue to support the credit growth in the country.”

Basu said going forward the sector will see a much better quarter. “There will be one or two cases that will come up here and there, but I think banks will be able to deal with them.” He said the steps undertaken by the government to repair the banking sector and legislations, such as Insolvency and Bankruptcy code (IBC,) have helped immensely.

“It is not all gloom. The measures that have been taken by the government in the last few years, many of them may not be coming out in the economic data as of now, but we understand that they have been for a good cause. The way in which IBC has empowered the banks, the attitude certain promoters had on how they will deal with the banks has completely changed. So, it has become much easier for us to go forward.”

Basu said for SBI and most other banks, the retail sector is doing very well. Personal loans are growing, services sector is doing well. NPA ratios are very low. In the corporate sector also, industries like steel have done well, he said.

Title: Bihar: Parties intensify poster war in Patna ahead of assembly election
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Political posters are put up in the city on every consecutive day with pun intended cartoons and slogans.

PATNA: Assembly election in Bihar is at least six months away but the ruling as well as opposition parties are already busy training their guns on each other through posters.

For over a month now, new political posters are put up in the city on every consecutive day with pun intended cartoons and slogans. Latest in the series was a poster with a punchline, ‘Thugs of Bihar’ with cartoon of incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad as lead. The latest poster reads, ‘Lara Film Presents — Thugs of Bihar’ and shows a reel with illustrations of kidnappings and murders among other crimes, possibly pointing towards the RJD regime (1990-2005). It also has a one-liner — ‘Zara Yaad Karo, Wo Kahani Purani (Try to remember the old story)’. The poster incidentally has no individual or party’s name as its propagator.

The ‘Thugs of Bihar’ appeared two days after the RJD poster put up near Income Tax roundabout on Monday with the punchline —’Do Hazar Bees, Nitish Kumar Finish’. The poster mentions the name of Bhai Arun Kumar, general secretary of RJD (Bihar) and Umesh Yadav, another party functionary from Kumhrar in Patna.

Another RJD’s poster with a photograph of Tejashwi Prasad Yadav shows CM Nitish Kumar sitting on a chair with a caption — ‘Kursi Pujari (worshipper of chair)’. The poster tries to attack the Nitish government on health, education and unemployment issues. It further says that youth will get jobs, migration will stop, people will get proper health and education facilities if Tejashwi comes to power.

RJD spokesperson Mrityunjay Tiwari said the poster war started by JD(U). “They started with ‘Theekey To hai Nitish Kumar (Nitish Kumar is fine)’. We have given a befitting reply by saying that 2020, Nitish Kumar finish,” he said.

Earlier, big hoardings with Nitish’s face and slogans like ‘Kyun Kare Vichar, Thike To Hai Nitish Kumar (Why should I rethink, Nitish Kumar is perfect (as CM)’ were put up by JD(U). Later, RJD responded with ‘Jhooth ki tokri, ghotalo ka dhanda’ and ‘Trouble Engine, Ek Jhooth Express’ posters.

Posters attacking RJD have also been put up in the state capital showing Lalu-Rabri era with broken roads, bloodshed, people holding guns, students studying under lantern and buffaloes in the background while Nitish era was shown with smooth roads and flyovers, girls cycling to school and women switching on the light.

JD(U) functionary and state IPRD minister Neeraj Kumar said the posters were being put not by JD(U) but its sympathizers and common people, who don’t want the return of lawlessness and lack of development they had witnessed during RJD regime.

Title: Adopt old methods to save water: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

PATNA: Magsaysay Award winner Rajendra Singh said on Thursday that water can be conserved by adopting traditional methods in the country.

Water is climate and climate is water, said Singh, while addressing the sixth symposium on ‘Water governance: Issues and Challenges’ organized by Development Management Institute (DMI) at Bihar Museum here on Thursday.

Singh, also known as the ‘Waterman of India’, said the world might face the wrath of third world war for water and natural resources. He stressed upon the need and urgency of water management across the world. “There is a need of dialogue between environmentalists and the policymakers to find a solution to the emerging water crisis,” he said.

In the context of ‘Jal-Jevan-Hariyali’ project in the state, the waterman said the Bihar government should focus on water literacy movement similar to the model adopted by the Maharashtra. He also shared his experience when Rajasthan was facing water crisis due to encroachment of farmland. “For sustainable watershed management, we need to recharge groundwater and make efficient use of water,” he said.

Singh also released his book ‘Main Hi Jal Hoon’ on the occasion.

DMI director Hemanth Rao talked about the relevance of the symposium theme. “The institute has taken the opportunity to bring environmentalists, experts, government officials and policymakers on a single platform to discuss water crisis and its solution,” he said.

The experts talked about fostering community participation in water governance, issues in groundwater use and availability in two separate technical sessions.

DMI chairman Anup Mukherjee and its dean Niraj Kumar and other members were present on the occasion.

Title: TAKE solutions profit up 41%
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chennai: TAKE Solutions on Thursday said its profits for the December quarter rose 40.6% year-on-year at Rs 51.1 crore. The operating revenues grew to Rs 651 crore at 24.8% from Rs 521 crore and the operating EBITDA rose to Rs 108 crore from Rs 88 crore. Srinivasan H R, vice chairman and MD, TAKE Solutions said, “TAKE has recorded a strong revenue growth of 7% as compared to the last quarter. We are delighted that our post-merger milestones of our recent acquisitions (DataCeutics and KAI Research) have successfully completed and the synergies have started to contribute towards increase in client base. The focus for coming quarters will continue to be on penetrating global markets.”

The share price of the company was up 2.7% at Rs 98.6 at the stock exchanges.

Title: ‘Boardroom battle with KKR led to Thapar’s exit’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Mumbai: Private equity firm KKR India may have had a role in the boardroom battle at fraud-hit CG Power and Industrial Solutions that led to the ouster of promoter-chairman Gautam Thapar from the company, proxy advisory firm InGovern said on Thursday.

KKR had a debt exposure to Avantha Holdings, which the Thapar-promoted company failed to repay completely. “This may be why the relations went downhill between KKR and Thapar,” InGovern said. It further said that upon request by Avantha to convert debt into equity, KKR had asked for the appointment of Narayan Seshadri initially as a consultant but later as an independent director on the board of CG Power.

“Seshadri has close business interests with KKR,” the report by InGovern said. Soon thereafter a three-member committee that included Seshadri was formed to investigate certain transactions in CG Power. Law firm Vaish Associates, commissioned by the committee, then came out with a report which showed many contentious transactions. Markets regulator Sebi, acting on the Vaish report, barred Thapar and other senior executives of CG Power from accessing the securities market. Subsequently, the company’s board removed Thapar from the chairman’s post.

KKR became a shareholder of CG Power with a 10% stake after invoking pledged shares of the promoter. “According to Thapar, the events at CG Power have been orchestrated by the lenders as KKR wanted to oust the promoter and take control of the company,” InGovern said. Reacting to the report, KKR said, “We have been a lender to Avantha and not a shareholder of CG Power until we enforced our share pledge on September 16, 2019 as a result of defaults by Avantha. As a result of our enforcement, we now own just under 10% of the equity stake in CG Power.”

KKR further stated that “As a shareholder, it is in our interest to engage constructively with the company, both through its board and shareholders, in order to preserve and enhance the value of the company. The appointment of Seshadri as an independent director predates our share pledge enforcement and in any case, it is entirely within the board’s power to manage the affairs of the company in accordance with its charter”.

Subsequently, the three-member committee was dissolved and a new panel was formed that included Seshadri as its chairman to focus on improving the company’s operations, capital restructuring including raising funds and dealing with regulators.

InGovern said an analysis of the issues at CG Power reveals that the boardroom battle has led to value destruction for minority shareholders of the company.

Title: Fire vehicles can’t enter into this concrete jungle
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Narrow lanes of a society in Ghanshyamnagar of Varchha

Surat: Every zone of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has residential areas where it is impossible for fire vehicles to enter in case of emergency.

There are at least 20-odd residential societies in areas like Varachha where there is no open space for the fire vehicles to enter in case of emergency due to unplanned development. For the first time, the SMC commissioner has asked the officials to spot these areas and, if required, take police protection to carry out anti-encroachment drive and make way for the emergency vehicles.

In Karanj area, which falls in Varachha zone, there are societies like Gayatri society, Ambika Nagar, Sitaram Nagar, Hari Iccha Industrial Society, Jawahar Nagar and Rang Nagar where there are concrete jungles criss crossing the way.

“In case of a fire breaking out in any of these places, it is almost impossible for the fire vehicles to enter and rush to the spot. It will take us an hour to take equipment to the spot. And by the time we reach there, things will have been gutted in the fire,” said a senior fire officer who worked in Varaccha zone of the city.

This is not an isolated case, but in many parts of the Diamond City, there are densely populated areas where there is very little space for two-wheelers to pass through. In such areas how can a fire vehicle enter?

After fire incidents at Takshashila arcade in May 2019 and Raghuvir Celeum in January 2020, fire and emergency department has started a survey mainly in commercial areas of the city.

N V Upadhayay, deputy commissioner in-charge of fire department, told TOI: “The city has witnessed all major deadly fires in commercial and industrial segments only. In residential areas, fire incidents are also a cause for concern. We have undertaken a survey across the city and will come up with a list of such areas shortly.”

Upadhayay added, “Once that list is prepared, we will start our work one by one. If required police protection will be taken but such encroachments will be removed which are an obstruction to the fire vehicles.”

Title: Police detain six during protest on AK Road
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Surat: Varachha police detained five women and a man on Thursday after they refused to end their protest at Shreenathji Dwar society on A K Road. The residents of a society started their agitation against a developer who, along with cops had arrived at the society to take possession of its nearly 200 yard plot worth Rs 1 crore.

The society residents claimed that the plot is a common property of the society which is reserved for recreational purposes. However, the developer claimed that they have purchased the land from the previous owner.

On Thursday, the developer went to the spot with police bandobast when residents started to protest. Later additional police force was called and those taking leadership in the agitation were detained. "Those protesting were detained after argument with police when they tried to stop those who had sought police protection. The developer recently won a case in court after which they wanted possession for which police protection was sought," said a police officer.

According to sources in the police, the society was developed in 1992 and the plot was given to the society for recreational activities. In recent past, the developers approached the society to take possession of the plot claiming that they own it but the society residents refused to hand it over and approached the court.

Title: You can get FASTags for free till Feb-end
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Lucknow: Here’s another chance to get a FASTag as the NHAI has extended the deadline to get it for free till February 29.

FASTags can be obtained for free at RTO, government e-suvidha kendras, select petrol pumps, NHAI toll plaza counters from February 15. To increase digital toll collection, the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) has decided to waive off FASTag fee till February 29. Although the cost of installation is just Rs 100, officials believe that offer to provide it free will motivate people to get FASTags at the earliest.Earlier, NHAI had issued free FASTags from January 21 to 27.

As per the NHAI data, over 3,000 vehicles go through each toll plaza everyday in the city, of this only 50% of vehicles have installed FAST ags in their four-wheelers. The remaining vehicles go through the cash lane.

Title: DMart stake sale to fetch Rs 3,500cr
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Bengaluru: Radhakishan Damani and other promoters of Avenue Supermarts informed the exchange they would be selling 2.28% stake or 1.5 crore shares of the company in a Rs 3,500-crore deal. The company that owns supermarket chain DMart will over a period of few days offload shares through an offer for sale (OFS). TNN

The stake is likely to be priced at 5% discount to Wednesday’s close price of Rs 2,482 and is being done to meet Sebi’s requirements on the minimum public shareholding requirement. At the end of this exercise, the promoters’ stake in the company will come down to 75% from 79%.

Earlier this month, Avenue Supermarts sold 2 crore shares at an issue price of Rs 2,049, reducing promoters’ stake to 77.27%. It had been 79.73% as of December 2019. Avenue Supermarts shares have surged 730% from its IPO price of Rs 299 in March 2017 — making founder Radhakishan Damani the sixth-richest Indian with a net worth of $12 billion after the company’s stock price hit record highs. The company’s shares rose over 2% to Rs 2,542 on Thursday on the BSE.

Title: Few bus operators follow safety norms in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A View of Luxury buses at Mithapur bus stands in Patna on Thursday which runs without following safety measure... Read More

PATNA: The Ferozabad bus accident , in which 14 people were killed on Wednesday night, raised questions about the safety norms being followed by bus operators in Bihar. Most of the victims were from Bihar as the bus was coming from Delhi to Motihari in East Champaran when it met with an accident on the Agra-Lucknow Expressway.

Though state transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said on Thursday that the permits of those buses not following safety norms will be cancelled, most of the private interstate buses under Bihar State Road Transport Corporation (BSRTC) do not have even the emergency gates. “We are going to launch awareness drive for bus drivers in association with Aurangabad’s Institute of Driving Training and Traffic Research (IDTR),” Agarwal said and added: “We will also give Rs250 honorarium to each bus driver and food packets during training about safety measures and precautions.”

Buses, run by the private operators mostly run without following safety measures; like they don’t keep hammer near windshield, fire extinguisher and medical kit. However, some drivers claimed their buses have facilities like CCTV cameras, speed governor, LCD screens and Wi-Fi.

Jhameli Singh, the cleaner of a private bus which plies on Patna-Purnia route, told this newspaper that his bus has one emergency gate “but we do not know how to open it. This has to be done by the engineers. We do not need firs-aid kit and fire extinguisher in our bus as people carry their own stuff which they need”.

Ram Kalraj, a bus driver at Mithapur bus stand, said there is no emergency gate in his double-decker bus for Gorakhpur. “There is no space for emergency gate. People can break the windscreen in case of emergency. We have one hammer that I keep under my seat,” he said and added: “If we put one hammer near every window, passengers will certainly break the glass and it would cost Rs10,000 to replace it. We have fire extinguisher, medical kit and other safety tools.”

Gopal Sharan, an interstate bus driver, said, “I keep the emergency gate locked because passengers often open it. It causes inconvenience to the cleaner.”

Sunil Kumar Singh, another interstate bus driver, said they have all the facilities in their buses except the emergency gate and fire extinguisher. “We had a fire extinguisher which was removed as we didn’t know how to use it,” he said.

Jeevan Kumar, a passenger travelling to Ranchi, said the bus drivers and cleaners need to be sensitized about such accidents. “It is the responsibility of the state government to ensure that those who get bus permits follow the safety norms,” he said.

Title: 500 sub-inspector aspirants protest in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Bihar police aspirants stage a protest march demanding CBI inquiry into their examination paper leak, in Patna... Read More

PATNA: Around 500 sub-inspector (SI) aspirants once again staged a protest near the J P roundabout in the state capital on Thursday. They demanded re-examination as well as CBI inquiry into the alleged leak of question papers of the Bihar police sub-inspector recruitment examination.

The SI aspirants burned an effigy of chief minister Nitish Kumar and raised anti-government slogans. They marched towards the J P roundabout from Patna Science College at 12pm.

One of them, Nitish from Jamui, alleged that many students had received the question papers much before the exam began. He told this newspaper, “We want the Bihar Police Subordinate Services Commission to conduct the exam again.”

Another aspirant, Suraj Kumar Sinha from Samastipur, said, “A candidate, who had not even written the examination, qualified it. How can this be possible?” he asked.

The Gandhi Maidan police lodged an FIR against seven people, who had led the protest. Town DSP Suresh Kumar said, “No water cannons or batons were used against the protesters, a complaint was filed against seven people, who manipulated the SI aspirants.”

Title: Electric cars: Electric cars likely to get same power specs
Content: Chennai: In a bid to standardise the various parts of the electric vehicle (EV) ecosystem, several constituents, including original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), have come together to define standards. The move is primarily aimed at commercial vehicles that will ply with swappable batteries The OEMs — which include Mahindra & Mahindra, Lucas TVS, Okinawa, Kinetic, GEM, Ashok Leyland , Exicom, Amara Raja Batteries and Exide — are involved in preparation of these specifications. “We have coordinated this effort and did iterations in the documents based on feedback from all different stakeholders,” said Prabhjot Kaur , CEO of the Centre for Battery Engineering and EVs (C-BEEV). The centre comes under the department of electrical engineering at IIT-Madras. The project is spearheaded by professor Ashok Jhunjunwala “We don’t want to commit the mistakes of mobile handset companies that did not standardise chargers, etc, when it would have made sense. We will continue to work towards setting up more common standards for the industry,” KaurThe standards are grouped under ‘Lock Smart - Vehicle Battery Charger Cloud Protocol (or LS-VBCC).They will act as the cornerstone for EVs.“The battery-swapping industry standard has been designed with a group coming from different segments — charger manufacturers, vehicle OEMs, battery manufacturers and other stakeholders,” Kaur said.The protocol specifies the communication to be implemented between subsystems that need to interact with each other, be it battery and vehicle, battery and charger, battery and hand-held device or apps and server.The purpose of the standard is to promote interoperability between energy operators, vehicles, batteries and chargers.This would make it agnostic to the make & model of these subsystems for an operator to procure the components. It would also be a great benefit for users to acquire or exchange the batteries and gain from the lower capital expenditure and operating expenditure and be flexible on the location of the operator across the intended area of travel.“Using Esmito’s platform at C-BEEV in IIT-Madras and several other locations, we have done several three-wheeler and two-wheeler pilots using the standard swapping platform. Esmito is now offering this solution as a SaaS platform for energy/fleet operators,” Kaur said.For example, the standards will involve vehicle identification number (VIN) and battery identification number (BIN) in specified formats that will help identify where the parts were produced, including if the batteries are lead acid, lithium ion or cobalt-based batteries, among others.“We need to still have standards on batteries, chargers, in all different segments and BIS is working on these,” she said.India has the potential to become one of the largest EV markets in the world, with the government pushing for the segment in order to curb pollution and reduce reliance on import-dependent fossil fuel, says a World Economic Forum report.The uptake of EVs has been slow in the country due to the high upfront as well as life cycle costs. But long-term investment in research and development (R&D) will create sustained growth.A step towards cheaper EVs is to sell the vehicles without batteries and allow the user to swap drained batteries with fully charged ones at dedicated charging stations.For example, if a conventional EV costs Rs 14 lakh, one without battery will cost only Rs 6.5 lakh and the user can drive into a charging station and swap the batteries in the time it takes to refuel a fossil fuel vehicle.

Title: West Bengal: Autos, rickshaws hope to turn into last-mile link for commuters
Content:
Rickshaws want permanent stands near Metro stations and autos look to pick up more passengers on the Karunamoy... Read More

KOLKATA: As the East-West Metro sets off on its commercial run from Friday, local transporters—buses, autos and even rickshaws—are keeping their fingers crossed. The new alignment, they claim, can help them remain “profitable and relevant,” provided the administration helps them become “the last-mile connecting medium”. Everything depends on whether they would be allowed near the new Metro stations or not.“Delhi Metro stations have several official auto and rickshaw stands around them. There is no reason why that model cannot be repeated here,” said Amit Dolui, an auto operator. As of now, auto operators have decided to keep some “flying” vehicles at four important points: Kadapara, Central Park in the morning, Sector V near Wipro building and City Centre. If the response is good, auto unions plan to set up permanent stands. The same applies for rickshaws, which have apparently promised police to operate on bylanes.“If you see the Metro alignment, not many residential blocks come directly in its path. It caters to the commercial hubs. At the same time, thousands of commuters are not likely to let go of the opportunity to use this Metro just because it’s a bit off their routes. We will become important in ferrying them to and from stations to the main roads and junctions,” said Tarit Das, an auto operator. “We stand to lose a few passengers who usually gets off on Bypass or visit City Centre, but we can gain from the higher number of people travelling from Phoolbagan to Bypass to take the Metro to Sector V.” Das has already shifted to the Karunamoyee-New Town route instead of his earlier route to Phoolbagan, as the former appears to be the “high-passenger” zone.Rickshaw-pullers are hoping for “ready passengers” to Metro stations. “The East-West Metro will benefit us. Everyone travelling within Salt Lake to their workplaces will try to use Metro as a more viable option when compared to an auto. To get to the stations from a short distance, they are likely to avail of rickshaws,” said Prabir Das, a rickshaw-puller.Initial estimates suggest that a large chunk of daily commuters, who earlier alighted at the existing Girish Park Metro station, might get off at MG Road station, take an auto to Kadapara, from where they will take the new Metro to Sector V or Karunamoyee. Similarly, those getting off on the Bypass for office or City Centre might opt for this Metro. A few commuters coming from extreme north and using Ultadanga as the transit point may also change their travel plans, provided the new Metro is viable and helps save commute time.Bus operators, however, said they did not expect too much change, given the “very short” distance of Metro operation, as of now. “But we are keeping an eye on the passenger behaviour, especially to Sector V, who might prefer to travel down to Bypass directly. Given that the East-West Metro work has begun yet again in Bowbazar, we might have to realign a few routes from Ultadanga and Chingrighata in near future. But as of now, we are expecting better footfall at the two Bypass stations,” said a member from the Joint Council of Bus Syndicate. Even several shuttle service operators are keeping an eye out for operations from Bypass.

Title: CCI calls Amazon’s arguments ‘mischievous’, begins probe
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

(File photo)

BENGALURU/NEW DELHI: The Competition Commission of India ( CCI ) slammed Amazon India in the Karnataka high court (HC) on Thursday, saying its arguments were “mischievous” and that it is not answerable to the Seattle-based technology major before it begins a probe.

CCI has also started its probe even as Amazon is fighting for an interim stay order on the same in the HC. Three sources aware of the matter said members of the Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh had gone to the CCI office on Thursday to make the first deposition in the matter. TOI has seen the CCI notice given to the Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh for this.

CCI’s comments in HC come after Amazon asked why the US e-tailer wasn’t informed about this probe that was announced on January 13. CCI’s advocate said Amazon’s “entitlement” has no legal ground and it is trying to create confusion about the matter being a foreign direct investment (FDI) law violation.

“The CCI is not questioning the source of money or the holding structure, it is probing what happens after the money comes to India and whether that’s anti-competitive,” the advocate said.

After the arguments by lawyers of both CCI and Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh, Flipkart’s lawyer will make a case on the matter on Friday along with a legal representative of the Confederation of All India Traders ( CAIT ).

TOI had reported in its February 13 edition that Flipkart has been made a respondent to the petition, which was confirmed by the Walmart-owned Indian e-tailer. To be sure, Flipkart hasn’t made its stance on the matter official yet, but it will face a probe too if Amazon does not get an interim stay in the matter.

CCI’s legal representative also said the e-commerce study released by the regulator cannot be applied to this case as facts differ. CCI’s order to probe Amazon came days before Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos landed in India for a visit last month, where he announced a fresh $1-billion investment.

Right after Bezos’s announcement, commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal kicked up a row saying Amazon wasn’t “doing any favour” to India by investing as it was to cover up losses, even questioning how a marketplace could lose so much money.

Title: Directors feel heat, seek cover against legal action
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The directors & officers’ (D&Os’) insurance policy, which compensates key management personnel of a company against legal actions, is seeing a surge in demand. The cover, which was earlier being purchased by businesses with a global exposure, is now being bought by companies with only domestic stakeholders as well.The trigger for the renewed demand for this cover has been the amendment to the Companies Act last year. Under this, the government can ask the National Company Law Tribunal to hold directors and key management personnel responsible without any limit to liability in the event of fraud .Besides this, there have been several actions by enforcement authorities against directors in recent times, particularly in the financial sector. Insurers say that the regulator’s action against directors of a large private bank have triggered claims under the policy. The regulatory action against IL&FS is also believed to have triggered a claim by the erstwhile management.“Another significant cause for a spike in claims has been in the employment practices coverage afforded to some large IT companies. Many of them have employees in the US, which is a highly litigious geography in this area and the industry has seen many claims coming from this exposure. It has an impact on the pricing of the policy,” said IFFCO Tokio General Insurance EVP (underwriting) Subrata Mondal.According to Praveen Vashista of Howden India Insurance Brokers , there has been a big surge in demand for D&O policies. “We are seeing lots of demand for D&O, which is part of the liabilities business. Because of increased demand, we have enhanced the size of our liability team and now have 55 people,” said Vashista. Insurers say that before joining, directors are asking companies whether they have a policy that will protect them from liability claims.According to Mondal, rates for D&O cover are firming up in sectors like finance, IT and real estate where the industry has seen a spike in regulatory action, financial downturn and consequent claims under D&O. “The claim payouts always start with defence costs and often involve out-of-court settlements. Given the length of the judicial process in many countries and long-tail nature of liability claims, the defence costs are high, and settlement is mostly out of court,” he said.D&O policies cover key officials against legal action from regulators, shareholders or employees. Besides covering the cost of legal fees for the defence, it also pays penalties. If there is a regulatory fine on an individual, which is civil in nature, the D&O cover will get triggered, provided coverage for civil fines and penalties have been granted. If the fine or penalty is criminal in nature or has criminal undertones, the policy will not cover it, but it will allow the insured to defend the imposition of the same.Promoters are also facing regulatory action because of the insolvency process during which violations come to light. The D&O cover can be extended for directors for past actions even after the board is dismissed, provided it has been purchased in advance.“When we underwrite a D&O policy, an important underwriting criterion is the financial health of the company. Most insurers generally frown upon granting a D&O to a company whose finances are distressed or already in the red. Higher claims activity will often see a higher demand for the insurance product from the industry,” said Mondal.

Title: KRML promotes use of public transport, sustainable devpt
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Kochi: Hinting at the need for having more open spaces in the city, Ernakulam MP Hibi Eden said that such places are a requirement for the well-being of both elderly people and youngsters. He said that all modern cities have public plazas where people can gather. He was addressing the gathering at Comfort Plaza in Jos Junction on Friday evening after launching an event to promote cycling. The event is part of the ‘Ease of living Initiatives’ launched by Kochi Metro Rail Ltd ( KMRL ).

Eden along with Ernakulam MLA T J Vinod cycled from MG Road Metro station to Comfort Plaza to promote public transport systems and non-motorized transport systems. “Promotion of public transport and rights of pedestrians should become a big movement. By extending Kochi Metro to Kakkanad, providing last mile connectivity and sufficient parking, KMRL aims to encourage people to use public transport systems,” he said.

The Ernakulam MP also encouraged people to vote in the ‘Ease for living’ contest, which will help to improve Kochi’s ranking. The contest is an indictor to the achievements in basic infrastructure development of the city.

Speaking at the event, Vinod said citizens should bring down the use of private cars. “It is the only way to reduce the number of vehicles operating in the city,” he said. “Buses, auto rickshaws and online taxi operators along with Kochi Metro provide a strong network of public transport system. The city is yet to tap the potential of public transport systems,” he said.

KVP Krishna Kumar, councillor representing Ernakulam South and actor Veena Nandakumar participated in the event to promote cycling along with KMRL. Music band Thekkan Chronicles performed at the plaza.

By organizing such events, KMRL is trying to convey the importance of road safety, usage of public transport, e-mobility, sustainable development and use of non-motorized transport to the public. The metro agency will introduce 1,000 cycles in the city. The cycles will be brought in various phases. With this aim, the metro agency will conduct an event every month at Comfort Plaza.

Title: PC shipments in ‘19 at a 6-yr high on mega deals: IDC
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chennai: Spurred by mega deals in government-driven education projects and corporates upgrading to Windows 10, personal computer shipments saw a 6-year high in 2019.

A report from global research firm the International Data Corporation shows that 2019 saw a year-on-year growth of 18.5% in the category with a total of 11 million shipments made during the period. The previous year saw 9.3 million units shipped. The October-December quarter saw a 16.5% YoY growth with a total of 2.3 million shipments. While the commercial segment brought volumes to the table, the consumer segment that saw a fall in 5 consecutive quarters grew 4.6% in the quarter, shipping around 9.5 lakh units, the report added.

“While large businesses were the volume driver, vendors invested in building new teams, exploring new channels, and educating the customers to tap the SMB segment,” says Bharath Shenoy, market analyst, PC, IDC India. Among categories, the gaming segment grew at 51.1% YoY. While most of the vendors increased their shipments in the gaming segment, Asus stood out as a leading vendor with one in every four notebooks shipped being a gaming one from the vendor in 2019. Notebook PCs too saw a growth.

Being thinner and lighter with enhanced mobility features, they are increasingly getting preference from the consumers, education sub verticals, and enterprises. The segment saw a 67.7% category share.

All top brands saw a growth in the number of shipments. For the whole year, Lenovo saw an 83% jump in growth to 3.5 million units in 2019.

HP India shipped 2.9 million units with a strong growth in the enterprise segment, the report added. “We have seen growth from all segments including retail, commercial and SMBs. We have seen improved consumer sentiment and that is reflected in overall growth numbers of PCs, said Vickram Bedi, senior director, personal systems, HP Inc. India.

Title: EV makers come together, set up common standards
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chennai: In a bid to standardise the various parts of the electric vehicle (EV) ecosystem, several constituents, including original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), have come together to define standards. The move is primarily aimed at commercial vehicles that will ply with swappable batteries.

The OEMs — which include Mahindra & Mahindra, Lucas TVS, Okinawa, Kinetic, GEM, Ashok Leyland, Exicom, Amara Raja Batteries and Exide — are involved in preparation of these specifications. “We have coordinated this effort and did iterations in the documents based on feedback from all different stakeholders,” said Prabhjot Kaur, CEO of the Centre for Battery Engineering and EVs (C-BEEV). The centre comes under the department of electrical engineering at IIT-Madras. The project is spearheaded by professor Ashok Jhunjunwala.

“We don’t want to commit the mistakes of mobile handset companies that did not standardise chargers, etc, when it would have made sense. We will continue to work towards setting up more common standards for the industry,” Kaur

The standards are grouped under ‘Lock Smart - Vehicle Battery Charger Cloud Protocol (or LS-VBCC).

They will act as the cornerstone for EVs.

“The battery-swapping industry standard has been designed with a group coming from different segments — charger manufacturers, vehicle OEMs, battery manufacturers and other stakeholders,” Kaur said.

The protocol specifies the communication to be implemented between subsystems that need to interact with each other, be it battery and vehicle, battery and charger, battery and hand-held device or apps and server.

The purpose of the standard is to promote interoperability between energy operators, vehicles, batteries and chargers.

This would make it agnostic to the make & model of these subsystems for an operator to procure the components. It would also be a great benefit for users to acquire or exchange the batteries and gain from the lower capital expenditure and operating expenditure and be flexible on the location of the operator across the intended area of travel.

“Using Esmito’s platform at C-BEEV in IIT-Madras and several other locations, we have done several three-wheeler and two-wheeler pilots using the standard swapping platform. Esmito is now offering this solution as a SaaS platform for energy/fleet operators,” Kaur said.

For example, the standards will involve vehicle identification number (VIN) and battery identification number (BIN) in specified formats that will help identify where the parts were produced, including if the batteries are lead acid, lithium ion or cobalt-based batteries, among others.

“We need to still have standards on batteries, chargers, in all different segments and BIS is working on these,” she said.

India has the potential to become one of the largest EV markets in the world, with the government pushing for the segment in order to curb pollution and reduce reliance on import-dependent fossil fuel, says a World Economic Forum report.

The uptake of EVs has been slow in the country due to the high upfront as well as life cycle costs. But long-term investment in research and development (R&D) will create sustained growth.

A step towards cheaper EVs is to sell the vehicles without batteries and allow the user to swap drained batteries with fully charged ones at dedicated charging stations.

For example, if a conventional EV costs Rs 14 lakh, one without battery will cost only Rs 6.5 lakh and the user can drive into a charging station and swap the batteries in the time it takes to refuel a fossil fuel vehicle.

Title: Maharashtra govt to spend Rs 28 crore to revamp 28 mantri bungalows
Content:
Uddhav Thackeray

Officials say not all state bungalows need repairs, but netas keen on revamp

MUMBAI: The Maha Vikas Aghadi government has earmarked Rs 28 crore for repairs and renovation of 28 bungalows allotted to ministers . Work has started on most of the bungalows and in some cases is almost complete. Each of four of the top five bungalows on the list (in order of expense) had, according to a 2016 CAG report , incurred a maintenance charge of over Rs 2.5 crore during 2010-15.Royal Stone in Malabar Hill, allotted to revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat, will incur the highest expenditure, Rs 2.3 crore. The amount has been distributed over two tenders—Rs 1.8 crore for renovation of the main bungalow, and Rs 44 lakh for guest room extension and renovation.The second highest expenditure, Rs 1.5 crore, is being incurred on the renovation of deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar’s Deogiri bungalow, which like many of the bungalows on the list is at or near Malabar Hill. Pawar occupied Deogiri for 15 years during the three successive Congress-NCP governments from 1999 to 2014. The bungalow’s renovation plan includes plastering, terrace waterproofing, fixing of new doors and windows, new flooring, toilet block repairs, and new furniture. On the third to fifth spots are the Ramtek, Satpuda and Jetwan bungalows.Though down on the expenditure list, two bungalows are prominent for their occupants: Sagar bungalow, allotted to leader of the opposition in the state assembly Devendra Fadnavis, which is being renovated for Rs 92.7 lakh, and the relatively modest bungalow A-6, allotted to tourism and environment minister Aaditya Thackeray, on which the government is spending Rs 74 lakh.The work is being carried out under the public works department (PWD), which maintains government buildings.Senior government officials say some of the bungalows indeed need renovation as they are either sea-facing heritage buildings prone to corrosion or are old-style wooden structures prone to leakage, but the others don’t need any major work to merit a high expenditure. “Repair and renovation in some cases is just unnecessary,” said an official. “Some ministers follow Vastu seriously and ask to change the direction of their office or kitchen or bedroom. Some ministers don’t like furniture placed by their bungalows’ previous occupants and put in demands for changing them.”Extensive changes are not only being carried out at ministers’ bungalows, but also their offices in Mantralaya. A 2016 report by the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) had flagged off “huge and unnecessary expenses” incurred by the state on renovation and maintenance of government bungalows. The CAG report said that during 2010-15, Rs 52 crore had been spent on ministers’ bungalows. The distribution for each was six to 20 times above prescribed norms, the report said, adding that in some cases, new bungalows could have been constructed for less than the renovation amounts. During the period under CAG’s consideration, the highest “maintenance and repair” expenditure was incurred on Puratan (Rs 3.5 crore), followed by Meghdoot (Rs 3.3 crore), Parnakuty (Rs 3.2 crore), Satpuda (Rs 3 crore), Sewasadan (Rs 3.1 crore), Chitrakut (Rs 2.5 crore), Ramtek (Rs 2.7 crore), Jetwan (Rs 2.77 crore) and Deogiri (Rs 2.5 crore).“The government is amidst a financial crisis, and yet they are making such wasteful expenditure. It is time ministers treated official bungalows as government accommodation and not holiday homes,” said Anjali Patil, an Aurangabad activist who works for the welfare of farm widows.A civil contractor who works with PWD said, “In many cases, tiles that were in a good condition were replaced and even doors that were fine were replaced.”Though low on the expenditure list, two bungalows are prominent for their occupants: Sagar bungalow, allotted to leader of the opposition in the state assembly Devendra Fadnavis, which is being renovated for Rs 92.7 lakh, and the relatively modest bungalow A-6, allotted to tourism and environment minister Aaditya Thackeray, on which the government is spending Rs 74 lakh. The work is being carried out under the public works department (PWD), which maintains government buildings.

Title: Exports positive despite slowdown in Motown
Content: Chennai: As the auto industry battles its worst slowdown in 20 years, one segment has continued to remain positive — exports, which has risen 5% in the first nine months of the fiscal, as companies push exports in an attempt to use up idle production capacity.“Domestic sales are slow, so efforts are being made to try and increase exports and those efforts are showing up. India is a largely small car market and these vehicles find a market in emerging countries in Africa and Latin America for example,” said R C Bhargava, chairman, Maruti Suzuki That Africa-and-Latin America focus is true for both car as well two wheeler shipments. Take Nissan for e.g. which has been focusing on newer markets to grow its exports. “In the case of Nissan we have been able to explore newer opportunities in markets like South Africa for our exports. Exports have been doing well because of newer markets for existing products as well as a better and newer product pipeline. Globally some markets in Africa, Middle East and South East Asia are doing very well and we have been able to capitalize on such opportunities specially with our GO and GO + and Sunny models,” said Rakesh Srivastava , MD, Nissan Motor India.Same is true for Hero Motocorp which has been pushing its presence in Latin America. “The bulk of the growth in two-wheeler exports over the past 10 months has come from the Africa market. Some of the key markets in Latin America have also seen growth during the same period. We expect the trend to continue for the rest of the months in this fiscal,” said Rajat Bhargava , head of global business at Hero MotoCorp. Consultants say the export game not only uses up capacity but also offers companies some margin comfort in a lean year. “When domestic sales are down, exports is a better margin business on the balance sheet. So not only do exports reduce idle capacity they also help the profit and loss statement,” said Som Kapoor, partner-automotive, E&Y.
