Cold, dry northerly winds may begin to enter north Madhya Maharashtra, including Pune district, and Konkan (partially) from Friday. Minimum temperatures will be down till Monday, Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI.Night temperatures in Pune may fall by 3-4 degrees celsius till February 17 and may start rising after that in line with the recent forecasts indicating early arrival of summer in parts of the state and the country, India Meteorological Department (IMD) officials said.“Till February 16, minimums would be more or less the same as they would be on February 14-15, while they would begin an upward climb from February 17 gradually,” Kashyapi said.The IMD weather models show Pune’s night temperature will dip to 12 degrees celsius to 13 degrees celsius on February 14 and 15 in Shivajinagar and Pashan.“After February 20, we will see minimal chances of a minimum temperature fall in Pune. The latest extended range forecast points to chances of above normal night temperatures during February-end and beginning of March in Madhya Maharashtra and Pune,” he added.The temperature drop from Friday would be a result of cold winds penetrating the lower atmospheric level in the absence of an anticyclone prevailing further up north.An anticyclone stationed over north Maharashtra or further north usually blocks northerly winds from entering the state. But as there would not be any such anti-cyclone over our region (especially over north Madhya Maharashtra), northerly winds would begin to enter once again in north Maharashtra.

Title: ISL: Yellow cards can derail FC Goa
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Panaji: When Brandon Fernandes picked up a booking against Mumbai City FC, his seventh yellow card of the season, there was a collective disbelief among FC Goa officials, both on and off the field.

When Seriton Fernandes got booked late in the game, he couldn’t believe what he did. That’s why he pleaded with German referee Dingert Christian and could have made it worse by grabbing his hand, twice. Seriton knows how important it was for him to stay card-free for the last two league games. But his booking, with eight minutes left, means he will now miss the crucial and possibly decisive battle against Jamshedpur FC next week.

Brandon has already missed one game due to suspension. He was out of action against ATK, a match Goa missed him terribly on the wings in Kolkata last month. With seven bookings, he will now miss the Jamshedpur clash, giving technical director Derrick Pereira and interim coach Clifford Miranda plenty to think about.

This is not the time for experimentation so Brandon’s replacement will be a straight-forward one. Seiminlen Doungel will step into his boots, although it remains to be seen whether he can bring the same creativity.

Stepping into the boots of Seriton will be a bigger headache. The right-back has played every game of FC Goa’s campaign in the Indian Super League ( ISL ) this season and to suddenly have a new player – almost certainly Amey Ranawade – fill that void could be a tough ask. Amey has been on the field for just five minutes this season.

Now that Goa have sealed a place in the play-offs, there could be more trouble for them at the most crucial stage. Two of their players – Hugo Boumous and Lenny Rodrigues – are on three bookings and will miss the first leg semifinal if they get into the referee’s book against Jamshedpur.

According to Article 4.8 of the ISL Regulations. “suspension resulting from accumulation of cautions in League matches shall carry over to the respective player’s first playoff match with the effect that the player shall be suspended from playing in such first playoff match.”

All players who have three bookings, or one yellow card away from suspension, at the end of he league stage will start afresh in the playoffs.

For playoff matches, a player who received two cautions in two different matches will automatically be suspended from participating in the final.

Title: Panel finds irregularities in fee collected at pvt schools
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission (APSERMC) conducted surprise inspections at 130 schools across the state on Thursday.

The commission paid special attention to schools collecting exorbitant fees, with the body focusing on regulating fees collected.

The state government, which is focusing on streamlining school education, had brought in major reforms in government schools. On the other hand, APSERMC, headed by Justice Kantha Rao, has been focusing on streamlining private schools which are looting parents in the name of being international schools, having a ‘techno curriculum’ and providing their children education which they deem is of international standard.

Several teams, led by district level officials of the education department, conducted inspections in 10 schools in each district on Thursday. While district education officers led these teams and inspected the amenities provided by the private schools, APSERMC members acted as observers during the inspection process.

The schools that were inspected offered CBSE and State syllabi. Officials inspected records and accounts related to fees collected by the school management. They cross-checked the actual fees collected by the schools and found that the schools were giving receipts for a lesser fee than the amount that was collected from the parents.

The APSERMC also observed that most of the schools which claimed to be ‘international schools’ were running their campuses at apartment buildings which were meant for residential purpose. The committee also observed that some schools had poor ventilation, unhygienic toilets, employed improper teaching methods that often induced stress in students.

APSERMC vice-chairperson Vijaya Sharada Reddy was also present during the inspection of some schools in Krishna and Guntur districts and interacted with students.

The committee also found that while the schools were collecting fees exorbitant fees from students, they didn’t provide infrastructure and amenities to the students.

The committee is also considering introducing a grading system for schools from the coming academic year to regulate fees collected by corporate schools.

Title: Ahmedabad caught in Donald Trump fever, CM caught in quota mess
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Deputy CM Nitin Patel held separate meetings with representatives of both sides and both continued to hold on ... Read More

GANDHINAGAR: Even as the Gujarat government is racing against time to complete preparations for the forthcoming high profile visit of US President Donald Trump , it has been caught in a bind over the contentious issue of reservation.

Members of both reserved and unreserved communities are protesting over a government resolution that bars reserved category women from applying for the general category seats in government recruitment examinations.

While women of reserved categories have been protesting against the resolution for over two months, demanding that it be scrapped, members of unreserved communities began protesting from Wednesday after the government announced that it will modify the circular to ensure nobody faces injustice in recruitment.

Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel held separate meetings with representatives of both sides and both continued to hold on to their tough stance. Nitin Patel however, was optimistic that a solution acceptable to both sides could be arrived at. “The CM had directed me and Pradipsinh Jadeja to meet the groups and listen to their demands. We have met different groups of non-reserve caste today and heard their representation over the GR dated August 1, 2018. We will brief the CM on Friday. Government will find a solution which is acceptable to both sides,” Patel said.

The bone of contention is a government resolution passed by Vijay Rupani-led government on August 1, 2018, that barred reserved category women from applying in the general category seats. Trouble started about two months ago, when the government announced results of the Lok Rakshak Dal (LRD) exams and applied the GR in the recruitment process.

Dinesh Bambhania, Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS) leader, who led the delegation of the non-reserved caste delegation, said, “We have categorically told the government that if any change is made in the August 1, 2018 GR, we will further intensify our protest. We are not against any community, but we expect the government to follow directions of the Supreme Court.”

Hasmukh Saxsena, Bandharaniya Adhikar Andolan Samiti (BAAS) which is supporting the protest of SC/ST/OBC women LRD aspirants, said “We feel that attempts are being made to create a rift in society by provoking women from non-reserved category to protest. The GR is not only damaging for the prospects of SC/ST/OBC women but also those from economically weaker sections. The protest will continue until the GR is not withdrawn.”

Title: Building norm violators snub notice, corp gears up for action
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The town planning committee, which convened the meeting of city corporation’s special squad here on Thursday following detection of parking norms violations, producing of fake building numbers and tax evasion by many commercial buildings in the city, noted that only 10 owners have so far responded to the notice issued by the corporation in this regard.

As many as 32 establishments were inspected and served notices in January.

Almost a month after the notices were served, no response has been reported from 22 establishments. Some of them have communicated that their owners are abroad and that they are not in a position to furnish the original building plan and conditions agreed by them at the time of allocation of building permit and issuance of occupancy certificate.

The committee has now decided to affix notices on these buildings in a visible manner citing that non cooperation from their part and no submission of explanation in response to the notice would lead to cancellation of the building numbers.

The town planning committee has collected details of all the buildings which were inspected from tax assessment registers.

The total area, plinth area, commercial space, number of floors and tax being paid were collected.

The compilation process revealed that some of the building numbers produced by the owners were not recorded in tax assessment register proving that such numbers were fabricated and the building was altered rendering it unauthorized.

The officials said that there were cases in which number was obtained for a small commercial space and a larger area was then used for commercial purpose, without ensuring mandatory parking space and by evading tax.

It was also found that a building which functioned as a hotel in Kuravankonam paid an annual tax of just Rs 46. The revenue wing will take over such cases of tax evasion and penalty will be levied from such buildings quoting relevant sections of Kerala Municipality Act.

The special squad is working on assessing the commercial area of each building based on details garnered from the tax assessment register.

The mandatory parking space for respective commercial area will be calculated and if this area is found inadequate in the buildings for which notices have been served, action will be taken, which will amount to cancellation of building numbers and hefty fines as applicable to unauthorised constructions.

Palayam Rajan, chairman, town planning committee, said that the special squad will do another round of inspection and compile a final report by the end of this month.

The special squad has been constituted comprising executive engineer of central zone, three assistant engineers, assistant revenue officer, two revenue inspectors and bill collectors of the wards where inspection was done.

Title: 3 B’deshis held for illegal stay in city
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Indore: Three Bangladeshi nationals, including two women, were arrested on Thursday for allegedly staying in the country illegally using fake documents.

The accused who were operating a sex racket in city for the past few years were also booked for their alleged involvement in fabricating documents, counterfeiting currency, prostitution and kidnapping.

The case had come to light when four persons including Begum Khatoon alias Megha, Lima Haldar and Roni Shaikh, along with Kishore Khandare were arrested on February 8 for allegedly kidnapping a person and demanding a ransom of Rs 2 lakh, said DIG Ruchi Vardhan Mishra

On February 5, the accused had abducted a local Anil Pal to extort money from him and had held him captive in Dutt Nagar. Acting on a tip off, the police rescued Anil and four persons including Kishore Khandare, Megha Khandare, Roni Sheikh and Lima Haldar were arrested.

During questioning, it was found that Roni and Lima are residents of Bagerhat district of Bangladesh. They had illegally entered the country and Kishore and Megha brought them to Indore for flesh trade.

DIG Ruchi Mishra said that Megha was also a Bangladeshi resident and had come to Mumbai illegally ten years ago in search of work. Here, she stayed in Washim area for three years. During this time, she returned to Bangladesh and got a passport made using fake identity and name -- Begum Khatun Sheikh. She got a visa on this passport and came back to the country in 2017 following which they shifted to Indore and started a sex racket. After the visa expired, the woman used the name Megha Khandare and got an Indian passport made using fake Aadhaar card which she got from Mumbai. She got a fake marksheet made through one Shiv Yadav for Rs 8,000.

Shivkumar Yadav and Ashok Agarwal and Babulal Gaud who helped in making the fake marksheet were also arrested by police. Ashok accepted that he has made over a hundred fake marksheets in the past.

It also came to fore that in 2018 when Kishore Khandare lived in Vishwas Nagar, he had started a fake currency racket and used to make photocopies of currency and distributed them in Mhow and Pithampur.

Title: Couples choose innovative activities to celebrate V-Day
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

melodious surprise: Nandita Kulkarni records ‘Aaiyein Meherbaan’ in a professional studio to surprise her husb... Read More

Pune: Conventional expression of love has taken a back seat for many Puneites this Valentine’s season with them opting for helicopter rides, camping and other out-of-the-box experiences to replace the usual trend of presenting dear ones with bouquets and gifts.

In an unconventional twist, almost 70 couples have booked a special helicopter ride with Vighnahar Aviation on the occasion of Valentine’s Day. “The 8-10 minute ride will offer couples an aerial view of the scenic Pashan Lake, Oxford Golf Course, Pune-Mumbai Expressway and Balewadi stadium. We will provide them with refreshments during the ride,” the owner of Vighnahar Aviation, Saurabh Pol, said.

“Almost 75% of the bookings are surprises. Many people have also asked us to make special arrangements as they plan to propose their partners during or after the helicopter ride,” Pol added.

Pune-based working professional Mona Agarwal has opted for the helicopter ride to surprise her partner Akshay Singhal. She said, “I have asked the company to arrange for a cake as I plan to propose him during the ride. The cake will carry the question ‘Will you marry me?’ and will be accompanied by a small gift.”

To serve lyrical justice to their love, Pune resident Nandita Kulkarni is set to surprise her husband with a special song. “I recorded the song ‘Aaiyein Meherbaan’ from Howrah Bridge in a professional studio with a sound engineer’s assistance,” she said.

Kulkarni opted for the recording on www.wishfunda.com, which has many other unique experiences in store for couples this Valentine’s Day.

“Cooking together under expert guidance, gifting one’s partner a makeover with a celebrity stylist, a mead tasting or sound healing session, and painting together, are some of the other experiences that we are offering,” said an employee working with the website.

Many couples have chosen to ditch the routine parties to spend their V-Day evening under a blanket of stars in the heart of nature.

Mehek Desai, from ‘Into the Wild Camp’ at Bhimashankar, said, “We are offering a special couple’s package, which includes meals, couple games and live music at a campsite themed on Valentine’s Day. We have registered 10 to 12 bookings till Thursday afternoon.”

According to Desai, people are looking to spend quality time with their partners.

“People want a relaxed evening with their partners rather than spending it in clubs,” she explained.

Title: Muzaffarnagar: Union minister Sanjeev Balyan appears before court
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: Union minister Sanjeev Balyan appeared before a court in connection with Muzaffarnagar riots case amid heavy security on Thursday. Balyan is accused of inciting people during the infamous Nangla-Mandaur Mahapanchayat held in 2013.

Soon after the Mahapanchayat, riots erupted in Muzaffarnagar leading to the death of 60 people and displacement of more than 50,000 villagers. The case is being heard in additional district judge’s (ADJ) court. Balyan is BJP MP from Muzaffarnagar. The court has now fixed April 3 for the appearance of the other accused in the case involving BJP leaders, including UP minister Suresh Rana.

As many as 14 people, including former BJP MP Bhartendu Singh, VHP’s Sadhvi Prachi and BJP MLA Sangeet Som were booked for hate speech.

Defense lawyer Gorav Chaudhry said, “Sanjeev Balyan and three other accused appeared before the court. It has now fixed April 3 as next date of hearing.”

After the hearing, Balyan said, “It was a false case which is now taking a lot of time. I was booked for addressing a panchayat. But, the truth is different. It was a rainy day, no public address system was present at the panchayat and no one had delivered any speech at the panchayat. I was arrested the next day and sent to jail.”

Title: Uttarakhand: Drunken man shoots at boy after being hit by a cricket ball
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: In a bizarre incident, a drunken man allegedly shot at an 11-year-old boy with his gun after he was hit by a cricket ball at Bheti village in Balganga tehsil of Tehri district on Thursday.

Police said that children of the village were playing cricket when the two men, identified as Ramlal and Bijendra Kandari, were hit by the ball while they were sitting outside Ramlal’s house.

Angry over being hit by the ball, Ramlal picked up Kandari’s gun and fired at the boy, identified as Mahesh, as he went near the two accused to pick the ball.

He was immediately taken to a nearby community health centre (CHC) from where he was referred to AIIMS Rishikesh for treatment.

“Both Ramlal and Kandari were under the influence of alcohol. The revenue police immediately arrested Ramlal and Kandari, too, was later arrested,” said Pradeep Singh Rawat, in-charge of Ghansali police station.

The revenue police have also seized the weapon used in the crime and have started investigating the matter.

Title: Novel coronavirus threat: Three test negative in Gujarat
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: On Thursday, the specially set up lab for detection of novel Coronavirus (NCoV) at Civil Hospital analyzed three samples from Ahmedabad, Kheda and Vadodara. All three samples were negative, mentioned state health department officials. In total, 23 samples have been tested by National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune and at Civil Hospital and all have been termed negative.“The screening at state airports have been strengthened and all the passengers, having any history of visiting China or nearby countries having history of nCoV are identified and advised quarantine. .

Title: Pune: Body of toddler recovered from Mutha river
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Fire brigade personnel undertake a search operation in a nullah in Dattawadi on Thursday

PUNE: The body of a two-year-old boy was recovered by firemen from the Mutha river near the Mhatre bridge on Thursday, a day after he fell into a nullah at Dattawadi while playing near his house, police said.

Sanksar Suryakant Sable of Mhasobanagar in Dattawadi was washed away by the gushing waters after he fell into the nullah around 5.30pm on Wednesday.

Some local people noticed the child being swept away and alerted his parents. The nullah flows into the Mutha river.

After receiving the information, a team from the Pune fire brigade reached the spot and carried out searches in the nullah. The fire brigade had to abandon the search operation on Wednesday night as it was pitch dark.

Rajesh Jagtap, fire officer, Pune fire brigade, told TOI that about 35 firemen and four officers began searching the boy from 7am on Thursday. “Garbage had piled up in the nullah. Three branches of a tree were in the water. We had to use an earthmoving machine to clear the garbage,” Jagtap said.

He said that the firemen checked every nook and corner of the nullah. “We even checked all the gaps in the wall of the nullah, suspecting that the boy may have got stuck in one of the gaps,” Jagtap said.

“Our teams went into the river and carried out searches. Around 2.30pm, we found the body in the river near the Mhatre bridge,” Jagtap said.

Jagtap said that the water level of the nullah increases in the evening after excess water is released into it from a water purification plant at Parvati.

The Dattawadi police said that the boy’s family hails from Beed district. His parents had recently shifted to Pune in search of work. “We have registered a case of accidental death,” said an officer from the Dattawadi police.

Title: Ministers, greens to take part in 2nd phase of Killiyar cleaning drive
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Over 30,000 people will participate in a massive cleaning drive at Killiyar on Friday. Organized by Killiyar Mission Samithi, the second phase of the cleaning drive ‘Karakaviyathe Killiyar’ for rejuvenation of the river will begin at 7.30am and will go on till afternoon.

In addition to the 22-km long stretch of Killiyar from Karinjathimoola to Vazhayila bridge, 31 streams flowing into the river will be cleaned. Hence, the total area to be cleaned as part of the drive is around 500km.

Ministers, MLAs, other people’s representatives, employment guarantee scheme workers, Kudumbashree workers and students will participate in the drive.The first phase of Killiyar cleaning drive was held in April 2018.

“After first phase, the committee conducted a series of follow-up activities, including closing down of 1,200-odd waste pipeline connected to the river and cleared encroachment in 6.2acres. These activities improved the quality of the water. We expect more people to join the drive,” said MLA D K Murali.

Minister for water resources K Krishnankutty will be present at Karinjathimoola, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac at Kallampara in Nedumangad, tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran at Vazhayila in Karakulam panchayat, agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar at Moozhi in Anad panchayat, forest minister K Raju in Azhikode Aruvikkara panchayat, DGP Loknath Behera at Kuttappara in Karakulam and district collector Gopalakrishnan will be present at Pazhakutty.

The district committee of CPM has urged party members to volunteer for the cleaning drive. “The large-scale participation of people in the cleaning and anti-encroachment campaigns so far is a major factor behind the success of Killiyar mission. We need to continue giving that support,” CPM district secretary Anavoor Nagappan said in a statement.

The representatives of the Killiyar Mission committee have planned to complete the survey to demarcate the encroachments on the river. In the next stage, they will take steps to clear these encroachments.

Title: Priest charged Rs 13k for Bhasamaarti, say NRIs
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ujjain: Five NRIs from Netherlands have lodged a complaint with Mahakal temple committee alleging that a priest fraudulently took Rs 13,000 from them to procure permission to attend Bhasmaarti ritual at the temple.

The complainants claimed that they became suspicious when they were not allowed to go close to Shivalinga, despite being told that the money was taken by Shri Mahakaleshwar Temple Committee to grant them permission to attend Bhasmaarti and perform special rituals.

NRI Krishna Sharma told the temple assistant administrator and tehsildar Mulchand Junwal that Rs 10,000 was taken for the Bhasmarti permission and Rs 3000 for special Pooja. “The NRIs claimed that the money was taken by priest Gopal Vyas through his son, who reached an Indore hotel to collect it from the complainants,” Junwal said.

The NRIs grew suspicious when they were not granted close access to Shivlinga and approached the temple office, only to find that no fee is charged for Bhasmarti permission. In an initial probe conducted by temple authorities, it was found that the letterhead of the accused priest – who is registered with the temple committee – was used to secure permission for the NRIs.

“We have suspended the priest and a letter has been written to Mahakal police station for lodging a formal FIR against the accused,” Junwal said. Additional SP Rupesh Dwivedi said the police was yet to receive the letter from temple committee. “Appropriate action will be taken once the complaint is received,” he said. Priest Vyas remained incommunicado after the matter came to fore.

Title: Swine flu: Four more people test positive, cases mount to 27
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Swine flu

MEERUT: With four more persons testing positive for swine flu, the number of patients suffering from the disease shot up to 27 on Thursday. This comes a day after the disease claimed its third victim. Swine flu raised its head in the district in January end, and ever since, the cases have been on a rise.

The doctors have advised that the locals should maintain hygiene and clean their hands to keep infection away.

“As many as four new cases of swine flu were reported in Meerut on Thursday. The new cases include 62-year-old man from Sardhana, 50-year-old man from Shastri Nagar, 32-year-old woman from Adarsh Nagar and 46-year-old man from Incholi,” said Dr Rachna Tandon, Meerut district epidemiologist.

Doctors have advised that only one member of the family should engage in taking care of a swine flu patient to prevent everyone from getting infected. One should wash hands frequently, wear a mask when in the vicinity of the patient, take care of cleanliness inside the patient’s room and use separate utensils for the patient, doctors said.

Children below five years of age, the elderly, especially above 65 years old, pregnant women and people with prolonged respiratory disease fall in the high-risk group patients and should exercise more caution.

“Private hospitals have been asked to set up isolation wards for patients of swine flu to ensure that other patients or hospital staff are not infected,” said Dr Raj Kumar, Meerut chief medical officer.

In areas where swine flu cases have been detected, surveillance is being conducted to check if there are more cases in proximity. Awareness camps are also being organized there so that people in those areas are aware about it. Also, epidemiological study and travel history of patients is being checked, the health department authorities said.

Title: Pune: Science graduate arrested for fraudulent withdrawal of Rs 1.4 lakh from ATMs
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An unemployed science graduate from Allahabad was arrested last week for using his and his relatives’ ATM cards for withdrawing Rs1.4 lakh through 14 transactions. But, the withdrawn amount was not debited from the accounts because of his “pin trick”.A team of the cybercrime police zeroed in on Satyavruta Kaushalprasad Dwivedi (23) on Friday in Allahabad. He made cash withdrawals of Rs10,000 each from 14 ATMs of different banks before he ran out of luck.Dwivedi would put a safety pin in the cash dispenser of the ATM at the time of collecting cash, resulting in an “incomplete transaction” signal going to the bank. The bank would then revert the “incomplete transaction” amount to the account holder despite Dwivedi collecting the cash from the ATM.Senior inspector Rajkumar Wakchaure of the Cybercrime police station said Dwivedi would travel to the city and stay in hotels. He targeted ATMs in Baner, Sangvi, Shivajinagar, Pimpri and Chinchwad over the past few days.The officials of a bank spotted Dwivedi lingering in an ATM kiosk in Baner for a long time. The CCTV footage of the ATM showed him buying time inside the kiosk and the bank concerned receiving an “incomplete transaction” signal at the same time.The officials reported the incident to the Cybercrime police station. The police then studied the CCTV footage and tracked down the details of the bank accounts, leading to the arrest of Dwivedi.Wakchaure said Dwivedi was a graduate and had a good friends’ circle in Allahabad. “His friends would insert a small pin before the flap of the cash dispensing tray of the ATM unit before it completely shut down. This would send a signal to the bank concerned that the transaction was not completed, and the amount withdrawn would be reverted to the account holder.”Dwivedi used the same trick to withdraw cash from some ATMs in Allahabad first. Then he decided to replicate the act in other places.“Dwivedi always withdrew Rs10,000, which a normal person withdraws from an ATM unit,” Wakchaure said.

Title: ‘Smitten’ by Kashmiri red roses, Gujarati farmers shun the ‘desi’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A farmer from Karjan in his farm of rose plants

Vadodara: Talk about love and the first image that floats in your mind is that of a vibrant red velvety rose. While the flower been synonymous with Valentine’s Day, the Gujarati farmers seem particularly smitten by a sweet smelling variety that comes from the Kashmir Valley. Hundreds of farmers in and around Vadodara have been seen growing this special breed of Kashmiri roses for the past few years.

The roses have not just reduced farmers’ hard labour but also helped them double their income.

“I used to plant ‘desi’ rose varieties for years. But a few years ago, I learnt about the Kashmiri roses that last longer and also fetch almost double the price. So I began growing these roses,” said Vishal Patel, a farmer from Bil village in Padra.

“Over the last five years, my income has gone up considerably. I now sow only Kashmiri roses round the year. Many farmers in my village have also started planting Kashmiri roses after they saw the benefits,” Patel said, adding that he ships his roses to Mumbai and Bengaluru where these are in great demand.

Kashmiri roses are grown mainly in the villages of Karjan taluka including Deroli, Ranapur, Kothiya, Nanikoral and Motikoral.

“Life of a local variety of rose is just 10 to 12 hours but the Kashmiri roses last for two to three days. Also, the growers get almost double the price by selling the Kashmiri roses that require no additional cost,” said Yogesh Patel, horticulture officer, Vadodara.

Local farmers also say that plucking Kashmiri roses is also far easier.

“Desi roses have to be plucked in the night and transported immediately to the markets before dawn. Kashmiri roses can be plucked in the daytime and sent to the markets even on the next day. Unlike the thorny stems of local rose, Kashmiri rose plants are not thorny which makes it easier for plucking,” Patel added.

Title: Burglars escape with SUV, jewellery
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The house at Gutkal village which was burgled

Vadodara: A gang of burglars broke into the house of a farmer at Gutal village in Waghodia taluka in the wee hours of Thursday and escaped his SUV, ornaments worth Rs 1.3 lakh and Rs 25,000 cash.

According to the farmer Mayurdas Sadhu, four burglars entered the house by breaking the lock on the kitchen door. When Sadhu heard the noise in the kitchen he went there, but the thieves hit a wooden stick on his head due to which he became unconscious. Hearing the commotion, Sadhu’s mother Meena, wife Komal and sister-in-law Neetu rushed to the kitchen. But the burglars threatened them and kept them under confinement in one room.

According to police, burglars took away the ornaments which the three ladies were wearing and also some from the safe along with cash. Thieves also took bank documents away with them. As the thieves exited Sadhu’s house Meena shouted for help. But the burglars fled away in Sadhu’s SUV.

Police said that Sadhu had brought the jewellery on Wednesday from another home in Manjalpur as the family went to attend a wedding on Thursday.

Although the burglars used wooden sticks and kept the family members under confinement while committing dacoity, police have registered the offence of burglary.

Title: Peeved over police ‘inaction’, 17-year-old rape survivor ‘kills self’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: A 17-year-old rape survivor , a resident of Mawana, allegedly committed suicide on Wednesday. Family of the deceased claimed that she was peeved over “police inaction” in her rape case where the 65-year-old accused is still at large. Though the deceased didn’t leave behind any suicide note, her family stated that their daughter was “receiving repeated threats to settle the case and was very upset”.

Now, Meerut SSP Ajay Sahni has shunted the local SHO to police lines for “dereliction of duty”. But, according to police, the family of the rape survivor initially made conflicting claims. Medical report also didn’t corroborate claims of rape, they said.

Father of the rape survivor said, “The police didn’t take any action against the accused and has instead been harassing us with questions. Earlier, the police didn’t care to probe the rape case and has now been reaching out to us after my daughter committed suicide. My daughter had dropped out of school over threats from the accused who is still absconding.”

The heinous crime took place on January 19, this year, when the 65-year-old accused, Brahmapal, allegedly raped the minor girl at gunpoint when his father, a daily-wage labourer, was out for work.

Family also claimed that the accused was threatening to settle the case and all this while local cops looked the other way. However, SSP Sahni said, “Rape was not corroborated in the medical report. Investigation in the case is pending. It was also brought to our notice that three written complaints with different versions of the crime were given to local police on the day FIR of the rape case was registered. Prima facie, a case of rape has been registered to settle scores in an ongoing village election rivalry.”

On Thursday, family and other locals staged protests after police handed over the body of the deceased following a postmortem. The family was demanding the arrest of the accused and monetary compensation. It was only after the intervention of senior police officials that the aggrieved family and locals could be pacified and the body was taken for cremation.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Reboot Kerala hackathon from today
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

T’puram: The first hackathon conducted as part of Reboot Kerala hackathon organized by higher education council and Additional Skill Acquisition Program (ASAP) will begin at LBS Institute of Technology here on Friday.

Students will have to find solutions to problems faced by government departments in the hackathon, which will last for around 36hrs. Higher education minister K T Jaleel said that selected tech solutions will be implemented in government departments after the event.

“Students will develop problem solving skills and new ideas through hackathons,” the minister said. The minister said that top IT companies will attend the event to hire talent.

Reboot Kerala will consist of 10 local-level hackathons and a grand finale. Student participants will be given various problem faced by 14 government departments. The local-level hackathons will be held from February 14 to March 15 in ten districts. Thirty teams will participate in each local hackathon. A team of judges, comprising technical experts, department representatives and social engineers, will select the winners. The first three winners will get Rs 50,000, Rs 30,000 and Rs 20,000, respectively. The grand finale will be held from March 27 to March 29 in the capital.

The first hackathon at LBS institute will conclude on Sunday. The second and third hackathons will be held from February 21 to 23 at AKNM Government Polytechnic College, Malappuram, and M Dasan Institute Of Technology, Kozhikode. The fourth and fifth will be held from February 28 to March 1 at Naipunnya School of Management, Cherthala in Alappuzha; Holy Grace Academy, Mala, Thrissur and Jawaharlal College of Engineering and Technology, Lakkidi, Palakkad.

The seventh and eight hackathon, to be held form March 6 to 8, will be held at FISAT Angamali in Ernakulam and Government Polytechnic College, Periya, Kasargode. Government Engineering College, Thrissur and College of Engineering, Idukki, will host the ninth and tenth hackathon from March 13 to 15.

Title: Criminal in cop net for 2 burglaries, 5 bike thefts
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: A 40-year-old criminal on police records was arrested on Wednesday for his alleged involvement in two burglary and five motorcycle theft cases.

The Chakan police recovered five motorcycles and two television sets, collectively worth Rs2 lakh, from suspect Ashok Sonawane of Parner taluka in Ahmednagar district.

A police team led by inspector Kalyan Pawar of the Chakan police took the Sonawane into custody from Parner. The team comprised assistant inspector Vikram Gaikwad and, constables Suresh Hinge, Virsen Gaikwad and Sanjay Jare.

During questioning Sonawane admitted to the charges against him and told the police that he used to operate in Chakan and Shikrapur.

An officer from the Chakan police said they have traced the owners of four motorcycles. “We are yet to find the owner of the fifth motorcycle,” the officer said. Sonawane has been arrested under sections 457 (house-breaking by night) and 380 (theft) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: Raj men offer to do chores to commit theft, held
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Indore: Kanadia police have busted a gang of thieves, who committed thefts in different areas in the garb of offering to do household chores. Stolen valuables worth Rs 20 lakh were seized from their possession.

On February 16, a man had approached Kanadia police complaining that he had left his house around 2pm and when he returned, he found that the lock of the bedroom almirah was broken and Rs 1.6 lakh cash along with diamond and gold jewellery was missing.

A case was registered. During investigation, police learnt that three persons had reached his home in search of work two days ago. But he had sent them away. They had a Rajasthani touch to their tone. Meanwhile, Officials received a tip off that some youths, who resembled the appearance described by the complainant, were standing near Bhuri Tekri. Subsequently, a team was sent to the area and the accused was arrested .

During questioning, they admitted having committed the crime. One of the accused Chhaganlal told police that he hid the stolen items at his brother-in-law Kantilal’s place. Both the accused were booked under relevant sections of the IPC.

Title: AU faculty bound over for good conduct
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Two professors at Andhra University were ‘ bound over’ for good conduct at the office of a local tahsildar who holds the charge of mandal executive magistrate.

Police had registered cases against Ragala Swamy Das, head, Social Work department, and Kondamudi Ramesh Babu, associate professor, Department of Marine Living Resources, for allegedly misbehaving with girl students under section 41/109 CrPC. The police have also registered a case under Section 498 A of IPC against Ramesh Babu based on a complaint by his wife.

Recently, a chemistry department faculty was arrested under Disha Act after he allegedly misbehaved with a woman government employee during a bus journey.

Deputy commissioner of police (law and order-I) G Ranga Reddy said Ramesh Babu’s wife complained that he is having a relationship with a scholar in AU.

Das was taken into custody based on news reports. According to the police, the professor misbehaved with students and used innuendoes at girls.

The DCP said if any student came forward to report about the misconduct of the faculty, the police would take action and protect the complainant's identity.

Title: PMC to seek data of rented properties from cops
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: The civic body will seek data of rented residential properties from the city police, based on which tax discounts to such units would be discontinued.

The property tax department of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) said there were about 9 lakh residential properties in the city, many of which were rented out by the owners.

“These units are not eligible for the 40% discount in property tax. The administration has already initiated steps to discontinue the discount for such properties,” a senior PMC official said.

“We will now seek data from the Pune police to identify more properties, which are still availing the tax discount despite being put on rent,” the official added.

He said officials from the property tax department were also paying random visits to properties availing the tax discount.

The civic administration said every property owner was expected to inform the civic body if the property had been rented out. “However, it has been observed that the owners are not providing such details as they do not want to lose out on the 40% discount in property tax. This is the primary reason for the civic administration to start door-to-door survey,” another civic official said.

The administration’s steps to identify the rented properties follows the appointment of a committee to propose measures to boost the civic body’s income. The committee had suggested to the PMC to plug loopholes in recovery of property tax arrears and identify rented properties, which are still availing the discount.

“The committee has suggested to identify all the rented properties in the city, which are availing 40% discount,” the official said.

Title: Rape survivor, 15, left studies after traumatic episode, now demands death for accused who killed dad
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Agra: 15-year-old Dheera (name changed) was studying in class XI when history-sheeter Achman Upadhyay allegedly abducted her from Shikohabad and raped her last August. He had been stalking her for three years. She has quit studies ever since and is trying to recover from the trauma. However, her world came crashing on Monday when the accused shot dead her father for refusing to relent to repeated threats to withdraw the rape case. Now, she wants nothing less than death for the accused.

Dheera said, “I want death for Achman. He destroyed my life and killed my father.” Her 37-year-old father was the sole bread-winner of their family of six. The second eldest among four siblings, the burden of responsibilities is now on her young shoulders. Her elder sister had got married a couple of years ago.

Her septuagenarian grandfather said, “Achman is our neighbour. His father too had a criminal history. While Dheera was in class IX, he started stalking her. Unable to find any way out, we decided to shift her to her maternal grandparents’ home for her to be able to continue her studies. However, on August 26 last year, Achman met the girl while she was heading to school. He lied to her that her father was involved in an accident and took her to his relative’s home in Tilak Nagar. He confined her there and raped her.” “When she resisted the rape, he smashed her head on the wall and even tried to strangulate her. He also made a video of the act. Later, she managed to escape his clutches and reached home,” he added.

The septuagenarian further said, “On learning about her ordeal, we lodged a complaint against Achman, based on which police registered a case against him under IPC section 376 (rape), 363 (kidnapping), 307 (attempt to murder), 342 (wrongful confinement), 506 (criminal intimidation) and relevant sections of the Pocso Act. Despite repeated efforts, he was never arrested, until Wednesday night.”

The survivor’s father, who was an electrician and the sole bread earner of the family, was fighting tooth and nail for justice to his daughter. Achman had even threatened him of dire consequences on January 31.

Inspector general of police (Agra range) Satish Ganesh said, “We have built a very strong case against Achman and his accomplice. We won’t leave any stone unturned to get him convicted for the crimes he has committed. I have also recommended for a fast trial in the case with the most stringent punishment.”

Dheera said, “Nothing short of death for Achman will give me peace.”

Title: Bijnor man in hospital after symptoms of coronavirus appear
Content:
Coronavirus

BIJNOR: A 38-year-old man with novel coronavirus-like (COVID-19) symptoms has been kept in an isolation ward at Bijnor district hospital in UP. The man had returned to India from Singapore on February 8, stayed at the BHU university guest house in Varanasi for two days and then came to Bijnor.He was taken from his residence to the district hospital in an ambulance as per the norms after he complained of coronavirus-like symptoms. Samples of his blood, throat swab and serum have been taken and sent to Lucknow KGMC.The man, who is a research scholar in Singapore and a PhD holder from BHU Varanasi, was fully aware of the symptoms. According to heath officers, he had come with cough and fever on Wednesday. He also called on the health department number which he collected from the airport and had kept himself isolated at home, as a precautionary measure.Soon after receiving the call, authorities in Lucknow swung into action and informed Bijnor’s health officers about it. A heath team led by chief medical officer Vijay Yadav and district malaria officer Brijbhushan along with heath staff reached the man’s house. His house comes under Noorpur block of Chandpur tehsil.District malaria and communicable disease officer Brijbhushan said, “We had received information about the man from higher authorities in Lucknow on Wednesday night. Our team rushed to the place and took the man in an ambulance to district hospital. He was kept in an isolated ward. This man was found suspected with coronavirus-like symptoms. Samples of his blood, throat swab have been sent for tests. We also checked the man’s family and all of them are keeping well so far.”The death toll from the deadly outbreak rose to over 1,300 in China on Thursday with thousands of people affected by the virus in China and other parts of South East Asia.

Title: UP Police’s high-profile sniffer dog laid to rest with honours
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Police personnel in Saharanpur on Thursday laid to rest 10-year-old Uppam , a male Doberman which has been an indispensable part of the anti-sabotage squad for eight years, with government honours. Several senior police officials also paid last respects to the canine.

Uppam had been a vital part of the Saharanpur police dog squad for the past eight years and was deployed during two Kumbhs — 2012 and 2019 — and assembly and Lok Sabha elections apart from other regular deployments during bomb threats, VIP duties, religious processions and key events in the district.

According to Saharanpur SSP Dinesh Kumar P, Uppam breathed his last on Wednesday evening and a postmortem was conducted to ascertain the cause of death. He said, “He died of an unknown ailment on Wednesday. Later, a postmortem was conducted and the findings are still awaited.”

According to local police, there were seven dogs in the squad which has now been reduced to six. “Now, a female Doberman, four Labradors and a German Shepherd are remaining in our dog squad. Each have their constable handlers who look after their well-being,” added police.

Title: SB Road residents protest against traffic woes caused by medians and footpaths
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A group of SB Road residents present a memorandum of demands to civic officials and police

Pune: Residents of Senapati Bapat Road and surrounding areas have criticized the “smart” road infrastructure that causes daily traffic snarls in their localities.

On Wednesday, a group of residents staged an agitation and submitted a memorandum of demands to the civic administration and traffic police. The complaints mainly concerned the width of footpaths and the increased length of road dividers.

Pradeep Deshmukh, a local resident and activist, said they were not against development. He said the work has not proved beneficial to neither pedestrians nor motorists.

“Footpaths have been made too wide, minimizing the carriageway. The available space on footpaths could attract illegal hawkers,” Deshmukh said, adding, “Footpaths should be just wide enough for pedestrians, as PMC doesn’t have an effective mechanism to curb unauthorized hawking,” Deshmukh said.

Residents said the extension of the dividers and wider footpaths have not left adequate space for buses and cars to turn. “This leads to daily chaos. Motorists are forced to spend a lot of time at traffic signals,” a resident said.

Umesh Wagh, another SB Road resident, said many commercial establishments have mushroomed on SB Road over the past few years, increasing its traffic burden. “Civic authorities should take local residents into confidence while preparing plans to deal with traffic management,” Wagh said.

Officials from Pune Smart City Development Corporation said that the redesigned road infrastructure was part of the adaptive traffic management system project, which includes synchronization of traffic signals and pedestrian signals for a better flow of traffic. “The issues raised by the local residents will be reviewed and taken up for discussion,” an official said.

Title: Pune: Cops catch serial burglar, crack 127 cases
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police on Thursday claimed that it cracked 127 cases of burglary following the recent arrest of an inter-state criminal.Police also arrested six others and recovered gold and silver ornaments valued at over Rs37.73 lakh.The criminal, Munna Qureshi, had residences in Mumbai and Hyderabad, police said.“The solved cases include 82 from Pune and 45 from Mumbai, Navi Mumbai, Thane, Nashik, Nagpur, Hyderabad, Bengaluru and New Delhi,” joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve said on Thursday at a press conference, alongside additional commissioner of police Ashok Morale and deputy commissioner of police Bachchan Singh.Qureshi was previously arrested in 2018by the Pune police in connection with 36 burglaries. “After he was released on bail, Qureshi frequently travelled to Pune by air or road and committed the burglaries. He would flee to Mumbai or Hyderabad,” Shisve said.He further said Shisve was caught on CCTV cameras on multiple instances, but they were not able to trace his whereabouts. “He constantly changed his aliases and address to evade capture,” Shisve said.Qureshi’s luck ran out on January 21, when he landed in police custody. Following a few leads, a police team led by senior crime branch inspector Datta Chavan intercepted Qureshi’s car near Sanjay Park in Vimannagar and arrested him.“A search of his car led to the seizure of weapons used in the burglaries. Qureshi admitted his involvement in the burglaries under questioning, and also named a local accomplice, Ishwar Shindewal, alias Chintya,” Shisve said.Shindewal was among the six others arrested. The other five men — Sharif Shaikh, Ashok Pradhan, Abdul Sattar, Moghul Anwarali Baig, Prabhu Nanjwade — helped Qureshi sell the loot. Police recovered 830gm of gold and 6.3kg of silver from them.Qureshi has cases registered against him at 24 of the 31 police stations in Pune, Shisve said.“As per the investigation, Qureshi — with help from Shindewal — would conduct a recce of housing societies in his car. He then struck at locked flats, mostly at night, while Shindewal kept a watch outside,” Shisve said, elaborating on how Qureshi operated. “Qureshi would take help from his friends and relatives in Hyderabad to sell the loot,” he added.Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham has announced a reward of Rs25,000 to the policemen involved in the arrest.

Title: Uttarakhand opener Kamal Singh scores a century on Ranji debut
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ranji debut in Maharashtra

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand opener Kamal Singh scored a century in his first-class debut in Uttarakhand’s Ranji Trophy encounter against Maharashtra in Baramati on Thursday. Singh’s knock of 101 is only the second century from an Uttarakhand batsman in the current Ranji Trophy season after wicket-keeper batsmen Saurabh Rawat scored a century against Jharkhand in Ranchi last month.

The Haldwani born player’s century helped Uttarakhand in gaining a first-innings lead of 44 runs and posting a total of 251 on the scoreboard. Maharashtra bowler Satyajeet Bachhav claimed four scalps with his left-arm orthodox spin bowling.

A win for Uttarakhand in this match would ensure of them not getting relegated to the Plate Group. Kumar Thapa, manager of the Uttarakhand team, said that Kamal handled the attack with ease.

Title: Minister proposes prefab technology for affordable houses on state govt land
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: State housing minister Jitendra Awhad has proposed “prefab technology” for the construction of affordable houses to be undertaken by the Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Authority on the Maharashtra government lands in the city, Nashik, Aurangabad, Palghar and Nagpur.

Following complaints over the quality of affordable houses, the minister insisted on using the pre-fab technology to ensure that these houses provided comfortable living.

Collectors would have to allot space for these affordable houses to be provided at a price of Rs3-4 lakh per unit, said a source in the Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Authority (Mhada). An international tender would be floated in the next three months for the proposed project, stated officials in the know of the meeting held by the minister.

Mhada would consult experts about the project technology after it was proposed by the minister. Each home would have an area 300-350sqft. According to the minister, this will ensure that the economically weaker class beneficiaries have good houses.

The entire project would be under the affordable housing scheme. The state has set a target of building 19.4 lakh affordable houses. At present, a total of 13.58 lakh units had been approved by the government and 2 lakh tenements had been occupied by the beneficiaries, stated officials.

The affordable housing scheme under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana aims to reach out to the economically weaker section of society. The Centre has proposed 17 new technologies for providing quality housing in less time.

Sources from the housing department stated that the “pre-fab” technology was tested abroad. A private company in Khopoli also tested it.

Title: Gandhwani cop on the run after kidnap, rape plaint nabbed
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Indore: Gandhwani inspector Narendra Suryawanshi, who was on the run after being accused of abduction and rape , was arrested by Dhar police from Indore and sent to jail on Thursday.

Suryawanshi was caught red-handed by his wife while he was with another woman at his official residence on Tuesday afternoon. Later, the inspector was caught on camera assaulting his wife who created a ruckus on the premises.

On Wednesday, parents of the 20-year-old woman caught with him, reached police station and claimed that she was held hostage by the accused for past three days and had also raped her.

Acting on the information, SP Aditya Pratap Singh booked Suryavanshi under Section 376, 376 (2), 343 and 506 of the IPC.

As soon as the accused came to know about the criminal case being registered, he absconded. “After getting directions from the SP, a police team was tasked with his search and arrest”, said Gandhwani SDOP Karan Singh Rawat. The team raided about half a dozen localities and arrested him from Indore on Thursday afternoon. He was immediately taken to Dhar and produced in the court of special judge Vandana Raj Pandey in Dhar court campus. The court sent him to jail.

None of the advocates from the entire town came forward to plead for his bail despite the fact that he has been serving in the district for the last two decades.

Rawat told TOI that after first few hours of searching him, Dhar district crime branch was contacted for help as it had become a challenge to arrest him as soon as possible.

Title: City to elect junior bicycle mayor on World Bicycle Day
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: After city got a bicycle mayor in May last year, focus has now shifted to youngsters. Bicycle mayor Prakash P Gopinath has initiated a programme among city students to select a junior bicycle mayor who can promote cycling among students.

Students from schools which are part of bicycle brigade can participate. Staff coordinator of bicycle brigade can nominate student coordinator and another student for junior bicycle mayor by logging to www.induscyclingembassy.com. Students aged between 12 and 16 and studying in Class VI-XI in any school in the city can be nominated. Junior bicycle mayor will selected from the shortlisted candidates by a jury through an open defence on World Bicycle Day on June 3.

There will be points for conducting cycling workshop in school, organizing ride with family and friends, introducing cycling to new friends, etc.

According to the organizers, the junior bicycle mayor will be an honorary position, who will be the ambassador of cycling among bicycle brigades. The junior bicycle mayor will get opportunities to represent the city in national-level cycling promotion events, to speak at different platforms about cycling and its benefits and engage in activities to make the city safer for children to commute in cycles. The junior bicycle mayor can hold the position for one year.

“Compared to others, children will be better effective campaigners to promote cycling among their peers. Currently Valsad in Gujarat is the only city to have a junior bicycle mayor. Along with us, Guwahati too will select a junior bicycle mayor on June 3. Here, nominations will be given by staff coordinator of bicycle brigade. Currently around 11 schools in city and four in Neyyatinkara have constituted bicycle brigades in their schools,” said Gopinath.

In every city, the bicycle mayor will be responsible for selection of the junior bicycle mayor. For details, contact bicyclemayortrivandrum@gmail.com or 8089494442.

Title: Vijayawada Airport: 20kg gold seized at Vijayawada airport
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

File photo of Vijayawada airport

VIJAYAWADA: Acting on credible information, sleuths of Commissioner’s Task Force (CTF) intercepted a private cargo courier and seized 20 kilograms of unaccounted gold ornaments worth Rs 17 crore right outside Vijayawada Airport on Wednesday evening. According to police sources, the courier came in from Mumbai and was collected by people here in the city.

The police said that they are interrogating suspects. Furthermore, cops also seized Rs 10 lakh cash from four persons involved in the transaction.

Sources said that the excess gold was being transported without any bills or proof of customs duty being paid on it. They said that the gold was being procured from major gold making companies in Mumbai at a cheaper rate and is being sold in the city at an exorbitant price.

This is the second such case this month, with the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) seizing gold worth Rs 13.3 crore in raids across Vijayawada, Nellore and Hyderabad during which people were caught with 31.2 kg of unaccounted gold ornaments.

Title: Coronavirus in Mumbai: After scare, Malabar Hill man declared virus-free
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Paras Society at Malabar Hill on Thursday called for BMC’s intervention to urgently test a resident it suspected of being infected with coronavirus. The man works in Singapore. Commotion over the matter lasted for over two hours in the building and ended after health volunteers arrived and ruled out any signs of infection. In a first, BMC issued a certificate, stating the 30-year-old resident was asymptomatic.Civic officials said they got a call around 10am from the housing society’s chairman, who told them the 30-year-old was seen “wearing a mask”. The building’s chairman called BMC’s disaster management cell which put him in touch with the ward’s medical officer, Dr Pramod Patil, who sent an assistant, along with an ANM (auxiliary nurse midwife), to check on the man, who was at home with his family. The medical team found that he had no coronavirus symptoms. “The man works in Singapore, and had gone to Sri Lanka to attend a wedding recently. He returned to India on February 10. He didn’t show any flu symptoms. He also didn’t have any signs of fatigue, usually seen when a person is recovering from flu,” said the doctor, adding that the man postponed his return to Singapore where 58 cases of coronavirus have been reported so far.Dr Patil said he issued a certificate to quell the fears of the building’s other residents. “We have certified that he doesn’t have symptoms and he has been screened by us,” the doctor said.The man at the centre of the storm told the BMC team that he was screened at the airport’s international terminal and was cleared. Prashant Gaikwad, assistant municipal commissioner of D-Ward, confirmed Thursday’s sequence of events.Dr Patil said the man was wearing a mask as per guidelines issued in Singapore that say masks are an effective way to prevent the transmission or contraction of the viral infection. Cases of housing societies and even offices demanding health certificates have been reported as the infection continues to spread beyond China.The state government on February 7 issued an advisory saying people should not discriminate against Chinese citizens or those with a travel history to affected areas.State epidemiologist Dr Pradeep Awate said multiple requests have come from corporates wanting to know whether employees who had recently travelled to China for work had tested positive for coronavirus. “We had to tell corporates that medical reports are confidential and cannot be simply distributed,” he said. “People should be assured that the health department is following up with people travelling from affected areas for two weeks.”Dr Patil said a team would be in touch with the Malabar Hill man till he completes 14-day isolation as a precaution.

Title: Three years on, govt bodies yet to update land records
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: Three years after a government circular was issued directing departments to update records on land in their possession, the process remains stuck on paper.

The circular was issued following the MIDC land scam case in the Bhosari industrial area. The circular directed government bodies to prepare a detailed report after confirming their entries in property cards and 7/12 extracts within three months.

“While all the departments were asked to carry out the process, it is not yet completed,” a senior official from the revenue department told TOI.

Revenue officials said the process has been bogged down by the sheer volume of data and a shortage of staff to verify documents going back 60 years. “Land has been acquired by the land acquisition officers from the revenue department, but changes in the record of rights has not been carried out. A recheck of all the records is necessary,” officials said.

“While the acquisition process has been completed, the final ownership of the government organization, which should have been recorded, is absent,” an official said.

In 2016, over 500 cases of private land, spread across 10,000 hectares acquired for government purpose in the Pune revenue division, had come under the scanner after names of government organization did not reflect in the record of rights. Various government organizations — public works department, irrigation department, MIDC, municipal corporations and councils had acquired land for various purposes, but their records do not show ownership. “Another factor in play could be that, while the due process of acquisition has been completed, disputes arise in many cases in the final stage of updating records,” he said.

Another official blamed laxity or negligence on the part of the parties involved.

Title: YCM Hospital to get advanced equipment worth Rs 3cr
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Civic-run Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial (YCM) Hospital is set to get two laparoscopy sets worth Rs 3 crore to enable doctors perform keyhole surgeries like appendicectomy, reducing patients’ post-operative stay at the facility.

“The new equipments will reduce the patients’ hospital stay from eight to three days,” Rajendra Wabale, dean YCM Hospital and Postgraduate Institute, said.

Mangesh Chitale, assistant commissioner, central stores department, said, “All legal procedures have been followed while inviting bids for these advanced equipment.”

Title: Hour-long surgery cures baby of rare birth defect
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: Timely diagnosis and an hour-long complex surgery helped doctors of a city hospital to give a fresh lease of life to a newborn detected with a rare birth defect.

The baby was diagnosed with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) during the mother’s sonography scan in the 25th week of pregnancy. “There was an absence of some part of the muscles (diaphragm) that separate the chest from the abdomen,” Jehangir hospital’s senior obstetrician and gynaecologist Vandana Khanijo said.

Since such a life-threatening congenital anomaly needs concerted management, Khanijo referred the mother to the hospital’s paediatric surgeon to plan and discuss the outcome of the pregnancy.

“Diaphragm is a partition in the body that separates the chest contents from the abdominal contents. This partition also helps a person to breathe. Due to the absence of the diaphragm, the abdominal contents like intestines, and organs like spleen and stomach were occupying the baby’s chest. The lungs in such babies are abnormally small and, in addition, they get compressed by the abdominal organs. The baby’s heart had also shifted to the right side of the chest,” senior paediatric surgeon Dasmit Singh said.

Neonatologist Sagar Lad explained to the parents the need for ventilatory care soon after birth, along with careful management of the immature lungs. “It is imperative to control the blood pressure of circulation in the lungs, along with low pressure ventilation, to prevent any damage to the immature lungs,” Lad said.

After assurance and support from the doctors, the parents took the decision to continue the pregnancy. When doctors were convinced of the baby’s maturity, labour was induced, following which the child was born through C-section on January 13.

The baby was immediately intubated, put on a ventilator and stabilised before performing the surgery. “That part of coordination was difficult, but we managed it with precision,” Khanijo said. After stabilisation, the baby was operated by Singh and anaesthetist Avantika Bhat.

“During the hour-long surgery, it was found that the stomach, spleen, part of the liver, and intestines were occupying the baby’s chest. We restored them to their rightful places in the abdominal cavity and fixed the diaphragmatic partition. To complicate the issue, the baby’s abdominal cavity was quite small. So, additional space had to be created by stretching out the abdominal muscles,” Singh said.

After the surgery, it took some time to settle various systems of the baby’s body. The newborn’s lungs expanded over the next few days and other vital parameters normalised. The baby was put off ventilator after 72 hours post surgery. Initially, the baby was fed through a tube placed into the stomach and subsequently the baby tolerated oral feeds. The baby was discharged on January 27.

The baby’s survival highlights the importance of antenatal check-up during pregnancy. “Early diagnosis, meticulous preparation and perfect execution ensured the survival of this baby,” healthcare expert Satyajit Gill, medical director of Jehangir Hospital, said.

When contacted, the parents said the baby was doing well.

Title: Haridwar: Priests to stirr if Har-ki-Pauri stream is not declared Ganga
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Har-ki -pauri

HARIDWAR: Ahead of the 2021 Kumbh Mela to be hosted at Haridwar , priests are angry at the government for not having undone a government order (GO) inadvertently passed by the previous Congress government of chief minister Harish Rawat in 2016, which the current BJP chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat had promised to remedy within a month of assuming office in 2017.

Waters of the holy Ganga is divided into several man-made channels along with the natural river bed, as it enters the plains at Haridwar. As chief minister, Harish Rawat had issued a GO declaring the stream passing through Har-ki-Pauri — the designated holy spot — as an “escape channel”, which priests claimed had hurt their religious sentiments. Under the banner of Ganga Sabha — an apex body of priests in the country — they had then organized a protest against the decision.

Former Ganga Sabha president Ashok Tripathi reignited the issue, when on Thursday, he asked, “Will Kumbh pilgrims be taking a dip in the holy Ganga or in a canal?” He threatened to launch an agitation if the stream passing by Har-ki-Pauri is not declared the main river.

Current Ganga Sabha president Pradeep Jha said they were willing to wait as the CM had assured them that the matter will be sorted before the Mela.

Title: Waghodia BJP MLA’s abusers get one day custody
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Raju Odedara and Sagar Patel

Vadodara: The man, who abused Waghodia BJP MLA, Madhu Srivastava, was remanded to one day of police custody on Thursday. Raju Odedara and co-accused Sagar Patel were produced before the court which sent the duo to police custody.

Both Odedara and Patel were nabbed on Wednesday by the detection of crime branch (DCB) from Ahmedabad.

The duo was earlier booked for hurting religious sentiments and threats to kill the complainant Vijay Yadav over phone. Odedara, who works as a security guard, had also called up Srivastava on February 5 and abused him during a heated exchange. The next day, Yadav, a sympathiser of Srivastava, called up Odedara who again threatened the complainant and also abused the gods.

While Raju originally belongs to Porbandar, Patel is a resident of Ahmedabad. On February 5, Raju had called up Srivastava to discuss his works being ignored by the state government. The conversation soon turned ugly and both started abusing each other. Both Srivastava and Odedara had claimed on the call that they were drunk. Audio of the call went viral on social media the very next day.

Title: Man beaten for hitting vehicle in funeral procession
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 24-year-old man from Gandhinagar filed a complaint with Vadaj police alleging that he was beaten by three to four men as his scooter mistakenly hit another scooter in a funeral procession in Vadaj on Wednesday.

In his FIR, Ajay Jadhav, a resident of Sector-17 in Gandhinagar and a student of BA third year with Gujarat arts and commerce college in the Ellisbridge, stated that he was returning from his college when the incident took place.

Jadhav said that few persons riding on two-wheelers were part of a funeral procession. As they were riding on wrong side, Jadhav hit one of the scooters and fell down on road. At that time, three to four men began thrashing him. One of them even tried to strangle him when he was struggling to save him from their punches.

Jadhav screamed for help and some of the people rushed there and rescued him. Jadhav called up police and his father. A team of Vadaj police reached there and brought Jadhav to police station where he filed a complaint against unknown persons under charges of causing hurt and abetment.

Vadaj police began an investigation into the case.

Title: Gone for a funeral, ten villagers hurt in bee attack
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Indore: In the third attack of bees in a fortnight reported in rural area of Mandsaur, at least 10 villagers were stung on Thursday. In similar attacks, an elderly man had lost his life while around 50 persons had suffered injuries.

“On the death of an elderly of Barkhedaloya village, around 200 villagers had gone to perform his last rites at a crematorium. Thick smoke emanating from the burning pyre would have enraged bees on the nearby trees following which they attacked the people there,” sarpanch Balkrishna Patidar told TOI.

He said that while most of the people managed to escape, at least 10 got trapped and were stung. “One of the victims has been hospitalized while remaining were being treated in a hospital of Garoth tehsil,” Patidar said.

A similar incident had occurred on Saturday when as many as 50 people, who had gone to perform the last rites of a villager, were attacked by bees at the crematorium of Titrod village in Sitamau, Mandsaur. Six people were taken to hospital as they were received grievous injured while remaining were sent home after preliminary treatment.

In the recent past, multiple bee attacks have been reported in rural areas of the district. In one such incident, an elderly person who had taken his goats for grazing had died after being attacked by bees at Bholamagra in Garoth.

“We have recorded the death of the elderly by bee attack,” said Garoth police station in charge Narendra Kumar Yadav, adding that as incidents of bee attacks are increasing, they would approach the forest department to shift beehives to a safe distance from the human settlements or take other appropriate steps, if any, to help avert such situations.

Title: Vava Suresh suffers snakebite
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

T’puram: Renowned snake catcher Vava Suresh suffered a snakebite and was subsequently hospitalised on Thursday. Suresh was bitten by a pit viper he was trying to catch.

According to sources, the incident occurred at Pathanapuram while Suresh was trying to catch the viper. The snake bit him on the middle finger of his right hand. He was rushed to Government Medical College Hospital, Kollam, and from there to the Government Medical College Hospital, Thiruvananthapuram.

Thiruvananthapuram MCH superintendent Dr M S Sharmad said that Suresh was admitted to the multidisciplinary intensive care unit immediately around 1.30pm and was administered anti-venom.

“At present, his condition is stable. But, we will have to keep him under observation for 72 hours,” Dr Sharmad said.

The main concern of the doctors is the history of Suresh facing numerous snakebites in the past. In all those cases, anti-venom was administered to his body. The doctors worry that anti-bodies that counter the anti-venom might have formed in his body during those instances. If so, the anti-venom administered in the latest case would have minimal impact.

Viper venom affects coagulation of blood and would cause excessive bleeding internally, especially in lungs. It also affects renal functions of the body. Dr Sharmad said that at present Suresh’s body has not displayed any such effects. But, there is a chance that adverse reactions may take place again. Hence, he is kept under 72-hour observation. Just over a year ago, Suresh had suffered a snakebite.

Title: Prez stresses on greater vigilance in Indo-Pacific region
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

(Photo by Sadanand Godse)

Pune: President Ram Nath Kovind on Thursday emphasized on greater vigilance in the Indo-Pacific region while observing that high quality training of marine engineers was crucial for sustained deployment and presence of the Navy in the country’s areas of interest.

“The geopolitical situation in the world, and in the Indo-Pacific in particular, demands greater vigilance. I am aware that the Navy has adopted mission-based deployments in the Indian Ocean region,” he said.

Kovind was speaking at a ceremony to mark the presentation of the coveted President’s Colours to INS Shivaji, a premier naval college of engineering which trains officers from the Navy and the Indian Coast Guards, among others, at Lonavla, about 74km from the city.

The institute, established in 1945 as HMIS Shivaji, is celebrating 2019-20 as the Platinum Jubilee year and the President’s Colours marks the highest honour in recognition of its exceptional service, in peace and war.

“The future will also see great diversity in the propulsion systems, ranging from conventional to nuclear and electric and hybrid propulsion. Concepts of maintenance will also undergo a paradigm shift with increased requirements on operational availability of platforms. INS Shivaji will need to impart the requisite skills to all trainees to prepare them to meet future challenges,” Kovind said.

“The training of marine engineers will also need to be tailored to train them to work with evolving technologies, while maintaining competence in the core engineering profession,” he said, observing that technology was leapfrogging to produce autonomous vessels.

“Artificial Intelligence and machine learning are being deployed for decision-making and war-fighting. I am confident that INS Shivaji would impart the skillset required in the future to all trainees passing out through its portals,” he said.

“A nation’s maritime interests are usually also linked to its economy and the well-being of its people. I am told about 90% of our trade, by volume, is handled by sea routes. This enhances the role of the Indian Navy not just in national security but also in economic security, and thus in the wider process of nation building,” The President said.

“The Navy is India’s chief instrument of its sea power. It is also the guardian of the nation’s maritime interests, both military and civilian.
