The nation is proud of the Navy’s commitment in protecting our maritime frontiers, securing our trade routes, and extending a helping hand in times of civil emergencies,” he said, highlighting the Indian Navy’s role in providing humanitarian assistance and disaster relief to the affected people of Madagascar following the devastation caused by Cyclone Diane.

Title: HM in soup for making student clean toilet
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Coimbatore: The father of a Class V student of a government elementary school in Pudhupalayam near Narasimhanaickenpalayam in the district on Thursday lodged a police complaint against the headmistress for making his daughter clean the school toilets and making caste slurs against her. He was accompanied by members of the Students Federation of India (SFI) and Tamil Nadu Untouchability Eradication Front.

On its part, the school education department has warned the HM and sent her on leave, as higher officials were not available to take action.

In his complaint to the Perianaickenpalayam police, M Parthiban, 34, of Maniyakarampalayam near Idikarai, said they belonged to the Arundhathiyar (dalit) community. The complaint said earlier this week his 10-year-old daughter had refused to go to school and take food. “When inquired, she said headmistress Kumareswari had forced her to clean toilets for two weeks. When she refused to clean them on February 11, the headmistress hit her and made caste slurs against her,” it said.

He sought action against the headmistress under the Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. “Police have not yet formally registered a case. They said they would do it on Friday,” said Dhinesh Raja, SFI .

School education department officials, meanwhile, denied the allegation that the headmistress had made the student to clean the toilets. A school education department source, however, said the headmistress was known to be rude and used to scold students. “Earlier, she had created problems at the government elementary school in Goundampalayam, following which she was transferred to this school.”

Perianaickenpalayam block education officer Krishnamoorthy said the headmistress had asked the students to use water to keep the toilet clean and that might have been misunderstood by the students. “However, we learn that she has behaved rudely to the students.” tnn

Title: 11th of Mandsaur family succumbs to injuries
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Indore: Another of the Mandsaur family , which lost nine members in a road accident in Bhilwara, Rajasthan, succumbed to severe injuries on Thursday morning.

Eight persons of Trilokchand Sharma’s family hailing from Sandhara village along with their driver had died in a road accident after the vehicle they were travelling in collided head-on with a bus of Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation (RSRTC) on Kota-Bhilwara Road late on Monday. Another member Tanuj, 18, had succumbed to injuries on Wednesday.

Abhishek Sharma, 27, died during treatment on Thursday morning.

“After the autopsy, Abhishek’s body was brought to Mandsaur and his last rites were performed by relatives in the evening,” collector Manoj Pushp told TOI.

He said that Mandsaur administration was coordinating with its counterpart in Bhilwara to ensure the best possible treatment to the injured.

At a local hospital of Bhilwara, four members of Sharma family including Mona, 24, Vedika, 1.5, Anuj, 15 and Vinayak, 25, are undergoing treatment there in a critical condition.

Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot and Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath expressed grief on the tragic accident. The state government has announced a compensation of Rs 2 lakh to the next kin of the deceased and Rs 50,000 each to the injured persons.

Title: MSU students, friends caught red-handed with liquor in hostel
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vadodara: Two students of MS University’s science faculty and their two friends were nabbed for possessing alcohol at KM Hall on boys’ hostel campus on Wednesday.

The warden of the KM Hall had received a tip-off that students in one of the rooms were involved in some illegal activity. The warden called the vigilance staff on getting the information and raided the room.

The vigilance staff said that the two friends were not students of the university and had come there to meet the science students. On checking the duo’s bags, the vigilance staff found two bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor.

On questioning, the students said that they had planned to consume alcohol but their plan was blown up. All four of them were handed over to Sayajigunj police station. However, police let all of them go next morning without registering any offence. tnn

Title: CMCH may put three patients on liver transplant waiting list
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Three weeks after the Transplant Authority of Tamil Nadu (Transtan) permitted the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital ( CMCH ) to perform liver transplants, the hospital is in the process of putting three patients on the waiting list.

The patients have a good chance of receiving a liver if a government hospital harvests an organ that matches their blood type. CMCH had performed the first cadaver kidney transplant a week ago.

The hospital, which began constituting a team and facilities to perform liver transplants a year ago, now has two surgical gastroenterologists trained to perform liver transplants. “We have three patients who need to undergo transplant and are fit enough to undergo the surgery,” said a senior CMCH official.

“We are in the process of completing all our assessments and sending them to Transtan. Once the liver transplant committee approves it, we will arrange for them to benefit from the comprehensive health insurance scheme. Once those two steps are fulfilled, they will be on the waiting list,” hospital dean Dr B Ashokan said during an earlier interaction with TOI.

If any of the government hospitals in the region announces a brain death and the blood group matches with those on the wait list, the patients have a strong chance of receiving a liver soon.

Salem GH had declared a brain death and arranged for organ harvesting for the first time on January 21 and CMCH had the first organ harvest on February 5. CMCH gets 10 to 12 patients declared brain dead in a month. However, they usually pass away before they can be put on ventilator or maintained.

So far, the liver failure patients that CMCH receives are medically managed with drugs. “In acute cases, they are sent to the Government Stanley Medical College Hospital, which performs many cadaver liver transplants,” said an official. “Some patients go to CMCH, while the others end up going to private hospitals if they can afford it. Others manage on medications as long as possible.”

However, the poor are severely affected because private hospitals charge a minimum of Rs 32 lakh for a transplant, including investigations and medications.

Title: More research spending needed for space programme: NASA scientist
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Indian government needs to allocate more funds for research and development in the Indian Space Programme, says Kamal Thakore, a Gujarati and a scientist at NASA. He was in Ahmedabad on Thursday to interact with students at Chimanbhai Patel Institute of Journalism and Communications.

Thakore is part of the team working on the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter project and others at NASA. “India is doing well in its space programme but the Indian government’s budget for the space programme is not big. Research and development (R&D) is very important and thus the government must focus on it aggressively and not rely on private companies which will only do R&D for their own benefit.”

Thakore also hailed the Indian government’s focus on defence, in context of its space programme. “India is in a hostile territory with China and Pakistan being on either sides of the northern border. We will face trouble if we don’t make our defence strong. To curb terror activities, we must have a strong hand,” he said. tnn

Title: Special cell to monitor work of third-party hires
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: The civic body has set up a separate cell to monitor the work of administration-appointed third-party auditors and consultants.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad recently issued an order for setting up a separate cell, which includes an officer of the rank of an executive engineer, a deputy engineer and three junior engineers.

The cell will report to the vigilance department of the civic body and will be responsible for assessing the reports generated by the third-party auditors.

The move comes after the elected representatives of the civic administration raised issue of inconsistencies in the reports of the audit agencies and consultants.

The representatives claimed that the performance of the third-party appointments was not up to the mark and the lethargic approach of the consultants had hampered the execution of several projects. They then suggested the appointment of a team of officers to monitor the third-party hires’ undertakings.

“The appointment of the special cell is to plug the loopholes in the reports generated by the third-party audit agencies. It would ensure that the civic administration spends realistically and avoids wastage of funds. In recent cases, it was observed that the reports of consultants lacked many vital details that were intrumental to the projects. The civic body should cease to accept such reports,” standing committee chairman Hemant Rasne said.

A senior corporator from the Nationalist Congress Party said the cell should also check the credibility and eligibility of the third-party auditors and consultants before finalising their appointments.

“The civic administration should not entertain blacklisted audit firms or those known for flouting norms. The special cell should also table the assessment reports before the PMC at regular intervals,” the corporator said.

The PMC undertakes developmental projects proposed by various departments and zonal offices within its limits. These projects include construction of roads, development of gardens, laying of pipelines and drainage lines, among others.

Title: Displaced people move HC for homes
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: Three persons from Gomtipur area have approached the Gujarat high court complaining that they have not been allotted houses as promised in the rehabilitation package while evicting them for the metro rail project.

The petitioners are Nathiben Solanki, Dineshbhai Jadav and Vijaybhai Makwana. They have said that they had non-titled houses in Gomtipur area. While asking them to vacate the place, the Gujarat Metro Rail Corporation (GMRC) offered a resettlement and rehabilitation package for squatters or non-title holder families. There was a scheme of compensation to the tune of Rs 3,000 per month and one-time compensation of Rs 50,000 to the affected for transportation and a tenement of 36.5 square metre in areas like Chandkheda, Bodakdev, Thaltej, Raipur, Saraspur or Vastral. This was provided in a resolution issued by GMRC, they claimed.

The petitioners have submitted that they had to vacate their houses and thus they are project-affected persons. In case of Solani, who is 66 years old, she was granted compensation of Rs 1.06 lakh only, but the authorities did not give her the promised tenement.

The petitioners claimed that after their houses were taken away in July 2016, they made representations that they should be treated as project-affected people and should be given alternate houses in accordance with the rehabilitation policy.

The GMRC replied to these petitioners’ representations on June 20, 2019 that there was no file pending as of now for grant of house or compensation.

Title: Passengers beat up man to death in crowded express train coach; 12 detained
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Pune: A 26-year-old man was brutally beaten to death by 13 ticketless travellers, including seven women, following a quarrel over seat-sharing in a crowded general compartment of the Mumbai-Latur-Beed Express, in the early hours of Thursday. The incident took place between Pune and Daund railway stations.

The Government Railway Police (GRP) in Daund later detained 12 people, including the seven women and a minor boy. Senior inspector Sureshsingh Gaud of the GRP, Pune, said, “The 12 detained people are being brought back to Pune.”

Police said victim Sagar Janardan Markad, an autorickshaw driver from Kalyan in Thane district, was travelling with his wife, Jyoti, his mother and two-year-old daughter to Kurduwadi to attend the funeral of Jyoti’s relative. The Markad family hails from Markadwada in Madha tehsil of Solapur district.

The family had started from Karjat in the Dadar-Chennai Express but got down at Pune station because the train does not stop at Kurduwadi. Around 12.45am, they boarded the crowded general coach of the Mumbai-Latur-Beed Express, which stops at Kurduwadi. They had to stand in the coach as there was barely any space to sit, police said.

Since Jyoti was carrying her sleeping daughter in her arms, Sagar requested a woman occupying a seat near the entrance of the coach to make some space for his wife. The woman picked up an altercation with him and started verbally abusing him, the police said.

In her statement recorded with the Daund railway police, Jyoti said that when Sagar asked the woman not to use foul language, she flew into a rage. She and other passengers started raining kicks and blows on Sagar. Some of them also hit him with sticks, the police said.

Jyoti told the police that she and her mother-in-law tried in vain to stop the assault on Sagar, who had collapsed on the floor of the coach. In desperation, she pulled the chain thrice to stop the train. However, the train stopped for a while but began moving again, she said.

None of the other passengers in the coach came to the family’s rescue although one of them alerted the railway police about the incident over cellphone. There was no patrolling in the coach.

A team of the Daund railway police moved into the coach after the train halted at Daund station and rushed Sagar to a private hospital, where the doctors declared him brought dead.

The Daund GRP registered a case under sections 302 (murder), 143 (unlawful assembly), 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting with deadly weapon), 323 (causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code and section 137 (ticketless travel) of the Indian Railways Act. The case has been transferred to the GRP in Pune.

Title: Gujarat HC to get four more judges
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court is set to get four new judges with the Supreme Court approving the proposal for promotion of four judicial officers to the HC bench.

During its meeting on Wednesday, the SC collegium has approved the names of judges – Ilesh Vora, Gita Gopi, A C Joshi and R M Sareen – as proposed for elevation to the Gujarat HC, the apex court said in a statement issued on Thursday. They are currently working as district judges in Gujarat’s lower judiciary.

At present, Gujarat high court has got 27 judges as against the sanctioned strength of 52 judges. The last appointment took place in the high court in March 2019 when Justice B D Karia and Justice Sangeeta Vishen joined the higher judiciary.

The promotions of Gujarat-cadre judges in higher judiciary drew controversies in the last couple of years. The transfer of Justice (retd) Jayant Patel, when he became the senior most judge of Karnataka HC, to the Allahabad HC led to his resignation. Similarly, the issue of transfer of Justice Akil Kureshi to the Bombay HC and later his promotion as chief justice of Tripura HC after the SC’s recommendation to make him the Madhya Pradesh HC chief justice gathered controversy. The Gujarat HC’s Bar approached the apex court against the alleged denial of promotion to Justice Kureshi.

Title: Man complains to VMC about synthetic eggs
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The man opened the egg and found a film inside it like plastic

Vadodara: A resident of Panigate area of the city has approached the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) food safety department with a complaint that he was sold a synthetic egg by a local vendor. While they didn’t buy his claim, the food safety officials may check egg suppliers in the city in the coming days.

The man opened an egg and found a film inside it which was hard to break and looked like plastic. A video, claimed to be of the ‘plastic’ egg also started making rounds in the social media. While the incident is said to be of Wednesday night, VMC officials received a formal complaint from the man only on Thursday evening.

“Our officials will check the quality of eggs that are being sold in the area. The complainant can also get the eggs he bought to be checked in our laboratory,” said an official of the food safety department. The official, however, added that they had not heard of any such incident in the city earlier.

The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has in the past clarified that it was highly unlikely that such eggs were being sold in the country. FSSAI has also circulated a detailed note in this regard. Sources said that a concern could be the freshness of the eggs that were sold to the complainant.

Title: Dehradun: Selaqui residents call off protest against Shishambara plant after 24 hrs
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: The residents of Selaqui called off their protest against Shishambara waste management plant outside the office of Uttarakhand Environment Protection and Pollution Control Board (UEPPCB) on Thursday. This comes a day after Selaqui residents began an indefinite dharna outside UEPPCB office in IT Park, Dehradun .

The stir was called off after Additional City Magistrate Maya Dutt Joshi assured the locals to look into the matter. The protestors also gave a memorandum to Joshi which was addressed to several ministers and secretaries of the state.

“The protest outside state pollution control board office has been called off as the ACM assured us that administration will soon look into the matter. We have also given a memorandum in which we have explained the problems being faced by Selaqui residents due to the stench coming from the Shishambara waste plant. We have mentioned in the memorandum that the waste is spreading diseases in nearby localities and also, polluting Asan river. We have warned the administration that if some proper action isn’t taken within the next 10 days then, we will launch a protest right in front of the chief minister’s residence,” said Satpal Dhania, a protestor.

Notably, the Selaqui residents have been protesting outside Shishambara Waste Management Plant for the past 130 days.

Title: Will run DPS East till March 31, govt tells HC
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ahmedabad: The state government on Thursday told the Gujarat high court that it intends to run the Delhi Public School (East) in Hathijan till March 31. The judges inquired how the administration will help parents to get children admitted in other schools.

The government said that it will run the school till the end of current academic session in response to a petition filed by parents of 369 students questioning the decision to abruptly close down the school.

The school management submitted that it has approached the Delhi HC against the cancellation of CBSE affiliation and the decision to close down the school and the issue is pending. Till the Delhi HC takes a final decision on the subject, the Gujarat HC was requested to adjourn the proceeding on this petition. The HC has deferred the hearing till March 9.

The school gathered controversy after its management gave space to godman Nithyananda for setting up an ashram in the school campus at Hathijan. The alleged irregularity came to the fore after a person lodged an FIR that Nithyananda and ashram management had illegally detained his minor kids and were involved in disappearance of his two daughters.

Title: Outfit claims several dalits have converted to Islam
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Dalit outfit has claimed that several arunthathiyars, a scheduled caste community, have converted to Islam acr... Read More

COIMBATORE: Tamil Puligal , a dalit outfit has claimed that several arunthathiyars, a scheduled caste community, have converted to Islam in the past month and a half across Coimbatore district .

“We had been subjected to caste discrimination of the worst kind for ages. We decided that conversion to Islam would free us from the clutches of caste hegemony,” said 28-year-old V Marx who has changed his name to Mohamed Abubacker after conversion. Abubacker, hailing from Kallipalayam village near Thondamuthur In Coimbatore, said five of his family members, including parents, have converted to Islam on January 11.

Ravanan, 32, from Saibaba Colony in Coimbatore said he converted on January 5. “There are several more dalits from our locality who want to convert to Islam. In the coming days a lot more of them will convert,” he said.

However, in the identical affidavits they filed seeking to convert to Islam, the dalits had declared that they were drawn to principles of Islam and hence chose to convert. “Everyone in our families were following Hinduism till date. We have no ill will towards Hinduism,” the affidavits said.

M Ilavenil, general secretary of Tamil Puligal, a dalit outfit, said that though they had been suffering caste discrimination for long, the tipping point was the Mettupalayam wall collapse tragedy where 17 dalits perished under the debris. “There was government apathy since the deceased were dalits,’’ he said. He claimed that 400 arunthathiyars have converted to Islam in Coimbatore since January. TOI could not independently verify the claim, but spoke to a few who got converted.

Incidentally, none of the dalits from Nadoor village where the wall collapse happened has converted.

“We are staunch believers of Lord Perumal. We will never leave Hinduism,” said Nadoor Muruganantham.

Ilavenil said there was huge political and police pressure to prevent the conversion, particularly in Mettupalayam, and hence dalits of Nadoor stayed away from converting.

“Hence, we kept the conversion move under wraps. Even now, most of the converted do not want to be identified for fear of a backlash,” he said.

Title: Assets worth over Rs 19L found from bank lockers
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ujjain: Lokayukta police on Thursday found cash and valuables worth over Rs 19 lakh from the bank lockers of cooperative department audit inspector during the second day of raids at his establishments and residences.

Lokayukta officials found Rs 1 lakh cash and gold and silver ornaments from two bank lockers of cooperative department senior audit inspector Nirmal Rai, Lokayukta DSP Vedant Sharma said.

The officials found documents indicating the inspector’s partnership in an RO water plant, he said.

Lokayukta police had raided Rai’s residence and unearthed assets to the tune of Rs 3 crore disproportionate to his known sources of income on Wednesday. He was employed with the department for the last 40 years. Apart from valuables, Rs 10 lakh cash was found hidden in the three-storeyed house. Details of fixed deposits of Rs 13 lakh were found during the raid.

The officials were in the process of ascertaining the source of income and expenses incurred by Rai in educating his sons – a doctor and an engineer.

Title: Pithoragarh: Two Nepalese women held with 4 kg cannabis
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

Pithoragarh: Two Nepalese women were arrested in Champawat district on Thursday for trying to smuggle drugs into India. The two women — Maya Devi (38) and Laxmi Roka (40) — were going towards Shimla. Police also seized four kilogram (kg) cannabis (charas) from their possession.

The arrest was made after the drug was found during inspection of their belongings by Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) and state police personnel.

“We recovered 1.96 kg drug from Maya and 2 kg from Laxmi. The two are residents of Rukum, Nepal . They told us that they were given Rs 10,000 by a person to smuggle the drugs into India. The identity of the person is yet to be ascertained,” said Lokeswar Singh, SP Champawat.

Title: Central government team inspects Mettur dam for damage
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

File photo of Mettur dam

SALEM: A six-member team from the central government ’s dam rehabilitation and improvement project (DRIP) inspected Stanley Reservoir in Mettur on Thursday. The team, led by DRIP chairman B K Mittal, inspected the sluice gates, 16 number shutters and tunnel shutters of the dam. They also visited the dam canals in a motorized boat.

The team also held a meeting with Public Works Department officials, including superintending engineer Jaya Gopal, executive engineer Devarajan and assistant executive engineers Subramanian and Madhusudan.

After the meeting, G Padmanabhan, one of the team members, said the Tamil Nadu government would repair and reinforce 36 dams in the state in the second phase of DRIP at an estimated cost of Rs 610 crore.

“The state government has given its nod to constitute an additional dam safety review panel to take up the second phase of the World Bank-funded project for which work will commence in April, this year,” he said. The Tamil Nadu water resources and agriculture engineering department will implement the project. The objective of the project is to improve the safety and operational performance of the existing dams and strengthen the dam safety institutional set up of the respective state.

Title: Leopard scare in Sirumugai
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Forest department officials in Sirumugai are planning to place a cage to trap a leopard , which has spread panic in villages on the forest fringes.

Villagers of Chittepalayam, near Kovilmedu , had spotted the big cat, which killed a goat, on Wednesday. They demanded that the forest department catch and relocate the animal.

Forest department officials combed forests near Kovilmedu, Chittepalayam, Sambaravalli and Thengalkaradu among others from Thursday morning to find the leopard. “We had placed camera traps to find the animal. None of the forest officials had seen the animal even once till Thursday night,” said district forest officer D Venkatesh. “Since the area is dry, we could not find pugmarks of the animal.”

A few months ago, forest department officials had successfully caught a leopard and relocated it to Sathyamangalam.

Title: District collectors struggling to provide house sites for all
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Amaravati: In a move that could hurt the state government ’s image, collectors in many districts have directed field-level staff to obtain satisfaction letters from beneficiaries of house-sites even before the sites are distributed.

Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy had asked the collectors to show the plots to beneficiaries before the distribution and hand over the pattas only if the beneficiary was satisfied.

Sources said many districts do not have vacant government land. For example, the Prakasam district administration could ready only 1,485 acres against the requirement of 2,319 acres. The land available is around 65% of the requirement. The story is the same in almost all districts. The shortage of land is severe in towns and cities where eligible beneficiaries are in thousands.

Struggling to find sufficient suitable land for distribution of house sites due to shortage of government land, the collectors have decided to ready the layouts in wherever land is available and distribute the plots.

In this context, there is a possibility of beneficiaries raising objection after seeing the plots. This might have led to the district administration obtaining ‘satisfaction’ letters from the beneficiaries before the site distribution.

Sources said some collectors were chasing tehsildars to acquire land required for house sites programme. In some places, farmers are refusing to hand over land due to paltry compensation offered by the district administration. Sources said the collectors are yet acquire at least 30% land required for the programme.

Since satisfaction of beneficiaries is mandatory as per the chief minister’s instructions, the collectors have decided to obtain the consent letters in advance.

If the beneficiaries found the land identified for house-sites was not suitable for construction, it may have an adverse impact. Sources said that in a hurry to meet the target, some tehsildars were acquiring agriculture land where construction of the house would not be practical.

Neerabh Kumar Prasad, chief commissioner, land administration (CCLA), has directed the collectors to complete land acquisition by February 28 and ready the layouts by March 15.

“It is the chief minister’s wish to see that no one in the state shall be seen without a house site after Ugadi (March 25). We are working overtime to give house sites to all,” said Prasad.

Title: Huge surge in demand for energy auditing subsidy
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Coimbatore: The district industries centre (DIC), Coimbatore, has received 43 applications from MSMEs for energy audit subsidies under the Promotion of Energy Audit and Conservation of Energy (Peace) scheme this year.

Of this, 13 applications have been filed and four of them have been given subsidies, officials said.

This was higher than last year, when only nine MSME units had filed and got the subsidy.

The ‘Peace’ scheme offers MSMEs 50% of the cost or Rs 75,000 as subsidy to conduct detailed energy audit. If the unit implements suggestions put forth by the energy auditing committee and shows 15% energy savings, they are eligible for getting 25% of the cost of the components or Rs 2lakh as subsidy.

General manager of DIC, Coimbatore, B Karthigaivasan said their target for the Peace scheme this year was to give subsidies to 60 MSME units and the target subsidy amount was Rs 30lakh. So far this year, Rs 1.7lakh has been given as subsidy for four units and nine subsidy applications were under process, he said. A total of 30 applications would be processed and filed soon, he said. “We eye to cross the target this year,” he said.

The DIC along with Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises (TACT) had conducted two awareness programmes on the Peace scheme at Velandipalayam and Ondipudur in the past weeks in the district.

District president of TACT J James said around 120 micro enterprise owners participated in each of the sessions. “Micro industrialists have said they would conduct energy audits at their units. A total of 17 people from both places have shown interest to apply for subsidy under the scheme,” he said.

He said based on how these units save energy and subsequently expenses, others too might take up energy auditing.

Title: When a Gujarati woman's love saved this Chinese man
Content:
Ma Hai Guo and wife Pallavi with 2-year-old daughter Ma An Ji.

AHMEDABAD: Love can conquer any odds. This was proved in the case of an Amdavadi woman whose love for her husband coincidentally saved her husband from China from the corona virus outbreak.Pallavi Gautam, 38, from Chandkheda was interpreter to Ma Hai Guo, 30, from Nan Chong city in Sichuan province in China. The interpretation turned into love and they married according to Buddhist rituals in December 2016.During the marriage, the couple promised to stand by each other in any difficult time and they stood by their promise.Pallavi, who is now known as Ma Pallavi Hai Guo, says, “After our marriage, we did not spend quality time together. So I had asked my husband to come to India for a long break so that we can live together. He followed my advice and came here on January 29, which was the same time when corona virus outbreak came to fore in China.”Pallavi said Ma Hai Guo works at a cellphone manufacturing firm, and was chosen by her as he is not like any typical Indian husband who feels ashamed in doing household chores.“He can cook, clean house and do any work which is not usually done by the Indian husband. This was one of the reasons for selecting him as my life partner,” she said.The couple has a two-year-old daughter Ma An Ji , which means ‘peaceful’ in Chinese. Pallavi says that her husband will stay in India for at least six months and the couple will then decide their further plans of settling either in India or in China later.

Title: Nothing says ‘I love you’ like Ooty carnations
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Over six lakh cut flowers including carnations, gerbera and liliums were sent from the district for export in ... Read More

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Intrepid lovers across the country will be carrying the carnation flowers that bloomed in balmy Ooty gardens today, the Valentine’s Day .

More than four lakh carnations were transported to major cities including Bengaluru from the 80 floriculture units in the hill district in the last one week, said Shiva Subramaniam Samraj, joint director of the horticulture department.

Floriculturists were putting off harvest for more than a week to encash on the demand.

Red carnations cultivated in the district are in demand next to red roses, said Kishore, a cut flower dealer. “February has always been a month of demand for cut flowers. Red carnations are in great demand to substitute the red roses in bouquets,” he told TOI.

A red carnation fetches farmers Rs 13 to Rs 16, Kishore, who sends cut flowers to Bengaluru, Chennai and Cochin, said. “Over six lakh cut flowers including carnations, gerbera and liliums were sent from the district for export in the last couple of weeks.”

The district does not produce cut rose varieties, said Samraj. “The climatic condition in the Nilgiris favours only roses of hybrid, shrub and climbing varieties. Long-stemmed roses used by florists require humid weather condition such in Krishnagiri and Hosur.”

Cut flowers are mainly procured by flower agents in Bengaluru through local agents and then exported mainly to Egypt, Germany and the United States.

Meanwhile, couples, especially the newly-wed, are flocking to Ooty to celebrate the special day. The weather gods are favouring the love-struck with moderated wintry sun during the day and mildly chilly evenings.

K Kishan and R Manisha, a newly-married couple from Secunderabad, said they came to Ooty just to spend the day in each other's arms.

Title: Tiger kills cow, spreads fear among villagers near STR
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

ERODE: The residents of Gandhi Nagar near Thalavadi in Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve were sent into widespread panic on Wednesday evening after a tiger on the prowl killed a cow in their locality. While the search for the big cat that was launched the previous night continued on Thursday, the combined team of villagers and forest officials didn’t make any headway.

The forest department is expected to set up a cage with a bait in it to trap the animal that is wandering near the village.

According to P Nagendra, 28, of Gandhi Nagar, who reared the cow that was killed, the tiger came out of the STR around 6pm on Wednesday. “I had left my seven cows on a farmland near the reserve forest for grazing. When I heard them cry and reached the spot, I found the tiger pouncing on one of the cows and trying to drag it into the forest,” he said.

Nagendra rushed back to his hamlet and alerted the fellow villagers, who rushed to the farmland. However, the tiger had left the place leaving the dead cow behind.

The villagers informed forest officials, who joined them in the search for the tiger. Though the search continued till Thursday, they couldn’t trace the animal.

The villagers have appealed the forest officials to trace the tiger at the earliest. A forest official said, “We will set up a cage to capture the tiger.”

The official said the dairy farmer would be compensated for his loss.

Title: Doctors, nurses turn maternity scan centre into dance floor
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

ERODE: The maternity scan centre at the Andhiyur government hospital had turned into a dance floor recently as the medical staff organized a farewell party there for their retiring colleague. The issue came to light on Thursday when the video of some of doctors and nurses dancing to some popular movie songs surfaced on social media.

TOI found that the incident had taken place on January 31, when chief doctor Dr S Kavitha and other medical staff threw a farewell party for Dr S N Sampath Kumar, who was retiring from service on that day. They had decked up the scan centre and nearby areas with colourful balloons and other items for the occasion. The event was held in the evening.

“During the event, a few doctors and danced to popular movie numbers, while some others sang songs. This was when more than 50 inpatients were undergoing treatment at the hospital. They were not bothered about whether the noise would cause disturbance to the patients,” said a doctor, requesting anonymity.

When contacted, Dr Kavitha said the event hadn’t caused any disturbance to the inpatients. “We conducted the event at the scan centre and no one was disturbed. I will not, however, allow such events to be hosted in the hospital in future,” she said.

Title: Retain original expansion plan of airport: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Coimbatore: Local administration minister S P Velumani has requested Union minister for civil aviation Hardeep Singh Puri to retain the original plan for expansion of the Coimbatore airport.

In a letter handed over to Puri on Thursday, Velumani said that the state government has already initiated the acquisition process for 627.89 acres as per the notification issued during 2010-11.

Rs 2,64.47 crore was allotted during 2018-19 and 2019-20, and the disbursement process to the landowners has commenced, the minister said. In this backdrop, chairman of the Airports Authority of India (AAI) informed that AAI has reworked the land requirement to an extent of 605. 67 acres (541.89 acre for airport development and 63.78 acres for 60 metre-wide approach road) as per the revised master plan to make the airport suitable for operation of wide-bodied aircraft.

“As seen in the revised master plan, about 5.76 acres of extended area does not come under the already notified area of 627.89 acres and about 27.98 acres of land already notified for the acquisition process. It is now subtracted from the original plan of 627.89 acres,’’ Velumani said.

“If the area is revised now, the landowners might seek compensation under the New Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act 2013, resulting in additional burden on the state exchequer. This could halt the expansion process,” the minister said.

Pointing out that in addition to additional expenditure, the land acquisition under revised plan would consume more time, Velumani requested the Union minister to allow completion of airport expansion as per the original schedule.

Velumani also met Union minister for rural development and panchayati raj Narendra Singh Tomar and requested him to release Rs 2,939 crore towards the second instalment of wages, material and administrative cost under MGNREGS for the year 2019-20 and an additional Rs 609.18 crore for wages, material and administrative cost till February 10. TNN

Title: Two cheated of lakhs by online fraudsters in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In a garb of updating KYC (know your customer) information, online fraudsters duped two Naranpura residents of lakhs using the same modus operandi. Two complaints have been filed with Naranpura police on Thursday.

In the first FIR with Naranpura police, Dharmesh Shah, 55, resident of the Naranpura area who works as development manager with LIC, said that he had lost Rs three lakh to online fraudsters on December 22.

Shah states in the FIR that he had received a call on December 22 from a man, introducing him as employee of Paytm, and asked him to update KYC (know your customer) details. The man told Shah to download an app called ‘quick support’ and add Rs 10 to it.

Shah paid Rs 10 in the new app wallet and after that his phone got hanged and Rs three lakh were deducted from his bank account, states the FIR. The man then approached cyber cell of the crime branch and filed an application to probe about the fraud. A month later, cyber cell sleuths called him up and informed that Rs one lakh out of the Rs three lakh were freezed.

Later, cyber cell officials told him to file a complaint with concerned police station. Shah approached Naranpura police and filed a complaint of cheating along with charges of Information Technology act.

In another FIR with the Naranpura police, Amit Shah, 41, a resident of Naranpura who runs a business of packaging materials, said that an unknown man called him and told him to update KYC details.

This unknown man had also asked Amit to download quick support application and add Rs 10 money in it. After that, Rs 1.09 lakh were debited from his bank account.

He had also first approached the cyber cell and finally his complaint was lodged at Naranpura police.

Title: Efforts on to find Tamil equivalent of technical terms
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

According to the Act, all written communications and records should be in Tamil

COIMBATORE: While 92% of government departments in the district are adhering to the Tamil official language norms laid down by the Tamil Nadu Official Language Act, 1956, the rest, including the health department and the electricity board, continue to use technical terms in English extensively, officials of the Tamil development department, who are attending the two-day annual official language workshop for government officials that began in the city on Thursday, said.

According to the Act, all written communications and records should be in Tamil. “Signatures, nameplates, circulars and word processors in computers should be in Tamil,” said an official.

In order to implement the rule in the departments that are still lagging, the officials have been conducting annual workshops and gathering technical terms for which there are no proper Tamil equivalents. “From time to time, we represent these terms to a team of scholars, who come up with Tamil equivalents,” he said.

While the initiative is antagonistic to English, it aims to make government circulars and communications accessible even to people from the lowest rungs of society, the official said. “If a person, who doesn’t know English, gives a petition or a representation, he should be able to comprehend the reply given by a government office in return.”

The officials also inspect government offices twice a year to check whether the circulars, forms and records are in Tamil and whether the officials are signing in Tamil. “If we find violations, we would warn them. If it is repeated, we would record it,” the official added.

As many as 140 officials from various government departments and boards are attending the workshop.

Title: YS Jaganmohan Reddy: CM Jagan to meet Amit Shah in Delhi today
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is scheduled to visit the national capital for a second time this week on Friday. He would be meeting Union home minister Amit Shah this time in the evening.

Jaganmohan Reddy had met Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday and submitted a charter of demands which included abolition of the AP Legislative Council and shifting of the High Court to Kurnool besides other issues related to AP Reorganization Act, 2014.

The chief minister is very particular on the decentralisation of administration by shifting judiciary to Kurnool and executive to Visakhapatnam at the earliest. As the Legislative Council, where the opposition TDP has majority, referred the related bills to select committees, the chief minister is now insisting upon its abolition to avoid delay.

The AP assembly had passed a unanimous resolution on January 27 seeking abolition of the Legislative Council. The resolution was sent to the Union Home Ministry for further action. The Union Home Ministry had referred the resolution to the Law Department for its review.

The chief minister is likely to request Home minister Amit Shah to speed up the process so as to avoid delay in shifting the High Court to Kurnool and secretariat to Visakhapatnam while retaining assembly in Amaravati. The resolution is to be cleared by the cabinet and Parliament for the President to issue notification to dissolve the Upper House in the State.

Meanwhile, the TDP-led Legislative Council is making all out efforts to move forward on its decision to refer two crucial bills to the select committees. Chairman, M A Shariff, had already announced the names of the members for the two committees and named ministers Botcha Satyanarayana and Buggana Rajendranath.

However, YSRC, including the ministers, has refused to be part of the select committees alleging that the council chairman did not follow the rules while referring the bills to the select committees.

TDP MLCs are planning to lead a delegation to meet the central minister’s against the chief minister’s decision to abolish the Council. The TDP MLC delegation is likely to meet Union ministers of law and parliamentary affairs and lobby against the dissolution of the Legislative Council.

In this backdrop, the second visit of the chief minister to Delhi to meet the home minister assumes significance. Besides the Legislative Council, the chief minister is also insisting on shifting the high court to Kurnool. As the court is already dealing with a case relating to the decentralisation move of the government, the chief minister wants the central government to make its moves fast to preempt the TDP on both the issues.

Title: Ahmedabad: Woman files FIR against in-laws
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 43-year-old woman from the Ghatlodia on Wednesday filed a complaint under the domestic violence act against her five in-laws alleging that she was harassed and tortured as she demanded hereditary rights for her son. But her in-laws allegedly changed her husband’s name in documents related to hereditary rights to devoid the complainant’s son to get the hereditary property.

The woman stated in her FIR that her in-laws began harassing her and thrashed her soon after their marriage in December 1996. In 2006, her husband suffered paralytic attack and gradually his condition worsened. As her husband was not able work, her in-laws allegedly did not help her financially.

Her husband fell down on July 14, 2015 and after spending 20 days on ventilator, he passed away. During this period also, her in-laws did not help her and she had to spend her entire earning that she gathered through embroidery work on his treatment.

The woman states that she had finally succeeded to send her son, 21, to Indian Institute of Technology (IIT)- Kharagpur. She said that her father-in-law had hereditary land in Mahuva in Bhavnagar. But when she enquired about it to transfer the land to her son’s name, she found that her husband’s name was wrongly written.

Even though she constantly urged her in-laws to change the name, they denied it and also thrashed the woman. She finally approached the Vastrapur police on Wednesday and filed a complaint.

Title: Teen track: Hook-ups and break-ups
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Love for majority of teens aaj-kal, is an emotionless highway, where hook-ups and break-ups are like changing attire. Blame it to peer pressure, instant gratification, loneliness , low emotional quotient, immaturity or hormonal changes, but this is the trend fast spreading.

Radhika Singh, a class XI student, always had a new boyfriend in three-four months. None of her relation stretched beyond that. On deeper probe by the psychologist, it was found that her control freak and possessive behaviour was reason behind her past seven break-ups. To avoid loneliness, she jumped to another relation immediately with no regrets of past.

Case is no different for Ankit Parikh, a class X student, who has one girl friend and four platonic relations. He said, “Break-up is common these days, so I always keep my back-up plan ready. It is uncool not to have girlfriend and I have a social image to maintain, who cares about emotions as they change automatically.” Adds Samir, another X grader, “It’s not fair to keep relationship going when you have no charm left, so it’s better to break up and move on.”

Sujata Tiwari, parent of a teen said, “I was shocked when my daughter asked me whether she is ugly and unattractive. Then she revealed that everyone in her class calls her ‘behanji’ as she does not have a boyfriend.”

(Names have been changed to protect the identities.)

Title: Ambulance drivers protest transfer of two colleagues
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: As many as 30 drivers of the 108 ambulance service turned up at the collectorate on Thursday to protest the transfer of two colleagues to Tirupur.

Guna and Koyamozhi were transferred because they were questioning the management on bad vehicle maintenance, said a protester. “They were also at the forefront of our earlier protests,” he said.

Several ambulances are badly maintained and are now being sent to Tirupur for maintenance, said a driver. “Vehicles that used to be maintained at workshops in the district are now being sent to Tirupur. This is because the establishment failed to pay the workshops here. The two drivers were transferred, because they asked questions.”

Women paramedics lack proper toilet facilities wherever they are stationed, the protesters said.

Meanwhile, 108 ambulance manager Muthukrishnan said the two drivers were transferred for violating the company policy by going to the media first regarding the issues, instead of the organization.

Title: Nashik: Fire at ginning mill guts cotton stocks
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Fire at cotton stock

NASHIK: A fire at a cotton ginning mill in Malegaon city of Nashik district , which broke out at around 11 am, burnt down nearly 11,000 quintal of cotton.

Seven fire tenders of the Malegaon Municipal Corporation rushed to the spot within a few minutes of being informed. It took them nearly two hours to control the raging blaze

Fire officials said that the exact reason for the fire is yet to be ascertained.

“The stock of cotton was kept in an open space within the mill’s premises. After the fire started, the mill workers quickly managed to shifted about 10,000 quintal. But the remaining stock was gutted,” added the officials.

Some civic officials said the fire could have been started by some lighted material like a cigarette. The local police would carry out a panchnama of the incident to ascertain the exact volume of destroyed cotton and the cause of the fire.

According to some local residents, the entire area where the mill is located was engulfed in thick smoke.

“When we reached the spot, the mill building was invisible through the thick smoke. We also helped the fire officials in controlling the blaze,” said Jainuddin Mansuri, a local politician.

Title: Not expelled from party, says AIADMK MP out on bail
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Former AIADMK MP K C Palaniswamy was released from the prison on Thursday after he was granted conditional bail by the Coimbatore principal district and sessions court on Tuesday. He was arrested on January 25 for running a fake website in the name of AIADMK despite having been expelled from the party .

Speaking to reporters after coming out of the prison, Palaniswamy said there was no communication from the party headquarters stating that he was expelled from AIADMK, hence there was no question of him forging his identity as a member. He also added that he has been fighting for the primary members of the party to get their rights to elect a general secretary for the party.

“AIADMK informed through media that I was removed from the party. But the party did not give any letters in written about my removal from the party. The party also did not send any letters to my address,” Palaniswamy said.

Title: Rs 1.35 crore for farmer producer groups to buy implements
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Twenty-seven farmer producer groups (FPG) in the district will be given Rs 5lakh each to buy farm implements and other equipment under the collective farming scheme this year.

Of this, 19 FPGs come under the agriculture department and eight, under the horticulture department. The departments have approached the collector for approval and are expecting it within next week.

Each group comprises 100 farmers. Earlier, 20 farmers were grouped into farmer interest groups (FIGs). Five of those groups were clubbed to form one FPG.

Agriculture department officials said with the fund, each FPG can buy farm implements or machinery they need. “They can use them among themselves or lease them to make money for the group,” said an agriculture department official.

The groups are spread across 12 blocks of the district. “The farmers can be cultivating any crop. They have to be from the same area,” said the official.

The scheme was started during 2017-2018. In the first year, 21 FPGs under the agriculture department were given Rs 5lakh each. Last year, 19 FPGs were given the fund.

Horticulture officials said they have been giving the funds to eight FPGs from 2017-2018.

While some groups are performing well under the collective farming scheme, some needed frequent impetus, the official said. “If the farmers take up the initiative and perform well, the scheme would be very profitable for them.”

The initial steps to form the FPGs are taken up by the agriculture and horticulture departments. The next step of forming farmer producer companies (FPCs) clubbing 10 FPGs would be taken up by the agriculture marketing department. The produce of the members will be packed or value-added and marketed directly without the involvement of middlemen.

Title: Civic work may delay as panchayats stare at empty coffers
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

When the rural local body elections were held, and village panchayats got their presidents after a gap of three years, the residents hoped that civic works would pick pace.

But the villagers as well as panchayat presidents are disappointed as they are staring at near empty coffers in the local bodies. Even in panchayats that have funds, the panchayat presidents are stuck as they could not access the funds due to a new rule that all money transfers should be done through the National Electronic Fund Transfer (NEFT) system.

R Pandiammal, the panchayat president of the Siruvalai panchayat in Madurai district, is a AIADMK member. “I was told that the coffers of my panchayat were almost empty, when I assumed charge. To ensure that the people are not affected we carry out small works, like motor repairs and water supply from my own money. When the funds are accessible, we intend to bring about big changes in the panchayat,” she said.

Many of the elected panchayat presidents have been given bank passbooks with less than a lakh in the panchayat account. This is insufficient to carry out developmental work, they said.

First time president A Angusamy, of Chinnakannanur village panchayat in Manamadurai union in Sivaganga district says that there is about Rs 6 lakh in the panchayat account, according to the bank statement given to him. But he couldn’t utilize the funds so far due to the new rule mandating NEFT transactions. “As of now I’m spending from my own funds to fix lights and repair taps,’’ he said.

K Aruchamy of Kolapratti panchayat near Pollachi said that he wanted to construct a community hall at a cost of Rs 4 lakh for his village. “But there are no funds,’’ he said.

The newly elected panchayat presidents said that they are yet to work out the specifics on fund requirement. For now, they are studying the financial discipline of the village, revenue and expenditure over past few years, and the requirements of the village. “Once we prepare a list of requirements, we will arrive at an estimated budget for the projects and approach the government for the fund,’’ said P Ranganathan, president of Kalangal panchayat near Sulur in Coimbatore.

B Thangavel, president of Odanthurai panchayat in Coimbatore said he has approached Nilgiris DMK MP A Raja for funds. Odanthurai near Mettupalayam falls in Nilgiris Lok Sabha segment. “He has agreed to provide Rs 13 lakh for a construction of an intake well to augment drinking water supply to our village. I am also planning to request him for funds for building a subway at a railway crossing,’’ Thangavel said.

In Mukkudi panchayat in Thirupuvanam union in Sivaganga district the newly elected panchayat president P Muthiah has set right faulty streetlights with his own funds to the tune of Rs 1.75 lakh.

However, panchayat presidents are hopeful that soon the government would release funds. “For an efficient president, paucity of funds would not be a problem at all. There are multiple sources. We must work closely with MLAs, MPs, government officers as well as industrialists and charity organisations to raise funds for the sake of public welfare,’’ said Ranganathan.

A senior government officer said that funds would be released soon. “Funds are being released for ongoing schemes like MGNREGS. We will soon release funds for village specific projects,’’ he said.

Title: Have delivered on 57% promises: Uttarakhand CM
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: In a meeting with BJP legislators, ministers and bureaucrats which was termed as ‘Manthan’ (Brainstorming), chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Thursday reviewed ongoing development projects in the state and claimed that 57% of the announcements made by the state government had been completed in the last three years. The CM also declared that separate departments will soon be made to boost reverse migration besides announcing the ‘CM Vatsalya Yojna’ for orphans, road to each village by 2022 and designated land as ‘samadhi-sthal’ of saints in Haridwar. In order to boost tree plantation, the CM said that a massive tree-planting drive will be carried out across the state on July 16.

“In the long marathon session, many points were brought to the fore. We have decided to form a separate department for people of the state who have migrated to other locations and want to invest in Uttarakhand. This department will aim to promote reverse migration, especially in the hills,” said the CM. He added that the migration commission formed by his government had “carried out elaborate research that will encourage people hailing from the state and settled outside, to return back or invest in the state.”

Pointing out that many seers come to Haridwar and take ‘samadhi’ here, the CM said, “The body of such saints used to get released in Ganga. With Kumbh coming up, many saints are expected to visit Haridwar. Therefore, we have decided to give land to saints for constructing ‘samadhi sthal’. Now, the bodies would not be released in Ganga.”

The CM also announced a ‘Vatsalya Yojna’ for the welfare of orphans. Although he did not divulge the details of the project, the CM said that it aims to help the orphans when they grow up and are ready to take up job opportunities.

Another big announcement was regarding road connectivity to villages. “We have decided that by 2022, all villages of the state will be connected with roads ,” said the CM.

During the meet, BJP legislators underscored different issues of their respective constituencies that require attention. Bageshwar MLA Chandan Ram Das suggested that the condition and infrastructure of government rest houses in his district needs to be improved. Salt MLA Surendra Singh Jeena highlighted the need of mobile medical vans in the hills.

Similarly, Nainital MLA Sanjeev Arya suggested the use of forest department’s barren land for afforestation work. Harbhajan Singh Cheema, legislator from Udham Singh Nagar district, was in favour of holding a similar review meeting after every three months. Rudraprayag MLA Bharat Singh Chaudhary advocated the need for early construction of Sainik School. Yamkeshwar MLA Ritu Bhushan Khanduri stressed on providing job opportunities to the youths of the state.

Meanwhile, Congress MLAs strongly criticised the review meeting asking as to why Congress MLAs were not invited. “Is he the CM of only 57 constituencies or the entire state? If it was a programme to discuss the projects of the entire state, then why were the Congress MLAs not called? I heard that the BJP was calling it a party event. If it is a party event, what were the bureaucrats and top officials doing in it?” asked Manoj Rawat, Congress MLA from Kedarnath.

Title: Cybercrime cops hold meeting with OLX, DoT over scams
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The victims of OLX frauds explained their ordeal at the meeting

Vijayawada: Vijayawada cybercrime police held a co-ordination meet with OLX representatives, Department of Telecommunications (DoT) officials and Telangana cybercrime team on Thursday.

Cops also brought in victims of OLX frauds for the meeting and explained their ordeals on the occasion. During the meet held at the BSNL headquarters, OLX representatives gave a detailed presentation on measures taken so far in preventing the frauds and aftermath measures.

On the other hand, cybercrime officials placed some of the demands such as implementing Know Your Customer (KYC) norms stringently, geotagging vendors, identity verification and cooperation with the cops during a fraud.

So far at least four cases of OLX fraud had come to light in the city where vendors convince customers to pay them an advance fee outside OLX payment gateways.

Cops explained that they had already communicated their issues with the e-commerce platforms with the DoT officials in light of the scams who then began to hold awareness meetings with major players.

Speaking on the occasion, deputy general manager Robert Ravi requested the OLX representatives to consider and implement the suggestions so that it could prevent further advance-fee scams.

Title: Seven more micro compost centres to come up in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Workers processing the biodegradable waste in Kulimikkarai road MCC in trichy

TRICHY: The Trichy Corporation has sanctioned Rs 2.9 crore to construct seven more micro compost centres (MCC), for collecting, processing and recycling the waste generated within a ward. Work on the new MCCs will start from March and will be completed in four months, an official said.

Already, 31 MCCs are functioning in various parts of the city, due to which the quantum of waste heading to the Ariyamangalam dump yard has drastically reduced, the civic body has said. However, as the existing MCCs lack infrastructure to cover all the 65 wards, the corporation has proposed to establish 17 more MCCs.

As part of the proposal, the local body has initially sanctioned the Rs 2.90 crore to install seven new MCCs in six wards of K Abishekapuram zone, including Pirattiyur, Crawford, Puthur and Fathima Nagar.

The proposed MCCs will cover the wards that were so far covered by the existing MCCs in nearby wards. The MCCs will receive waste from the mini-trucks that collects waste at doorsteps from houses.

MCCs will segregate the waste further through women self-help groups (SHG) and process the biodegradable waste into manure within 45 days by decomposing the waste and applying micro-organism solution.

Non-biodegradable waste will be sold to scrap dealers for a price while combustible waste such as leather and rexine will be transported to cement factories as fuel.

“We have opted our own office space to establish the new MCCs. They will lessen the burden of the existing MCCs that additionally cover another ward,” a senior corporation official said.

The new MCCs predominantly will cover the entire ward in which they are located and additionally the nearby wards.

The corporation said that transport cost and time involved in moving the waste will come down.

Title: Nashik: Chhagan Bhujbal directs civic body to prevent Godavari pollution
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Godavari river

NASHIK: District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal has directed the civic body to take all the necessary steps to prevent pollution in the Godavari river .

He chaired a review meeting of Nashik ’s city projects under the Smart City Mission at Mumbai on Thursday.

Sitaram Kunte and and Prakash Thavil, the chairman and CEO of the Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Limited(NMSCDCL), respectively, attended the meeting along with civiv chief Radhakrishna Game.

According to sources, the minister has made it clear to the Nashik Municipal Corporation and NMSCDCL that both these agencies have to take immediate steps to ensure that no sewage water flows into the river without first being treated.

“He reminded the authorities that Nashik’s identity is due to the Godavari and all steps must be taken to prevent the river from getting polluted,” said sources.

Recently, during his visit to the city, well-known water conservationist Rajendra Singh was appaled to see the extent of the pollution in the river and had described Godavari as a patient on ventilator support.

“Bhujbal also instructed the officials that all smart city projects that are planned on the banks of the river should be undertaken in an eco-friendly manner,” said the officials. He also asked the officials to implement all smart city projects in a time-bound manner ensuring their quality.

Title: Nashik medical college project gathers steam
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The proposed government medical college in Nashik

NASHIK: The proposed government medical college in Nashik would have about 120 seats for postgraduate courses and 100 for under graduate courses.

At present, Nashik does not have a government medical college, although there are a couple of private medical colleges in the district.

The Nashik-based Maharashtra University of Health Sciences would be entrusted with the responsibility of running the college. The college would offer postgraduate courses in 11 subjects.

District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal chaired a meeting about the project in Mumbai. State medical education minister Amit Deshmukh, public health minister Rajesh Tope, senior government and MUHS officials attended the meeting.

“Bhujbal has directed the officials to put the project on a fast-track so that at least PG courses can kick off from the upcoming academic year. Both Deshmukh and Tope have assured that their departments would help in starting the PG classes as soon as possible,” officials told TOI.

According to the officials present in the meeting, Bhujbal is keen on MUHS starting courses for homoeopathy, ayurveda etc. also in the future.

A MUHS official said that it is due to Bhujbal that the medical college project in Nashik has gathered pace. “MUHS wants the project to start as possible since it would help students in the state,” said a varsity functionary.

The state government and MUHS will soon sign an MoU outlining the details of the project. The university would be responsible for providing the facility for the college and oversee its functioning. “For the first three years, the college would function at the Nashik civil hospital. Till then, a new medical college and hospital would be constructed within the premises of MUHS. There is ample land available within university,” officials added.

Title: Don’t raze Sectt until new design is finalised, HC tells T
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana high court on Wednesday directed the state government to not demolish the existing Secretariat building till the cabinet decides the plan and design of new Secretariat complex and till the HC adjudicates the pleas filed against demolition.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy gave this interim direction while hearing two PILs filed by Congress MP A Revanth Reddy and Professor P L Visweswara Rao.

Responding to a contention of additional advocate general J Ramachandra Rao that the designs have not been finalised yet, the bench wondered as to why the state is taking so much time to finalise the design. The bench also expressed doubts as to how the construction of a new structure would commence without design and directed the government not to go ahead with the demolition process till it decides about the new structure.

The government has been contending that it wants to build a world-class Secretariat in the place of the existing Secretariat. The state counsel said that the existing Secretariat is beset with many problems and the offices in it were scattered.

He said that the proposed new structure would be built with Rs 400 crore and urged HC to allow them to go ahead with any plan that suits the government.

Title: A blend of youth & experience at Khajuraho fest this yr
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Bhopal: In its 47th edition, Khajuraho Dance Festival is expected to live up to its reputation yet again. Starting from February 20, this weeklong cultural extravaganza will see a perfect blend of youth and experience mesmerising the audience in the backdrop of ethereal Khajuraho temples, a UNESCO World Heritage site in Chhatarpur district, with their mastery over various classical dance forms, including Kathak, Bharatanatyam, Odissi, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam, Sattriya.

This year, the inaugural day will see two virtuoso dancers—gurus Uma Sharma and Jatin Goswami—perform for the discerning audience. Both will also receive Kalidas Samman from MP government at the festival.

Looking forward to attend the event, Uma Sharma said, “This will be my sixth performance at Khajuraho festival, which is very close to my heart. I will be performing there after a gap of 12-15 years, along with my troupe, so it makes it extra special. My focus would be on abhinaya, sadly this aspect is losing its lustre when it comes to all the dance forms today. I would like to revive it, especially for the youngsters."

Goswami who had performed earlier at the prestigious fest in 2002, shared, "This will be my second performance at one of the best classical festivals in the world. I really hope that I can inspire the youngsters to take up ethnic traditional dance forms like Sattriya, which are slowly becoming extinct."

A major tourist attraction, the annual fest is attended by a lot of tourists from India and abroad. Despite the ongoing coronavirus scare, the number of foreign tourists is not likely to nosedive. “People plan their trips to Khajuraho especially during this time because the weather turns beautiful with the advent of spring and sublime aura around the temples adds to the magic of dance performances. This year too, we expect around 200 foreign tourists every day, especially from the United States, Britain, France and Germany, along with Indians," said Akhilesh, director of Ustad Allauddin Khan Sangeet Evam Kala Academy, department of culture, Madhya Pradesh, the organiser of the event.

"With each passing year, we have seen the number of youngsters increase at this event," said Akhilesh and added, "We have invited the students of dance from various music colleges across the state, so that they get a platform to watch some of the internationally acclaimed dancers at this unique platform. It is a great learning experience for them."

Meera das, Pujita Krishna, Krishna Mohan Mishra, Lata Singh Munshi, Shobana Pillai, Suprava Mishra, Anand Shankar Jayant, Y Asha Kumari, Kshitija Barve, Ragini Makkhar, N. Srikanth , Aswathy Srikanth, Nair sisters, Narthaki Nataraj, Bhadra Sinha, Gayatri Verma, Richa Joshi, Deepak Gangani, Mohika Saxena, Srividya, Enakshi Sinha, Sinam Basu, Amita Khare are some of the dancers expected to perform at the event.

Khajuraho Dance Festival, organised by the Madhya Pradesh Kala Parishad, is a one-week festival of classical dances held annually against the spectacular backdrop of the magnificently lit Khajuraho temples.

Title: Air Marshal Choudhary visits Air Force Station at Devlali, Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chief Maintenance Command of the Indian Air Force

NASHIK: Air Marshal Shashiker Choudhary, the Air Marshal Commanding-in-Chief Maintenance Command of the Indian Air Force, has called upon the personnel of the Air Force Station, Devlali , to be professionally sound and always be vigilant to safeguard the assets. He lauded the high level of professionalism of the personnel at the depot.

Choudhary arrived in Nashik for a two-day official visit to the Air Force Station, Devlali, on Wednesday. He was accompanied by his wife Anita, who is the president of the Air Force Wives’ Welfare Association (Regional). Air Commodore and AOC Air Force Station Devlali, Ravi Sharma and his wife Rama received the guests.

The AOC-in-C was introduced to the key personnel and was given a short brief on the depot functioning. He visited various sites, warehouses and material management institute located in the functional wing of the depot.

Choudhary showed keen interest in various aspects of the functioning of the depot and appreciated its well-maintained infrastructure. He emphasized on the well-being of all depot personnel in terms of body and mind.

Anita Choudhary visited the Air Force School, station medical centre, AFWWA ventures and Aarambh playschool and she interacted with the staffs and appreciated their efforts and involvement in maintaining the ventures in a professional manner. She also interacted with the special children of the depot.

Title: Baranagar fire: Woman dies after three days
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Kolkata: Three days after a middle-aged Baranagar homemaker ran in a ball of fire and collapsed in front of a neighbour’s door on Sunday, she died at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital on Thursday.

Cops on Thursday arrested the victim’s sister-in-law for allegedly setting the victim , Shyamali Das, on fire with kerosene and burning her to death during an argument. Cops are looking for others family members of the accused, Smita Das, who had gone into hiding after the news of Shyamali’s death arrived.

According to locals, the two Das brothers own an ancestral house on a three-cottah plot at Baranagar’s Lakeview Park. “Both families used to engage in bitter battle over property dispute. Sometimes, neighbours, too, intervened to settle the matter,” said a local.

“Both the families also complained to police against each other but they continued with the brawl till late at night,” a local woman said.

The situation took a turn for the worse on Sunday when the two got into an argument. “Both the husbands weren’t at the home when the two homemakers scuffled with each other during an altercation over property dispute. Suddenly, we saw the eldest housewife running on the street in a ball of fire,” a neighbour said.

Title: Appoint high-ranking officer to check if BMRCL is following norms: HC
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The high court on Thursday directed the Centre to appoint a higher-ranking officer to inspect whether BMRCL has complied with terms of the memorandums of understating (MOUs) pertaining to Phases 1 and 2 of the Namma Metro project .

Acting on a PIL filed by DT Devare and Bangalore Environment Trust, a division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka also directed the central government to specify whether the Metro policy envisaged is enforceable or not.

The bench orally indicated that in case the policy and associated norms are found to be binding in nature and the project is not being implemented in accordance with them, the court will not hesitate to stop the ongoing Phase 2 project.

The petitioners have claimed that despite the agreement between the state and Centre with long-term perspectives for Bengaluru, the authorities are continuing with implementation of the Metro project without adhering to Comprehensive Mobility Plan (CMP) and Integrated Traffic Ratio Rationalization Plan (ITRRP).

Th petitioners have also cited example of authorities leaving out two important stretches, Marathahalli to Hosakerehalli and Iblur to Hebbal, due to the possibility of overlap with the elevated corridor project. According to them, a huge amount of public money is being wasted on ad-hoc and stopgap projects.

Sanction for Phase 1 was accorded on May 11, 2006 and a tripartite MOU was signed on December 24, 2010, as per which the state was under obligation to created an ITRRP or CMP. Phase 2 was approved on February 21, 2014 and an MOU was signed on February 24, 2017.
