Title: Shelter saved 10 inter-caste couples in a year
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Safe shelter for inter-caste couple in Trichy

TRICHY: A year after its inauguration, the state’s first exclusive safe shelter for inter-caste couples in Trichy has accommodated and saved several couples hounded by their families for marrying outside their caste. On the occasion of Valentine ’s Day, about 10 couples who benefited from the facility were profusely thankful to it for safeguarding them from the hostility they faced.

The shelter built by Adhalinaal Kadhal Seiveer (Therefore, fall in love) trust near police colony in Anna Nagar for about Rs 10 lakh was opened in the Valentine’s Day week last year. Couples marrying outside their caste who approach the trust can be accommodated in the 345 square feet facility for one week. The time should be used to register their marriage and find employment to lead an independent life. “A week after the inter-caste marriage is crucial for the two adults. We help them in this critical period by providing them shelter and food,” Se Gunasekar, managing trustee of the trust, said.

Though inter-caste couples can approach the police station, they will not be allowed to stay there during the night. Thus, very often they are orphaned on the streets and it is for such people that the shelters will be a safe haven, Gunasekar said. According to him, the shelter which completes a year on February 14 has saved 10 inter-caste couples from violent opposition from their families.

“For a week, my family was hounding us because I married a person of another caste. We felt very safe in the shelter. It will surely help similar couples to evade the threats,” said a 24-year-old woman. The trust said that police colony was chosen for the shelter as it is located close to the Navalpattu police training institute. “We have applied for recognition from the district social welfare department. However, they have been hesitating to recognize the shelter saying there is no precedent,” Gunasekar said. If the department rendered recognition, police stations would direct inter-caste couples seeking refuge to stay at the shelter, he added. Efforts to contact the district social welfare department officer went in vain.

Title: Two-day IT conference to focus on disruptive tech
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The two-day annual conference of the Computer Society of India (CSI), EPIC 2020, organised by CSI Visakhapatnam chapter in association with Visakhapatnam Steel Plant (VSP) will be held in the city on February 20 and 21.

Addressing the media here on Wednesday, chairman of the CSI Visakhpatnam chapter and director (personnel) of VSP, KC Das said the theme of the conference is ‘Edge computing, Process automation through robotics Industry 4.0 and Cognitive technology (EPIC 2020).

The conference, Das said, will bring together researchers, engineers, developers, practitioners and students from academia, industry, government bodies, NGOs and MNCs for an exchange of knowledge, experience and ideas on how disruptive technologies are changing society and industry.

Over 300 delegates are expected to attend the conference, Das said, adding that the conference will foster dialogue among IT professionals and serve as a forum for discussions on state-of-the-art research and developments in information technology. Chairman and managing director of VSP, PK Rath has conceptualised the conference, Das said. The conference will have two key-note addresses by technical experts. Exhibition stalls will showcase the latest IT products and services on offer by manufacturers, service providers and dealers of IT equipment.

Title: Nashik: Stretch from Meher signal to CBS chowk to remain closed for 2 days
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Stretch of road from Meher signal to CBS

NASHIK: The stretch of road from Meher signal to central bus stand (CBS) chowk will remain closed for two days starting Saturday in both the directions.

Police issued a notification to this effect on Thursday. Police have decided to keep the aforementioned stretch of road closed in view of the two-day convention of the Maharashtra and Goa Bar Association and the Nashik Bar Association on the premises of the district court from Saturday.

Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde will be in Nashik on Saturday to address the Bar. On Sunday, Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray will lay the foundation of the new court building. NCP chief and former Union minister Sharad Pawar is expected to attend the closing ceremony of the programme.

Deputy commissioner of police Pournima Chougule-Shringi said, “We have decided to keep both sides of the road closed for traffic from 2pm to 10pm on Saturday and from 9am to 7pm on Sunday.”

None of the vehicles will be allowed to enter the road either from the side of the Central bus stand signal or the Meher signal.

Motorists who wish to travel towards Ashok Stambh and beyond will have to take the left from the central bus stand and move towards the Tilakwadi signal, from where they can go to their respective destinations.

Vehicles coming from Meher signal will have to take the left, go to Sangli Bank corner and take the road they wish to take.

Title: Nainital: Hubby kills actor over affair
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: A 29-year-old TV actor from Punjab, whose charred body was found in Nainital’s Kaladhungi area, was allegedly killed by her husband and his friend on suspicion of an extra-marital affair, police said on Wednesday.

Nainital SSP Sunil Kumar Meena told TOI that the actor, identified as Anita Singh, had come to Kaladhungi with her husband Ravinder Pal Singh.

The police official said that Ravinder suspected that Anita was involved in an extra-marital affair which is why he conspired with his friend Kuldeep to kill her. “Ravinder told his wife that his friend Kuldeep has some contacts in Mumbai who can help her get acting roles in Bollywood. The couple travelled from Ferozepur in Punjab to Kaladhungi on January 30 and met Kuldeep at an eatery. Kuldeep had laced Anita’s tea with sedatives and as she lost consciousness, the duo strangled her using a rope, took her to a field and set her body on fire after midnight. They then fled the spot,” Meena said.

After committing the crime, Kuldeep went to his home and Ravinder escaped to Delhi. The day after, local residents discovered the charred body and informed police.

Meena added that footages from over 110 CCTV cameras were scanned to nab the accused. “We scanned the CCTV footage and found the car in which Anita was carried. The owner of the car was soon located and he said that his relative, Kuldeep, had borrowed the car,” Meena said.

Police then traced Kuldeep and subsequently Ravinder, following which both confessed to the crime.

Title: TNSTC launches two AC bus services on Karur town routes
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), Karur region has launched two air-conditioned (AC) buses on town routes in Karur. State transport minister M R Vijayabhaskar inaugurated the buses on Thursday.

This is the first time after the Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC) in Chennai, AC buses on town routes are launched outside the state capital. TNSTC said they have attempted to operate the AC town bus for the first time in the state in Karur, a facility that is not available even in large cities like Coimbatore, Madurai and Trichy .

The two AC buses will connect Karur town with Kulithalai and Velur (near Velayuthampalayam) towns. Velur is located about 21km from Karur town while Kulithalai is located between Trichy and Karur Road. “Both routes are high-demanding stretches. Operating AC bus in the Velur destination is an appropriate choice as people near Velayuthampalayam visit Karur for work on a daily basis,” said K Manohar, a Karur-based businessman. Fare for the AC bus will 10-20% higher than the normal bus fare, officials said.

“Minimum ticket fare will be Rs 10, and will go up to Rs 30. Based on the response, we will increase the number of AC buses,” an official with the TNSTC said.

The AC bus has a seating capacity for 40 passengers and can accommodate 20 standees.

Since Coimbatore, Madurai and Trichy are sanctioned electric buses under Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric (FAME) II scheme, it is said that Karur was allotted the AC buses.

Title: Namma Metro News: Trains may run at 2-minutes frequency on 3 upcoming Namma Metro corridors
Content:
Representative image

Times View Speed, affordability and ease of travel have led to a surge in Namma Metro’s popularity. So have six-coach trains, which made commutes a tad more comfortable. With ridership steadily climbing, it’s prudent on the part of BMRCL to embrace new technologies and upgrade its systems. Increasing train frequency will not only reduce waiting time at stations, but may also get more passengers on board. However, BMRCL has a bigger task at hand: expediting work on the upcoming corridors. Phase 1 missed multiple deadlines and the same story should not be repeated this time around.

BENGALURU: Passengers travelling on three upcoming Namma Metro lines — Electronics City, IIMB and ORR-airport — needn’t have to wait long for the next train. The corridors may see trains running every two minutes, thanks to the advanced communications-based train control (CBTC) system.In existing corridors, peak-hour frequency is four minutes and for non-peak hours, it’s 10 minutes. The distance-to-go (DTG) signalling system is used at present, in which the minimum time between two trains is two-and-a-half minutes.“The newer standalone lines like Electronics City, IIMB and ORR-airport are being designed for CBTC from the beginning,” said BMRCL managing director Ajay Seth.CBTC can reduce train headway to less than 90 seconds.“The present signalling system can handle three minutes’ frequency. With CBTC, two-minute frequency is feasible, but reducing it to 1.5 minutes will require other operational improvements. Frequency doesn’t depend only on signalling, but also civil design, location of turn backs and length of underground sections,” he said.BMRCL is also planning to upgrade signalling system of the existing Purple and Green lines. “The present systems are designed for 120-second frequency. Upgradation of existing lines will be necessary after 10 years once the ridership reaches 40,000 passengers per hour per direction (PPHPD). At present, it’s about 22,500,” Seth explained.Officials said frequency of trains will depend on actual requirement and Phase 2 platform lengths will be designed to accommodate only six-car trains. The maximum length will be 150 metre for elevated stations and 192m (platform and system rooms) for underground stations.The state-of-the art signalling system has already been implemented in new Metro systems like Kochi and Nagpur. While RV Road-Bommasandra (Electronics City) line will be functional by November 2021, the other two corridors Gottigere-Nagawara (IIMB) and Silk Board-KR Puram-Kempegowda International Airport (ORR-airport) will be operational by 2024.Driverless trains will have to waitAn official said: “CBTC allows operation of trains without drivers but people are not ready to accept driverless trains. We have to instil confidence in passengers.”CBTC will help maintain a safe distance between trains with the help of sensors on the track and other systems.

Title: Telangana: Lucrative on-site posts find no takers amid coronavirus fear
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In their attempts to keep employees safe, IT companies are discouraging travel to China and other countries affected by the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), which has reportedly claimed nearly 1,200 lives in the neighbouring country.Even employees working for companies with Chinese clients have refused to take on-site postings in Hong Kong. In many cases, these on-site postings offer employees three times their current salary.While most IT companies in the state do not have business ties in China, the alerts are also meant to discourage employees from taking leisure trips to the country. “We are being told to name the destination of travel while making leave applications. The grapevine says that the human resource team is keeping track of all leaves being sought which are over three to four days. They are even trying to find out from other teams if a member has plans to travel abroad. Although our company does not cater to China or Singapore, many employees travel abroad for vacations,” said a software engineer working with an IT firm in the city.Meanwhile, some companies which have on-site opportunities are finding it increasingly difficult to find interested employees for such postings. However, employees are playing it safe be it for personal or professional reasons. “In our office, an informal chat by a senior supervisor about a posting in Hong Kong resulted in five people calling in sick the very next day,” said a techie under the condition of anonymity.While on-site offers are the creme-de-la-creme when it comes to opportunities with postings generally meaning higher pay, IT professionals have declined several such lucrative offers in a bid to avoid being affected by the virus. “While IT companies in Hyderabad have very few clients in China, most of the on-site postings are in Hong Kong and these have been declined outright. In fact entire teams have turned down offers, leaving team leads in a fix,” said Telangana Information Technology Association (TITA)president, Sundeep Kumar Makthala.

Title: Introducing the jury for Times’ Hyderabad Heroes
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The Times of India’s unique initiative, ‘Times Hyderabad Heroes ’, launched to honour the city’s do-gooders has received overwhelming response. To evaluate these entries and draw a final list of Good Samaritans, who will be featured in these columns, TOI has put together an eminent jury comprising four prominent citizens from Hyderabad.

On this panel are: BVR Mohan Reddy, executive chairman of Cyient and chairman of the board of governors at IIT-Hyderabad; Sangita Reddy, joint managing director of Apollo Hospitals Group; Pullela Gopichand, chief national coach of the Indian Badminton team and Swati Lakra, inspector general of police (women’s safety), Telangana. Apart from being celebrated professionals, each of these jury members are known for their contribution to society in the field of education, healthcare, sports and women’s safety.

Mohan Reddy’s Cyient Foundation that runs an Adopt-a-School programme, extends financial, infrastructural and social support to over 18,500 children in 28 government schools. The foundation also imparts digital literacy in India through 67 Cyient Digital Centres.

Committed to building an inclusive and sustainable healthcare ecosystem in the country, Sangita Reddy launched Apollo Reach, which aims to build a string of secondary care hospitals in rural areas across India. Her Apollo Philanthropy arm encompasses multiple programmes: Save a Child’s Heart Initiative, SAHI, CURE and the Billion Hearts Beating Foundation.

Alongside churning world champions from his own academy, Gopichand also plays an active role in the Gopichand-Mytrah initiative – a collaboration between Pullela Gopichand Badminton Foundation and Mytrah Foundation – that extends training facilities to aspiring athletes from economically weaker sections. It takes care of 32 athletes apart from other sportspersons in various disciplines.

Known for a force to reckon with, within the police department, it was during Lakra’s regime as ACP (Crime) that two major initiatives for women’s safety were rolled out: SheTeams and Bharosa Centre. Thousands of women and children — victims of sexual assault and domestic violence – find legal and social support through these platforms. Given its success, the Supreme Court even suggested that the Bharosa Centre be replicated across the country.

Title: Wrong catch: Fish nets in city lakes harming birds
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Hyderabad: Just a year after two incidents — a fishing hook piercing the neck of a flamingo and a darter’s beak getting entangled in a cloth at Ameenpur lake — a spoonbill was spotted with a plastic rope from a fishing net tangled around its beak at Osmansagar. Wildlife teams are currently on the lookout for the bird after a photographer posted the picture of the spoonbill on social media seeking its rescue.

Lakes and other water bodies in the city, over the past few years, are becoming increasingly hazardous for birds and other marine lifeforms due to the presence of ghost nets and other fishing gear. This, besides the rampant pollution.

“I have spotted a group of spoonbills during one of my photo expeditions to the backwaters of Osmansagar lake. Among them was this bird which looked as if something was stuck on its beak. After taking a closer look, I saw that a plastic rope from a fishing net got entangled to its beak,” said wildlife photographer and conservationist IS Hariharan. “The rope was so badly entangled that the bird was not even able to open its beak to eat. It was as if someone had tied it shut...,” he added.

Following this, environmentalists and members of the rescue team who formed a search party to find the bird have warned that such leftover fishing gear could threaten wildlife if not removed or disposed properly. “Our team is trying to track the bird...This is happening despite us cleaning the lake regularly and fishing out huge quantities of ghost nets,”,” said founder of Animal Warriors India (AWI),Pradeep Nair.

The AWI has reached out to the forest department asking them to intimate the concerned authorities and sensitise the fishing community about the dangers of such unattended fishing gear in water bodies. “We will write to the concerned authority as lakes do not come under our jurisdiction. We will attach photographs of such birds and other animals which are suffering due to these nets and ask them to sanitise such lakes,” said senior forest department official, A Shankaran.

Title: Teacher advice: Stick to revision of basics for last-minute studies
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Hyderabad: With the commencement of CBSE board exams just a day away, teachers have urged students to avoid studying till the last minute and instead use that time for revision of basics. Over 10,000 students from 167 schools across the city are set to sit for their Class 10 and Class 12 exams from February 15. The exams will begin with skill-based subjects followed by core subjects on February 21.

Given a slew of changes introduced by the CBSE for this year’s exams, teachers have discouraged students from rote learning. Students have been told to not worry about the “type of questions” as the board has reduced the number of questions for major subjects and has focussed on objective-type questions. “

There are students who try to mug up on the last day. They should instead strengthen areas which they are confident about and leave behind their weaknesses on the last day,” said principal of Chirec International School, Iffat Ibrahim. “Making notes of key topics will help them fare better,” the principal advised.

From revising chemical names to formulae and theories, teachers recommend that students should stick to the simple things and not exert themselves too much on the last day. “Many students believe in solving as many problems as possible till the last minute. Instead of solving problems, students should focus on remembering the procedures and formulas that will ultimately help them draw solutions,” said Raghavan Badrinath, mathematics teacher at Geetanjali School.

Apart from counselling students on managing stress, many teachers have formed Whatsapp groups to help students clear doubts.

Title: VMC spl officer rule extended
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) extended the special officer rule for another six months. The civic body has been under the special officer rule since the completion of the tenure of the TDP-led municipal council on July 2, 2019. Krishna district collector and VMC special officer A Mohammed Imtiaz proposed to extend the rule at a council meeting.

Meanwhile, officials are busy completing works for the upcoming municipal elections.

Title: Trafficked teen tortured in Saudi
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Hyderabad: A woman from Gulshan-e-Iqbal colony in Chandrayangutta has written to Union external affairs minister S Jaishankar to rescue her daughter, who was allegedly trafficked to Saudi Arabia in 2017 when she was just 15 years old.

Sayeda Sultana said her daughter’s age was shown as 32 in the passport that two travel agents First Lancer had made for the minor.

She claimed her daughter rarely contacted her, and has been calling occasionally in the past one year to inform she was being physically tortured and forced to work as a domestic help. The agents had promised the girl a beautician’s job for a salary of Rs 25,000 per month.

“In spite of my objection, my daughter went to Riyadh on February 1, 2017 form Delhi,” Sultana said. When she wanted to return to India as she was being made to work for 15 hours a day, and the kafeel demanded Rs 2 lakh to let her go.

Title: After residents, traffic cops irked by slow pace of work on Margosa Road
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Margosa road at Malleshwaram dug up by BBMP on tender sure project (File Photo)

BENGALURU: Traffic police have joined motorists and Malleswaram residents in expressing concern over the snail’s pace of redevelopment work on Margosa Road , a lifeline of the locality.

The work, taken up under the TenderSURE model, began on January 5, 2019 and was to be completed by the yearend. However, the slow progress has forced motorists to endure nightmarish crawls. Dust kicked up by the work is leaving locals and traders exasperated.

Considering that it’s a one-way stretch, it’s difficult to divert traffic and reduce congestion on the road, say traffic police. Joint commissioner of police (traffic) BR Ravikanthe Gowda said no work happens on the road at night, hence the delay. “They (workers) bring the material only by 3.30 or 4am,” he pointed out.

According to the officer, the contractor has listed out several reasons for the delay. The presence of nearly 75 trees on the stretch is among the major concerns as work has to be carried out in such a way that they aren’t damaged.

Rekha Chari, a member of the ward committee, said, “We had a panel meeting on February 6 and our corporator assured us the work would be completed by March 31.”

Srinivas KN, a senior citizen and resident of Margosa Road, said: “I leave for morning walk at 5am but it’s very dark as they have removed all streetlights. I can’t walk on the road any more as construction material takes up half the space.”

Title: Shareef warns of action if panel not constituted
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Amaravati: The stand-off over the constitution of the select committee in legislative council is heading for a showdown between YSRC and TDP as council chairman MA Shariff warned legislative assembly secretary of serious consequences if the committee was not constituted as per his instructions.

Taking legislature secretary Balakrishnamacharyulu’s decision to return the file with a serious note, the chairman asked the secretary to follow his instructions.

The chairman expressed his displeasure at the secretary for not obeying his directive. According to sources the chairman has told the secretary to face the consequences if he did not to comply with his directive.

Earlier this week, the legislature secretary Balakrishnamacharyulu had returned the file to the chairman stating it was not possible to constitute the select committee under Rule 154. Sources said the chairman sent the names for two select committees to the secretary with a directive to issue formal orders and send the notification to all the members.

The chairman named finance minister Buggana Rajendranth as chairman of the select committee to oversee the three capital cities bill and municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana as chairman for the committee to scrutiny CRDA repeal bill. He also named five MLCs from TDP, one each from YSRC, BJP and PDF in the two committees.

Leader of the Council and deputy chief minister Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose and YSRC chief whip Ummareddi Venkateswarlu wrote separate letters to the chairman and legislature secretary raising objection over the constitution of the select committees.

They said the formation of the select committees without voting on the bill was against the rules and there was no need to follow the chairman’s instructions. Bose said the chairman’s discretionary powers were very limited and he could not do whatever he desires.

Sensing trouble, TDP MLCs met the secretary and asked him to expedite the process of constituting the select committees as the chairman had taken the decision. Similarly, ministers Botcha, Bose and other senior YSRC leaders held discussions with the secretary and asked him not to constitute the panels as it was against the rules.

“The chairman’s directive is not a fatwa to be translated into orders immediately. The secretary too has a job to go through the rules and take a decision,” said legislative affairs and finance minister Buggana.

After going through the arguments of both the sides, the secretary returned the file to the chairman stating that the constitution of select committees under Rule 154 was not possible.

Title: 12% of rural Andhra doesn’t have mobile services: DoT data
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vijayawada: Despite completing two decades of cell phone revolution, the latest data collected from telecom service providers (TSPs) and Department of Telecommunications ( DoT ) in 2019 showed that 2,095 inhabited villages in the state do not have mobile services.

In Telangana, 110 villages are without mobile services.

Overall, AP accounts over 7% in terms of having inhabited villages without mobile services in India. Overall, India has 27,721 inhabited villages that are still waiting for a mobile service let alone internet penetration. However, BSNL boasts of having connectivity even in areas affected by Maoists in the state.

Going by census 2011, there are 16,158 inhabited villages in Andhra Pradesh which means that 12% of entire rural AP do not have mobile services while the remaining 14,068 villages have mobile services. The IT ministry attributed lack of mobile services in rural areas due to tough terrain, diverse locations, scattered population and commercially non-viable.

Interestingly, the data showed that the percentage share of BSNL to total subscribers in Andhra Pradesh was 11.31% and of private TSPs, 88.69%. One of the fundamental reasons for this is that BSNL migrated to 4G in Andhra Pradesh only in August 2019.

Whereas other private operators had already migrated and also brought out attractive unlimited plans under 4G scheme. Also, there are a total of 10,3365 4G base transceiver stations in the two Telugu states as of January, 2020.

Title: Alert patrol team foils mechanic’s suicide bid
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Hyderabad: A mechanic who attempted suicide due to his debts, was saved by a police patrol party of Amberpet at the nick of time when he was hanging from the ceiling at his shop on Thursday morning.

Amberpet police said they got a call from 50-year-old Subhramanyam informing them that he was committing suicide and disconnected the phone call. Police claim the patrol team reached Subhramanyam’s mechanic shop at Patel Nagar in three minutes. They opened the shop’s shutter and found Subhramanyam hanging from the ceiling with a chunni (stole).

On seeing him struggling, the patrol team — constables K Raghu Kumar, Vinod Kumar and home guard Gangachalam — rescued him by removing the chunni and immediately shifted him to a local hospital, and his life was saved.

“As part of community policing, generally the locals and police patrol teams exchange their numbers and be in touch with each other. Subhramanyam, who too has patrolling party number, directly called our patrolling staff and informed that he decided to end his life. Patrolling team tried to counsel him over the phone but he disconnected the call,’’ Amberpet inspector B Mohan Kumar told TOI.

He said that since the patrolling staff knew Subhramanyam they rushed to his shop. Police said that if there was a delay of even a few seconds, the mechanic would have died. ``Subhramanyam decided to take the extreme step due to financial problems,’’ the inspector said. However, no case was registered by police and his condition was said to be stable.

Title: Schools told to sensitise students on measures to prevent COVID
Content: Hyderabad: The Telangana State Council of Educational Research and Training (TSCERT) has issued a notice to all schools to sensitise students about public health measures to prevent spread of Coronavirus (COVID-19). The move comes following orders from the Union health ministry to spread awareness among students about preventive interventions.“Frequent hand wash, respiratory etiquettes (using handkerchief over mouth while coughing, sneezing...)staying away from school when sick...will help in preventing/reducing transmission of not only this disease but also large number of other communicable diseases...,” reads the notice issued to over 40,000 schools in the state.The TSCERT has also distributed pamphlets in schools and other teacher training institutions to follow simple public health measures to prevent spread of novel Coronavirus and other communicable diseases. “As of now, there is no drug or vaccine available to manage this disease. Hence, preventive measures become crucial to stop spread of this disease,” stated the notice.

Title: Trichy: Woman jumps into well with 9-month-old baby, rescued
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The fire service personnel said it was a miraculous escape for the woman and the baby as the water level was 5... Read More

TRICHY: Fire and rescue services personnel rescued a 30-year-old woman and her nine-month-old daughter from a ring well at her home in Subramaniapuram in the early hours of Thursday. Police said Mythili from Konar street jumped into the 30-foot-deep well with the baby to end their lives over a dispute in her family.

On hearing the baby’s cries, neighbours woke up and alerted the fire control room. As soon as the call landed at 2.25 am, the firemen led by Trichy station fire officer Melchioraja rushed to the spot in five minutes.

They found the woman holding the baby in her arms sitting against the wall on top of the water in the well. Leading fireman A Michael went down the well using a rope and caught hold of the baby. As Mythili refused to take his help, the fire service personnel lowered a ladder and she climbed up.

Though the mother and the baby had minor injuries, they were admitted to Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) and both were safe. Fire service personnel said the woman had jumped into the well 15 minutes before the cry of the baby reached the neighbours. All women police station (AWPS), Cantonment which took up the investigation found that she decided to end her life due to a family dispute.

The police were yet to decide on registering a case of attempt to suicide. The fire service personnel said it was a miraculous escape for the woman and the baby as the water level was 5 feet and the well was also free from any poisonous gas as it was in use.

Title: Nagpur: No government can give job to every graduate, says joint director of technical education
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: On the backdrop of rising unemployment and concerns over economy, joint director of technical education at Amravati division, DV Jadhav, raised several eyebrows when he said no government can provide jobs to every graduate.

He was speaking at the 22nd convocation of Government Polytechnic, Nagpur, on Thursday.

Speaking to TOI on the sidelines, Jadhav said by saying so, he meant that it is difficult to provide direct jobs. “No government can give jobs to 100% graduates. There are several schemes through District Industries Center (DICT) under the micro, small, medium enterprises (MSME) initiatives to provide funding worth lakhs. Graduates need to initiate startups so that they become job givers and not seekers,” he said.

Asked about largescale vacancies in government sectors, including education where qualified candidates are forced to take up odd jobs, Jadhav said it was up to the government. “I can’t comment on that as it is a policy matter,” he said.

On the manifestos of each party and successive government’s attempt to lure youth on job promise, Jadhav said, “Graduates shouldn’t wait for the governments to create jobs for them. They can innovate using their imagination and take benefit of schemes,” he said.

Jadhav delivered the 22nd convocation speech in the capacity of chairman, Board of Governors. This was the first time a joint director from a neighbouring division donned the role in the absence of a full-time joint director at Nagpur. The temporary charge is held by Ram Nibudey at Nagpur.

Addressing the students, their parents, and teachers, Jadhav said, “Now, you have achieved a major milestone in your career and you have an opportunity to choose either a graduation course or appear in competitive exam or may be opt for a job in industry. Even as you enter your working life, many good things are happening around.”

“But we are facing several challenges too. The first good thing is that you are entering your practical life when the Indian economy is getting integrated with the global economy through the process of globalization,” he said.

“Instead of becoming job seeker, can we become job provider by becoming an entrepreneur? You have different ideas. Incubate them, go for patent and being you own startup,” he said.

TCS Mihan center head Arvind Kumar, officiating principal Deepak Kulkarni, controller of examinations Milind Deshpande, ceremony in-charge NV Raut and heads of all 12 branches were present.

Title: Nashik: One killed, Two hurt in separate accidents
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: A man was killed and a woman and her daughter were injured in two separate accidents in Nashik , the police said.

A biker was killed when his vehicle was knocked down from behind by another motorcyclist at Shahu Nagar near Trimurti chowk. The victim, identified as Satyam Rajendra Thakur, was on his way to work in the Ambad industrial area when the incident occurred. He was rushed to the hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries.

In another case, a woman and her daughter riding a two-wheeler were injured when another motorist driving a car knocked down the former’s two-wheeler near the City Medical Stores, Gangapur Road on Tuesday at 9 am. The woman’s husband lodged a complaint .

Title: Anthem on global warming likely in April: A R Rahman
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A R Rahman

TRICHY: Music composer A R Rahman has exuded confidence of releasing the anthem for ‘Hands around the World’ project on global warming and climate change, in April.

“The first phase recording of the global warming theme project has just got completed in Hollywood. It is likely be released by April after completing the second phase,” Rahman, who was in the city to promote A R Rahman live-in concert to be held at Morais City in Trichy on Saturday, told reporters on Thursday.

Rahman said that his troupe has been preparing for the Trichy concert for four months. He also thanked the music lovers and fans from Tamil Nadu and abroad for their enthusiasm to watch the concert that is being held in a tier-two city for the first time.

“I am excited as this is the first time with these audiences. I hope you will love the show and it will be an inspiration,” he said.

Scores of Tamil songs and a few Hindi songs will be featured in the concert, said Rahman.

Rahman also denied that he concentrated more on foreign concerts. “We have a target that we should perform well. Several facilities were unavailable here nearly 25 years ago. But the facilities like sound systems are coming here,” he said.

Title: TDP MLCs to move privilege motion against chief minister
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Amaravati: TDP MLCs have decided to move privilege motion against chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy in the next session for disrespecting the council chairman MA Shareef and other members.

They will visit Delhi to apprise the central government about the alleged undemocratic actions of the chief minister.

These were revealed by MLCs P Ashokbabu, AS Ramakrishna and BT Naidu, who spoke to the media at the party office on Thursday.

They criticised the chief minister for insulting members of the Upper House. Ramakrishna said the Upper House has several intellectuals, including teachers, doctors and advocates, and it was unbecoming of the way the chief minister spoke. “The CM said MLCs entered the council from the backdoor. He has not right to humiliate the members who entered the portals through election in a democratic way,” said Ramakrishna.

Speaking on similar lines, Ashokbabu said the chief minister met Prime Minister Narendra Modi to discuss the abolition of legislative council and three-capital proposal but failed to make public the memorandum submitted to the PM.

He accused the chief minister of deciding to abolish the council out of grudge against TDP MLCs. tnn

Title: Nashik: Two booked for duping gym owner of Rs 6 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Two people have been booked by the police for allegedly cheating a gym owner of Rs 6 lakh on the pretext of running the facility on rental basis.

Nishikant Suryawanshi (53), a resident of Bali Mandir, Panchavati, has a gymnasium at Sitaram Chambers on Peth Road. Two people, hailing from Wadala village in Nashik city, approached him to take the gym on lease.

Suryawanshi rented out the gym in March 2019, along with equipment worth Rs 6 lakh. The business at the gym was going on smoothly for quite some time.

However, tensions started brewing between Suryawanshi and the two suspects over the conduct of the gym over the past few days. Suryawanshi said when the two suspects started defaulting on payment of dues, he asked them to honour the agreement he had signed with them.

A few days later, Suryawanshi learnt that some of the equipment had gone missing from the gym. When he asked them about the missing equipment, they made excuses claiming that the equipment was sent for repairs. Later, Suryawanshi learnt that the two suspects had allegedly sold the equipment to a person in Bhiwandi. He then lodged a complaint at Panchavati police station.

Police said they have launched a manhunt for the suspects. They have also searched their residences but the suspects were not there. “We have booked the suspects under section 420 (cheating) and 406 (breach of trust) of the IPC,” said a police officer attached with Panchavati police.

Title: West Bengal: Iskcon Mayapur gets ‘biggest’ pujari floor
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Newly inaugurated TOVP floor

KOLKATA: After waiting for 10 years, people got to see the inside of the Temple of the Vedic Planetarium (TOVP) at Mayapur — headquarters of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness ( Iskcon ) — on Thursday when the first floor of the temple was inaugurated.

Nearly 10,000 devotees can assemble together on the ‘ pujari floor ’, spread over 2.5 acres or 400,000 square feet. Iskcon authorities claimed that it’s the biggest single floor for religious congregation. The floor has a central hall and 20 mammoth rooms, each of which will be designated for some service.

The temple will be inaugurated in 2022 and devotees from across the globe, who are engineers, have designed its dome. This is the second largest temple in the world with 113 metres height, next to St Peter’s Basilica that is 138-metre high.

The temple is being built at a cost of Rs 700 crore, while Ambarish Das or Alfred Ford, a scion of the American Ford family owning the automobile giant, has taken a lead role in this project.

Three principal deities of the temple are Radha Madhava, Pancha Tattva and Narasimha. Perhaps for the first time, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, founder of Gaudiya Vaishnavism, will be addressed as the Prince of Nabadwip in this temple.

Title: Disinvestment move hampering AIE’s capacity addition: CEO
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Trichy: Trichy is the number one market for Air India Express (AIE) in Tamil Nadu and the airline wishes to add more capacity in this sector. However, as the company is in disinvestment mode, they are unable to augment the capacity as of now, said the budget carrier’s chief executive officer K Shyam Sundar.

He was speaking to reporters here on Thursday while announcing the airline’s maiden non-stop flights on the Trichy-Abu Dhabi and Trichy-Doha sectors from March 28. New services to Delhi and Madurai will also commence on the day. “With this, AIE will be offering Trichy passengers a total of 35 flights per week”, he added.

AIE has been operating flights to Dubai and Singapore for years while Sharjah was also added a few years ago. When asked about more domestic services, Shyam Sundar said though Air India Express is not much into domestic operations, they were introducing a direct flight from Trichy to Delhi via Madurai starting March 28.

Elaborating on AIE’s performance, he said the airline has been registering profit continuously for the last few years. “We expect a record profit of more than Rs 500 crore in 2019-20. Air India Express (AIE) has registered a 40% increase in operating revenue in the first half of the financial year compared to the corresponding period of last year,” he said. He added that the net profit earned by AIE had also gone up by 26%.

“Already we have attained Rs 4,235 crore as operating revenue at the end of December 2019. For the first time, AIE will touch Rs 5,000 crore operating revenue at the end of this current fiscal year since the airline's inception”, he said.

Title: Suicide note misleading, claims Viveka’s daughter
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Thursday heard petitions filed by former minister Y S Vivekananda Reddy’s daughter seeking a CBI inquiry into his death.

The petition was heard by a high court bench led by Justice U Durga Prasada Rao. Among the petitioners were YS Vivekananda Reddy’s daughter Sunitha Narreddy, his wife Soubhagyamma, MLC BTech Ravi, and former minister Adinarayana Reddy. The petitioners’ counsel expressed dissatisfaction over the investigation taken up by the state police. They argued that the special investigation team (SIT) deployed by the government was not effective. They said the police had arrested only three suspects in the case.

The counsel argued that Viveka’s suicide letter was misleading. “Despite allegations against the driver, the police still have not arrested him and this is raising doubts about the investigation,” the counsel said. Petitioners also argued that the then opposition leader YS Jaganmohan Reddy, who demanded a CBI inquiry into Vivekananda’s murder , had withdrawn the petition after becoming the chief minister.

When asked by the court whether they have any objections, counsels for CBI said they do not have any.

Former Union minister Salman Khursheed argued on behalf of MLC BTech Ravi. The court has posted the case to February 20 for further hearing.

Title: Staff up in arms as top collegiate edu official assaults two of them
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Trichy: A section of employees in the office of the regional joint director of collegiate education in Trichy on Thursday accused RJDCE S Usha of physically assaulting two of them and sought action against her. The employees have written to the director of collegiate education in this regard.

One of the victims, Rajeswari, a stenographer in the office, was admitted to hospital after she allegedly fell unconscious following the trauma. Sources said the assault began on Wednesday evening when office superintendent Savariyammal Brisca Mary came out weeping from Usha’s cabin. “Mary told us that she was slapped by Usha when she had requested her to process a file that had come from one of the aided colleges in the city,” said a male staff member in the office.

On Thursday morning, Rajeswari herself was slapped by her on her back for “committing a simple spelling mistake”. She said she was so traumatised that she had to be admitted to hospital. Director of collegiate education, Chennai C Jothi Venkateswaran confirmed to TOI that he has received complaints from the staff and that he would forward them to the higher education secretary recommending action against Usha.

Saying that this was not the first time that the RJDCE has been accused of such action, former BDU syndicate member D Muthuramakrishnan said that last year she was accused of abusing staff in filthy language and the issue was taken up with the district collector. She went on medical leave, but was reinstated after a few days.

Following the incident, employees of the RJDCE office, a majority of whom are female, gathered in front of the office in protest against Usha’s abuse. “Physical assault of subordinate staff invites suspension with immediate effect. Therefore, we urge the higher education secretary to suspend her and order an inquiry into the whole controversy,” said former AUT president K Pandiyan. Higher education secretary Apoorva said she has not yet been informed about the incident but promised to take necessary steps after a detailed inquiry into the matter.

Title: Nashik: Two-Women robbed of gold chains
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

Nashik: Two chain-snatching cases were reported in areas falling under the jurisdiction of the Mumbai Naka police station on Wednesday.

In the first case, a 27-year-old woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 40,000 near Aditya Nagar corner on Ravi Shankar Marg. According to police, Khushbu Alkesh Bachchhav was walking home around 8.55pm on Wednesday when two bike-borne men snatched her chain. By the time she raised an alarm, the suspects had already fled towards Bodhale Nagar.

In the second case, Shweta Kisne (29), a resident of Ahmednagar currently residing at her relative’s place in Nashik, was going towards a medical store at Suvichar hospital in Ashoka Marg — close to the place where the first chain snatching occured. Just when she crossed Bank of Maharashtra, a motorcyclist snatched her gold chain worth Rs 30,000.tnn

Title: College students should get tested for thalassemia and sickle cell
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Nagpur: Vice-president of Maharashtra Medical Council and Director of Thalassemia and Sickle Cell Centre, Dr Vinky Rughwani recently met the vice-chancellor of Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University, Dr S P Kane recently and apprised him of the problems faced by thalassemia and sickle cell patients.

Rughwani explained that these two diseases could be brought under control only if precautions are taken by checking thalassemia minor and sickle cell trait test of every student taking admission in the university. Once this trait is found, precautions could be taken to ensure that children are not born with any major disease. Kane assured Rughwani that steps would be taken to issue instructions to all colleges regarding check up concerning thalassemia and sickle cell trait.

Title: 7cr litre of treated water goes down drain daily
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

(done)

Aurangabad: In drought-prone Aurangabad , which invariably faces water scarcity, a whopping seven crore litres of treated water generated from sewage treatment plants (STPs) is wasted almost on a daily basis.

The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) operates four STPs, which generate 75 MLD treated water, said the civic authorities.

While the civic body is ready to offer this water at a meagre price of Rs 25 per thousand litre for construction purpose, individuals as well builders continue to use either tap water or groundwater for building houses.

“The water generated from STPs cannot be used for drinking purpose, but it can be safely used for construction among other limited purposes. Out of 75 MLD water generated from STPs, only 2 MLD to 3 MLD is utilised towards the intended purpose. It is negligible use considering the huge amount of total treated water generated from STPs,” said Anil Tanpure, AMC deputy engineer with the drainage department.

“While one MLD corresponds to around 10 lakh litres of water, 70 MLD water in question that remains unutilised comes out to be huge seven crore litres, which is discharged into nullahs.”

Incidentally, the amount is close to half the water drawn by AMC from Jayakwadi dam over a period of 24 hours towards supply to Aurangabad. The civic body draws around 160 MLD to 170 MLD water from the dam

The AMC has STPs operational each at Kanchanwadi, Zalta T-point, Padegaon and near Salim Ali Lake with varying installed and operational capacities.

Civic authorities said that only National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has been procuring water from STPs for the ongoing construction work of Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway that passes through Aurangabad among other sporadic demands.

“The civic body has fixed a reasonable rate for the treated water from STPs. We do not want to earn any profit from the selling from treated water, but the only intension is to ensure judicious use of water in the city like Aurangabad where water-scarcity has almost become a norm,” Tanpure said.

As building construction activities are rampant in the city and outskirts, civic activists have called for an official crackdown to ensure mandatory use of treated water.

Civic activist Rajendra Datey-Patil said the AMC must crack down against the construction activities that found using tap water or groundwater for construction purposes. “It is a scientifically proven fact that the treated water from STPs can be safely used for construction activities. The local civic body must issue orders for imperative use of such water for building homes and those using other sources must face punitive action,” he said.

As per official data available with MahaRERA, the regulatory body in the field of real estate, around 860 registered housing construction projects are on in Aurangabad district with a majority of them being taking place in and around the city.

Besides, the period between two successive monsoons is used by many households for carrying out an extension of their existing homes. While the latest number of building permissions issued by the local civic body could not be ascertained, construction activities in the range of 500 to 700 were on within AMC limits.

Title: NMC special general body not in favour of NIT’s restoration
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NAGPUR: The city Congress is divided over the fate of local urban development authority — Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT). This came to the fore during the special general body meeting convened by mayor Sandip Joshi , which was aimed at countering the move on NIT’s restoration.

A section of party leaders, including guardian and energy minister Nitin Raut, demanded restoration of NIT. But most of the 29 Congress corporators, including leader of opposition Tanaji Wanve, favoured scrapping of the civic agency.

On Thursday, the BJP-ruled NMC passed a resolution stating that the city should have only one planning authority. Now, the civic administration will submit its say to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray, who on January 10 had sought NMC’s stand over Raut’s demand.

“Nagpur should have only one planning authority. As per the state government’s old order, NIT along with Gunthewari and other schemes should be handed over to the NMC. Excess NIT employees and officials should be absorbed in NMC and if they are not interested to join the civic body, then the NMC should take nod from the state government to appoint staff,” the mayor said while giving ruling after the marathon meeting.

As many as 34 corporators, including Congress corporators Darshani Dhawad, Manoj Sangole, Sanjay Mahakalkar, along with BSP and BJP corporators, participated in the discussion and all of them opposed restoration of NIT. Joshi said the minutes of the special general body meeting will be sent to the state government.

The mayor also directed the administration to form a special cell to resolve cases related to the Gunthewari Act by February 29. “A meeting of former trustees, senior corporators and all party leaders along with NIT chairman should be convened soon,” the mayor said.

“Nagpur should have only one development agency like any other city in the country or state,” was the general observation of corporators, who expressed concern over how two developing agencies are adversely affecting the city’s development.

Earlier, senior Congress corporator Sandeep Sahare informed the mayor that the special general body meeting over NIT could not be held as the dissolution issue remains sub-judice. It prompted the mayor to sought legal opinion and the administration clarified that the house can continue.

Former mayor and city BJP president Pravin Datke blamed NIT for destroying city’s planning by carrying out large-scale unplanned development works. “On the backdrop of this, it is the citizens who are forced to suffer haphazard development,” said Datke.

Endorsing that the city should have only one planning and development authority, senior Congress corproators, including Wanve and Praful Gudadhe, blamed the Devendra Fadnavis-led BJP government for the mess. Wanve justified Raut’s move as many citizens had approached him over pending works in the NIT and it forced him to approach the state government to restore the civic agency.

Gudadhe said the past BJP-led state government’s move to dissolve the NIT was just to garner votes in civic and state assembly elections.

Senior BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari defended the past government’s move and succeeded in cornering Gudadhe. He said the NMC has received CM Uddhav Thackeray’s letter seeking corporation’s opinion over restoration of NIT with missing pages. He demanded the mayor not to give ruling until the NMC receives the full letter.

Senior independent corporator Abha Pande informed the house that issuing just a government resolution cannot dissolve the NIT.

The first announcement to dissolve NIT was made in December 2016, just two months ahead of the NMC elections that were held in February 2017. The second announcement was made in August 2019 ahead of the state elections.

Title: 24kg gold jewels stolen in 2019 in Madurai house break-ins
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Gold jewels weighing around 23,872 grams were looted in 135 reported house break-in incidents in Madurai city police limits in 2019, reveals an RTI filed by TOI. The quantity of the loot in 2019 equals the quantity of gold jewels looted in 2017 and 2018 put together.

About 11,600 grams of gold jewels were looted in 2017, whereas in 2018, it has increased to 14,800 grams. With the quantity of gold jewels stolen has been on the rise, the city police are clearly struggling to crack cases and put the burglars behind the bars.

However, in terms of the number of incidents reported, house break-in incidents have come down quite well. In 2019, the reported number of cases has dropped to 136 from 185 in 2018, a dip by 26%.

Madurai city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham attributed the increased quantity of looted gold jewels to one incident, which was reported in mid-February last year in Tallakulam police limit. About 11,930 grams of gold jewels were stolen in that particular incident alone.

The commissioner said that some of the police stations such as Anna Nagar and Thilagar Thidal worked well and brought down house break-in incidents in the last year. however, he was not satisfied with the performance of the police stations in Tallakulam range, which consists of Tallakulam, Sellur, and Koodal Pudur, in terms of prevention and detection, he said. He has formed special teams to work on crime detection and increased vigilance in Tallakulam and Koodalpudur station limits to check the crime incidents, he said.

The recovery of gold jewels has also been on the lower side in 2019. Against 36% of recovery shown in 2018, the city police have managed to recover only 17% of the looted gold jewels.

Police officials from Koodal Pudur and Tallakulam police stations, where more number of house break-in incidents are reported, say that the area to be covered by them is vast. A police officer from Koodal Pudur station said that they have increased the beat system at night and introduced additional patrol teams. Detection in a few incidents leading to the arrest of criminals is the only way to bring down the theft cases, they said. “We are working on prevention of crime and detection. We are hopeful of cracking a few incidents and bringing down the numbers,” a police officer said.

Title: Woman doc, minor injured in acid attack at Saoner , Nagpur
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Nagpur: ‘Tumhara aisa chehra bigad du, toh tum kya kar loge?’ (What will you do if I spoil your face like this?) Thus saying, a 22-year-old man hurled acid on a lecturer of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) and another two girls, including a 14-year-old, at Pehlapar ward of Saoner tehsil on Thursday.

Sources said the attacker Nilesh Kanhere went close to the woman doctor-cum-lecturer, in her 20s, and passed an objectionable remark. As she retorted strongly and started walking away, the man followed and threw acid aiming at her face from a plastic bottle. The woman managed to dodge in time but still got some acid on her right hand elbow that got burnt. She is a lecturer of preventive science medicine and also completing her MD.

Police claimed the acid appeared to be the one used for cleaning bathroom but it is being examined. The injured were rushed to a local hospital in Saoner before being shifted to Mayo hospital in the city.

The three suffered minor burns on their face and other parts of the body. A patient accompanying the woman doctor too was injured on her lips in the attack. At least another four were lucky to escape unhurt.

The incident took place while a five-member team of GMCH doctors was carrying out a survey and screening project work on Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI) and Reproductive Tract Infection (RTI) among rural and suburban women in Saoner tehsil, around 40-km from Nagpur.

The team of five doctors had been camping at Saoner for screening women, especially the under-privileged ones. This programme is learnt to be carried out by the GMCH’s satellite wing at Saoner as part of National AIDS Control Organization.

Minister Sunil Kedar, also Congress MLA from Saoner, rushed to meet the victims. Terming the incident unfortunate, Kedar said he was looking into the issue.

Collector Ravindra Thakre said he was set to enforce strict regulation of availability and transportation of acid and petrol. “We will also undertake awareness campaigns against such attacks,” he said.

Attacker Kanhere, who was overpowered and apprehended by the onlookers, was beaten up before being handed over to Saoner police. He was apparently drunk. Police are now trying to ascertain whether he has any criminal background too.

Kanhere, a vagabond, was learnt to be working at a butcher’s shop but was fired from the job. A resident of Telangkhedi in Kelvad, he had been staying at different places and was seen at Pehlapar since for the last couple of days. He had worked at a cinema hall in the morning where he and his friend cleaned toilet with acid. Kanhere had apparently saved some acid from work. Police said he wanted to damage two-wheeler of a person under whom he worked but saw the doctors on way and attacked them instead.

The minor and her neighbour said they were stunned by the attack. “I was not able to gauge what was happening when he threw acid towards me. I realized something was wrong when I felt burning on the skin,” said the minor now being treated at Mayo hospital. “The acid hit my mouth. I felt burning sensation on my lips,’ said her neighbour.

It is learnt Kanhere had first targeted three other women doctors of the team standing beside their vehicle near a temple at Pehlapar. After threatening them, Kanhere had hurled some acid on them too. Though they escaped, the acid fell on the vehicle. As they raised an alarm, Kanhere fled and entered the lane in which the woman lecturer was carrying out her work.

She had been to the home of an unwell woman with the teenager and her mother showing her the way. After taking the patient with her, they were returning through the same lane towards the vehicle parked near the temple when Kanhere came from behind and attacked them.

Addl SP Monica Raut, who is camping at Saoner police station, said Kanhere was being quizzed but his changing statements are posing a hurdle. “We are trying to ascertain from where he got the acid and reason for his attack. He has named different persons as the ones who supplied him with the acid and all have turned out to be fake,” she said.

Senior PI Ashok Koli of Saoner police station said the situation was under control and citizens were co-operating in keeping peace.

Title: Rs 10,000 cost on litigant for wasting court’s time
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Madurai: Taking a serious view for wasting the court’s time, the Madras high court has imposed a cost of Rs 10 ,000 on a public interest litigation (PIL) which sought to release the names of corporate companies who have not repaid bank loans and to waive Rs 55,000 crores of educational loans across the country.

In his petition, A M Sundaravel, a resident of Tirunelveli district, moved the high court Madurai bench seeking for a direction to publish the name list of multinational corporate and private companies who have not repaid bank loans in all the media, newspapers and websites for public view.

When the petition was taken up for hearing on Thursday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran took a serious view for wasting the court’s time and dismissed the petition. The judges imposed a cost of Rs 10,000 to the petitioner and directed him to pay the same to the Chief Justice Relief Fund within one week’s time. tnn

Title: CM’s Delhi visits futile, says Yanamala
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Amaravati: Former minister Yanamala Ramakrishnudu said chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s New Delhi visits were not helping the state.

He said the chief minister’s in getting additional funds from the Centre clearly showed he was not keen on fighting for the state’s interests. “It is a clear case that the CM is only lobbying for favourable orders in his cases,” said Yanamala.

Speaking to reporters here on Thursday, Yanamala said that the chief minister had visited New Delhi seven times in the last seven months and met Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah. Although the CM is contending that he had been submitting representations seeking funds and projects for the state, the Centre had not spared even a single rupee after YSRC came to power, said Yanamala. He said that the Centre would normally oblige at least a few of the CM’s requests when he met the PM and other Union ministers several times.

“The centre has neither sanctioned funds nor alloted schemes to the state as requested by the CM. It means that the CM had not submitted the representations that are being leaked to the public. He must be batting for something else,” said Yanamala.

Title: Demand for stopping ongoing hydrocarbon projects in delta region
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Trichy: While welcoming chief minister Edapaddi K Palaniswami’s announcement on declaring delta region as protected agriculture zone, the Movement Against Destruction has urged the government to take necessary steps to stop ongoing hydrocarbon projects in the region immediately.

“The Tamil Nadu government must take immediate steps to enable its implementation and must pass an ordinance in the assembly. The foremost requirement is to urge the union government to publish it in the gazette,” said K K R Lenin, founder and president of the movement.

“Not only hydrocarbon projects, no corporates would be allowed to launch any kind of projects in delta any more. Agro based project and activities should only be allowed,” he said.

Lenin urged the state government to do the needful to wind up ongoing hydrocarbon projects in delta region. “Oil wells occupying agriculture lands should be evacuated immediately,” he added.

“ONGC is extracting oil and gas from fertile lands after taking them on lease. Though ONGC has been stating that no other new projects were taken for exploration, many projects are continuing for many decades,” he said.

Lenin also urged the government not to allow anyone to convert fertile lands into housing sites. There are several hectares of empty lands which remain unutilized for years. The government should take steps to convert unutilized lands to construct house.

“Thermal power projects should not be allowed to execute along the shore in Tamil Nadu. Sagar Mala projects should also be abandoned without any hesitation,” he added.

Title: Kolkata airport domestic wing gets inline bag scan
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Screening of a bag at Kolkata airport after the roll-out of ILBS

KOLKATA: Authorities at Kolkata airport kicked off the soft launch of inline baggage screening system (ILBS) in the domestic wing on Thursday with Air India getting the checked-in bags of six flights screened by the new system. With three portals in the international wing already in use, the addition of portal E in the domestic wing meant more than half of the portals that are to be commissioned between February 18 and 28 are currently undergoing live trials.

“The E portal that is reserved for Air India was put into use on Thursday. The shift went glitch-free and for Friday, we have planned to put one more domestic portal into use,” said a senior official at the airport. This is likely to be portal D used by SpiceJet and Vistara. IndiGo that operates over 100 flights daily uses two portals — B and C. Portal A used by AirAsia India and GoAir will get the ILBS system later.

While the soft launches have been glitch-free till now, four passengers had to be escorted to the ILBS area in the terminal basement to remove power banks from their checked-in baggage. Three of these passengers were travelling to Dubai on Wednesday evening and one by an Air India flight on Thursday. “Six flights with 820 passengers availed of ILBS on Wednesday. Altogether, 1,145 checked-in bags were screened on portal G and H. Of them, only three went to level 4 check requiring passengers to be summoned to remove restricted items from bags. All other bags were cleared at either level 2 where the screener checks the 3D image of the bag and its contents generated by the CTX machine or in level 3 where screeners get more time to review the image or use standalone X-ray and explosive trace detector to clear the bags,” said airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee. He added that one passenger, who had travelled by an AI flight on Thursday, also made the mistake. Airlines do not allow power banks inside checked-in baggage for safety. Power banks are essentially batteries that utilise lithium cells that catch fire in some situations. If they are taken on board as hand baggage, in case they catch fire, it can be doused with fire extinguishers in the cabin.

The power banks in the checked-in bags did not pose a problem because the numbers were few. But the count may shoot up once ILBS goes live in all the four domestic portals. That is not only due to the large number of flights that screeners have to handle, but it is also because the number of first time and infrequent flyers who are not conversant with the rules. So, they are more likely to leave their power banks in checked-in bags, despite the reminder at check-in counters.

Title: Nagpur: Cash crunch makes civic chief stop all development works
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NMC cash crunch

NAGPUR: With the Nagpur Municipal Corporation experiencing severe financial crisis, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe told the special general body meeting he had restricted civic administration from floating new tenders for development works until the condition improved. "I have also issued instructions to stop all works, whether work orders were issued or not," said Mundhe.

Replying to a query raised by former mayor and BJP corporator Pravin Datke, the civic chief said, “I found the NMC was not even paying income tax and provident fund contribution though it was deducting them from employees' salary. Besides, NMC was yet to pay Rs400 crore outstanding to contractors for various works."

Like elected members, civic administration too wanted development works in the city. But we have to carry them out as per priority, he said. Mundhe also appealed to the corporators that they should propose development works as per its priority.

The civic body has failed to contribute its share in many projects funded by state government. Mundhe cited example of cement road projects. The other partners — state government and Nagpur Improvement Trust— had contributed Rs100 crore each for the cement road projects. “We have not contributed our share so we could not issue work orders for conversion of tar roads into cement roads,” Mundhe explained.

In Rs2,412.64 crore Nag River Pollution Abatement Project, the Centre, state and NMC will bear share of 60%, 25% and 15%, respectively. NMC will have to contribute Rs324 crore, but the current financial condition won’t allow it, he added.

For many other state sponsored projects like Nagar Utthan, NMC will have to contribute 30% of the cost for land acquisitions. It also has other mandatory contributions in projects implemented under district planning committee. “Under these circumstances, we could not undertake any new project. Instead we should concentrate on ongoing projects,” he said.

“I have imposed the restrictions to bring in financial discipline,” he said.

Datke also sought to know whether Mundhe had issued directives that the standing committee had no power to okay proposals for administration nod. Following demand from senior BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari, Datke, Congress corporators Sandip Sahare and Praful Gudadhe, mayor Sandip Joshi directed the administration to table a report on financial condition of NMC in next general body meeting.

In December last year, the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar too had imposed a 25% cut in budget presented by standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane. Pohane had presented a budget of Rs 3,197.60 crore. Bangar dropped various works pertaining to basic amenities worth over Rs 772 crore.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: State-wide stir on February 17 by Left parties
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: A round-table meet of Left parties and peoples’ organisations decided to hold state-wide protest at district collectorates on February 17, seeking implementation of the bifurcation promises. The speakers condemned the indifferent attitude of the state and central governments in fulfilling the promises made to the people at the time of the bifurcation in 2014.

Among the issues, which were taken up at the meet, were denial of special category status, promised in Parliament at the time of bifurcation and failure of the Centre to help with the revenue deficit, which was to the tune of Rs 22,948 crore. They said the government has washed off its hands from the issue by paying a mere Rs 3,979 crore.

Title: No more coronavirus suspects in central Tamil Nadu hospitals
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: More than a week after panic gripped people over the spread of novel coronavirus (nCoV) from China, central Tamil Nadu no more has patients with its symptoms. Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH), a tertiary care centre in Trichy, was free of nCoV suspect cases as of Thursday.While the hospital administration discharged a 27-year-old Singapore returnee of Madurai last week, three others — a 38-year-old man from Pudukottai, a 30-year-old man from Trichy and a 35-year-old man from Ariyalur — were also sent home after either they tested negative or had no symptoms of fever, cough and breathing difficulties.Except the Pudukottai man who was working in China, others were workers in Singapore which was one of the four countries including Hong Kong and Thailand where nCoV outbreak was reported. The first passenger diagnosed with the symptom was the 27-year-old man from Madurai on February 2.“Though they had fever symptoms while arriving at the airport, their health condition became normal after a few days of treatment at the isolation ward. Though they were discharged, they are being home quarantined,” deputy director of health services (DDHS), Trichy Dr A Subramani told TOI.So was the case in the government medical college hospital at Tiruvarur where two men from there and one from Nagappattinam got admitted either with symptoms or out of fear of nCoV infection in the last ten days.All of them were China returnees.As of Sunday, all of them were discharged as they tested negative, confirmed the dean of the medical college hospital Dr J Muthukumaran, on Thursday.Yet, over 600 people from the four countries who returned through the Trichy international airport have been kept in home quarantine, said DDHS Subramanian.In Trichy district alone, 95 passengers have been home-quarantined as of Thursday.“If the home-quarantined passengers are found to have any of the symptoms in 28 days, they will be shifted to the isolation ward,” said Subramanian.
