Tamil Nadu has the highest rate of unemployment among the developed states in the country

CHENNAI: Last September, nearly 4,000 youth vied for 14 vacant posts of sweepers at the secretariat. The interview that went on for 40 days had many applicants who were postgraduates and professional degree holders, including BEs and MBAs, for the job offering a monthly salary of Rs 15,000.Two months later, the Coimbatore corporation received nearly 7,000 applications to fill the 549 grade-I sanitary workers’ posts that guaranteed a monthly salary of Rs 20,000.The two episodes indicate a dearth of proper employment opportunities and job security in the state that were forcing highly qualified youngsters to compete for the post of sanitary workers and peons in the government sector.Though the Edappadi K Palaniswami government has been taking efforts to attract foreign investment and is working on an effective single window system for ease of doing business, the results will take time to fructify.Deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam, while presenting the 2019-2020 budget, admitted the government was facing a "daunting task" to improve the economic growth of the state to create more jobs and reduce poverty. The government, accordingly, is focusing primarily to woo greater investments in the manufacturing and service sectors.The CM and his cabinet colleagues toured the UK, the USA and the Middle East a few months ago and signed 41 MoUs, attracting investment to the tune of Rs8,835 crore. Ahead of the trip, the EPS government held the second edition of Global Investors Meet and signed 304 MoUs to attract investment of little more than Rs3 lakh crore that is expected to generate around 10 lakh jobs in the next few years.Though experts and industrialists welcome the government’s efforts to attract foreign investments with an eye on generating employment for the youth in the state, they also feel it will take a few years to turn it into reality.A day ahead of the state Budget, industrialists and experts opined the government should invest more in micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) as well as in the agriculture sector. It will arrest migration of labour from rural to urban areas. Entrepreneurs said the government should extend financial support to small and micro enterprises and create facilities to train and supply skilled workforce for the sector. "We have been requesting the government to come up with policies to support and encourage MSMEs for the past three years, but nothing has happened. We hope our pleas will be considered this year," said M Swaminathan of the Federation of Association of Small Industries of India.According to the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) in 2017-2018, which was published recently by the ministry of statistics and programme implementation, Tamil Nadu has the highest rate of unemployment among the developed states in the country. Unemployment stood at 7.6%, as against the national unemployment rate of 6.1%. The neighbouring Andhra Pradesh (4.5%), Karnataka (4.8%), and Maharashtra (4.9%) and West Bengal (4.6%) are placed better than TN on this front.Being a predominantly service sector driven economy, which contributes to 51.86% of gross state domestic product (GSDP), the national and international economic slowdown has its direct impact on the industrial climate in the state, according to K R Shanmugam, director of Madras School of Economics."The government should come up with a policy to enhance the minimum wages from Rs18,000 to Rs35,000 and guarantee job security for the workforce in private firms," said S Kannan, state acting general secretary of CITU. CII’s Tamil Nadu state council chairman S Chandramohan said speeding up of the Chennai-Kanyakumari industrial corridor, which is a comprehensive development plan, will enable the state grow faster.

Title: Jaipur: Smriti Van to be opened for joggers from Friday
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The park was closed due to the presence of a leopard from a nearby forest

JAIPUR: After being closed for nearly four months, the Smriti Van will be opened for morning walkers from Friday.

The park was closed due to the presence of a leopard from a nearby forest area. The forest department has decided to open the park, but entry to it will be allowed only after those going in sign an undertaking and procure an entry pass, which will be charged.

Divisional forest officer, Jaipur, Kavita Singh, said, “The park will be opened for morning walkers only between 7am to 9.30am. We have installed 45 route signages along with warning signs on the jogging track. The residents will be allowed inside after signing an undertaking that they are entering at their own risk.” The joggers will have to register themselves at a gate to procure an identity card. For this, the department will charge Rs 55 (one time) from the joggers.

This is for the first time that public entry to the biological park was prohibited for such a long period. The forest department has installed three cages in the park, but all efforts have been futile till now. Officials said since leopard is an intelligent animal it is not entering the cage now as it was captured at an earlier occasion in the park.

As the elusive leopard, which has taken refuge inside the sprawling Smriti Van, did not go out, many residents came forward and requested the authorities to allow them entry to the park after signing an affidavit. A forest official said the feline was being regularly tracked and after monitoring its movement, the department decided to open the park after imposing restrictions. “We recently inspected the park to track the movement of the big cat. At present, the movement of the female leopard is near MNIT and temple area. We have earmarked the track on which morning walkers will be allowed.”

Title: Delhi Weather: End of long winter in sight as heat likely to rise, predicts weatherman
Content:
Days have been particularly chilly so far in Delhi this season.

NEW DELHI: The mercury at Safdarjung weather station crossed 25 degrees Celsius on Thursday for the first time since November 28 last year. It touched a high of 27.8 degrees, nearly five notches above normal. The previous day, the station had recorded its first significantly higher-than-normal maximum temperature in two weeks.The weather is finally turning. This year’s long winter in north India may be coming to an end. Day temperatures in the region, which have mainly been below normal since the end of November, are now set to rise, according to the Met office.Signalling the shift in weather conditions, the India Meteorological Department’s (IMD) extended range forecast on Thursday predicted above-normal heat over north India in the next two weeks.“Winter is now ending. Cold day conditions aren’t likely now in Delhi-NCR. Indications are that maximum temperature will rise over the next few days,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, head of IMD’s regional weather forecasting centre. “Nights may get a little colder for the next two-three days because of a western disturbance crossing the region but thereafter it will get warmer.”This the first time since late November that weekly average maximum temperatures in IMD’s extended range forecast are projected to be above normal in north India. Even average night temperatures are likely to be above normal after a week.In the capital, the change in weather was dramatic. Day temperatures crossed the normal mark for only the second time in the month on Wednesday, when a maximum of 24.5 degrees Celsius was recorded, a rise of 1.5 degrees over the previous day. On Thursday, the maximum was five degrees above the normal mark.“Heat is likely to gradually rise because no major WD activity is expected in the coming week. Some activity is expected around February 21, which could bring some rain in the northern plains and possibly break the trend of rising temperatures temporarily,” Srivastava added.Days have been particularly chilly so far this season. This is the first time in at least the last 28 years (for which records are readily available) that the temperature at Safdarjung stayed below 25 degrees Celsius in the whole of December as well as January.The mean maximum temperature in December was 18.8° Celsius, the second lowest recorded for the month since 1901. Mean day temperatures in January too were below normal by one degree Celsius. The season also saw the longest “cold day” spell of 18 days in December, an all-time record for the national capital.

Title: Madurai folk spend less on gifts, more on flowers for Valentine Day
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Prices of Banglore roses have soared up at Mattutavani Flower Market in Madurai

MADURAI: With online and offline stores screaming of discounts for Valentine ’s Day, it is hard for anyone to traverse though the commercialization of romance. However, city folk, this year, have given a slip to the ubiquitous norm of exchanging expensive gifts..

Shopkeepers said that this year, surprisingly customers preferred cheaper gifts over attractive and expensive gifts.

A shopkeeper at a more than 10-year-old gift store in Thallakulam, which stocks special gifts for V-Day, said that over the years, the demand has declined. “The demand mostly fluctuates but customers are choosing gifts at cheaper rates. Even without offers, customers still come in to buy gifts ranging from cards, mugs to teddy bears but just prefer the cheaper alternative,” said Shivashankar D.

“Valentine’s Day is a meaningful day that should be celebrated because it makes us want to show our love for our beloved. But, expensive gifts like chocolates, bouquets and cards have become clichéd, I feel. We can still show our love without spending too much and instead save the money for something else,” said Nishantini R, 27.

Flower and bouquet shopkeepers said that roses remain a favourite V-Day gift. “Many prefer to buy bouquets as there is something nostalgic that many connect with flowers . We also got orders for door delivery to surprise their loved ones. Many feel it is a simple yet fulfilling gift,” said a florist from Chinna Chokkikulam.

Flower vendors are also expecting the price of button rose to go up on Friday.

Title: Mentally unstable woman ends life on tracks in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A 52-year-old woman committed suicide by jumping in front of a train at the Imli Phatak in the city on Thursday morning. According to initial investigation, the woman was mentally unstable and was undergoing treatment for the same.

The woman was identified as Munni Devi and the incident happened around 8 am on Thursday. “The woman left her house without informing anyone and started walking on the railway track at Imli Phatak. People called out to her when they saw an incoming train but Munni Devi did not pay heed and continued walking on the track. After some distance she sat down on the track and was hit by the train. Since the train was at high speed, no one could put themselves in harm’s way to physically remove the woman from the tracks,” said an official of Jyoti Nagar police station.

Initial investigation suggested that Munni Devi was suffering from some kind of mental ailment and the official added, “We have asked her family to give us medical details including the treatment which she was undergoing to ascertain if she was really unwell or there was some other reason that she decided to end her life. We are also questioning her husband further to find more details in the case.” Munni Devi was hit on the head by the train leading to her instant death. According to officials she and her family had been staying in Jaipur for last six years.

Title: Rajasthan: SHRC seeks report on government steps to curb coronavirus
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Expressing concern over coronavirus, the Rajasthan State Human Rights commission (RSHRC) on Thursday sought a detailed report from the state government on the arrangements made to check it. The commission has specifically asked for the arrangements like sanitation, preparedness and availability of safe drinking water at hospitals, jails and hostels in the state.

Taking cognizance of the news reports surrounding coronavirus and its status in Rajasthan, Justice Mahesh Chandra Sharma, chairperson of RSHRC asked the state government including district collectors, district superintendent of police, director, medical and health, and director general of police (prisons) to give a detailed report by March 18.

“Provide detailed account on coronavirus-suspected patients undergoing treatment at various hospitals in the state and also on the preparedness and arrangements at the various government hospitals to deal with the suspected patients,” Justice Sharma said in the order. The commission has also asked DG (prisons) to inform it on whether jails across the state have enough resources to deal with coronavirus suspects.

Title: MKU syndicate to discuss case of lost answer sheets
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Vice-chancellor of the Madurai Kamaraj University ( MKU ), Dr M Krishnan, on Thursday, said that the university syndicate will soon meet to take action against those involved in a case where a bundle of answer sheets was lost as well as the graft charges against the controller of examination (CoE), O Ravi.

Speaking to TOI, the VC said that he received information on February 6 that a bundle carrying 138 answer papers from the exam conducted in November 2019 had gone missing. “I got to know about the missing papers when staff requested to postpone the announcement of exam results for the 69,000-odd candidates, who took the exam this year, citing the missing papers. I instructed them to not publish the results unless the papers were found,” he said. Later, on February 10, the staff found the missing answer papers under the seat of a bus, which was used to collect the papers.

The VC further said that he immediately took note of the staff’s carelessness and initiated an inquiry. “College officials subsequently confirmed that the missed bundle was indeed original by checking the seal and stitching in front of syndicate members. The answer sheets are now in the process of correction as well,” he explained.

“Based on the replies we get to the memos, the syndicate will discuss in the next meeting and take action. We will also be discussing the matter of the graft charges against CoE,” said Krishnan.

Title: ‘Using Section 144 to handle terror threat mischievous’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Panaji: Raising doubts over the terror alert raised by the government, Congress on Thursday asked how the imposition of Section 144 could possibly thwart a terror attack in the tourist state.

The party also questioned why Section 144 was being imposed only in Goa, and not in the neighbouring states.

“If the terror threat is real and if the alert has been notified for the entire western coast of India, then why have these curbs been imposed only on Goa?” asked Congress media cell convenor Trajano D’Mello, addressing a press conference in the state capital on Thursday.

D’Mello said the party suspects that the state wants to either harass tourism stakeholders or clamp down on activists holding peaceful protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). “The conditions laid down for verification of people staying in rented houses and flats and tourists checking into hotels and guesthouses, appears to be very mischievous when these conditions already exist and are being enforced. This specific inclusion in the notification appears to be a ploy to be able to raid houses, hotels and any other place, and will be misused to harass people known to be speaking out against CAA, NPR and NRC,” said D’Mello.

Congress said the government’s notification was ‘mischievous’ and ‘deplorable’. “The Supreme Court, in its recent judgement, has explained to the law makers that Section 144 cannot be used to restrict citizens of their fundamental right to assemble peacefully and cannot be used to prevent expression of opinion or curb any democratic rights,” said D’Mello.

Congress said that there are adequate laws and tools to deal with terror threats, other than Section 144.

“By issuing such a notification that there are terror inputs, the government is telling the world loud and clear that Goa is not a safe place to live in , forget travel to while on holiday. The tourism industry is bound to be affected,” said D’Mello.

Title: Shifting RR venue: ACA becomes party in case
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Jaipur: A division bench of Rajasthan High Court on Thursday allowed Assam Cricket Association (ACA) to become party in the case challenging shifting of Rajasthan Royals matches to Guwahati.

ACA had approached the high court to become party in the case since the petition is on organising of two IPL matches to be played by Rajasthan Royals at Guwahati. The bench comprising Justice Indrajit Mahanty and Justice Ashok Gaur allowed the application of ACA.

The court further asked Board of Cricket Control in India(BCCI), Rajasthan Cricket Association(RCA) and Rajasthan Royals(RR) to go for out of court contract only if they are willing in connection to the organising of the matches of Indian Premier League. Hearing a PIL challenging the shifting of venue of the matches of Rajasthan Royals to Guwahati, the court had earlier said that fixing of the venue of the matches from Jaipur to Guwahati is subject to the outcome of writ petition. The court during then had granted time to BCCI, RR and Rajasthan Sports council(which owns and manages SMS stadium in Jaipur). TNN

Title: When blooming romance ties the knot with heritage
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

A couple pose for a photoshoot near Rumi Darwaza in the city

LUCKNOW: February is the month of love and those who are sealing theirs legally now are freely indulging in the romantic ritual of pre-wedding shoots.

Young couples are choosing locations in and around the city, instead of fairytale destinations in India and abroad, for the photo-op of a lifetime. From historical sites to lush green parks, Lucknow’s lovebirds are creating memories amid the city’s rich culture and heritage.

According to photographers and couples themselves, the Residency tops the list of preferred pre-wedding shoot sites, followed by Ambedkar Park, Kudiya Ghat, Gomti Riverfront, Rumi Darwaza and Janeshwar Mishra Park.

Teacher Reema Mahajan, who recently tied the knot, said she wanted her photo shoot to happen at a place close to her heart. “We had the option of choosing exotic locales, but we decided to stick to Lucknow. Several of our friends scoffed at the idea of a professional shoot in the city, but we showed them they were mistaken. Our album was shot at the Residency and at Janeshwar Mishra Park. We simply love how the pictures turned out,” she said.

Aishwarya Thapar, another ardent fan of the City of Nawabs, says the best part of shooting here is the dimension domes and minarets add to every picture. At Kudiya Ghat, for instance, the stunning architecture is further complimented by the Gomti. To top it all, people around are comfortable with photo shoots,” she added.

Some couples like Swati and Harshit Dubey are also walking the extra mile to get permission to shoot at heritage sites. “February is always in high demand, but we managed to get permission to shoot at Rumi Darwaza and Ambedkar Park. The best part of shooting in your own city is that it is easier to coordinate with photographers and family,” said Dubey.

Title: Not possible to fully enforce hand hygiene at GRH: Dean
Content:
Patients and attenders sanitize their hands with surgical spirit

MADURAI: Government healthcare centres in the city including primary health centres, community health centres (CHC) and Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) actively started enforcing hand hygiene only after the novel coronavirus (nCoV) breakout across the globe, said health officials and staff on Thursday.However, officials at GRH have said they are not able to completely enforce hand hygiene owing to the huge patient footfall and attenders. Despite round-the-clock cleaning by sanitation workers, many spots in the hospital are still unclean.“We are trying our best to keep the wards and corridors clean and the situation has improved much now compared to few years ago. We are also trying to restrict the number of attenders as well to prevent spread of infection but it is difficult because we always face opposition to it,” said GRH dean Dr J Sangumani.The dean also said that it was not practical to strictly enforce hand hygiene in a tertiary healthcare centre. “Currently we are strictly keeping hand sanitizers and hand washing solutions outside ICUs and infection-prone wards, enforcing hand hygiene for attenders. However, we can’t keep it for public use in the campus or for outpatients because many tend to misuse it,” said Dr Sangumani.The best way to prevent the spread of nCoV or any viral infection, as prescribed by the World Health Organisation (WHO), is practising hand and cough hygiene. “We always used to create awareness about hand hygiene and try to enforce it at all healthcare centres. However, it wasn’t strict enough before and some used to be a little careless. But, after nCoV breakout, though there has been no case in Tamil Nadu , the onus fell on hand hygiene,” said a city health official.Health centres in the city have kept hand washing solutions or hand sanitizers for public use and healthcare workers are also actively educating patients and attenders about hand hygiene, including the recommended six-step reverse hand washing method, cough hygiene and nCoV.“We are also keeping surgical spirit at the entrance of our CHC and are asking all those who visit to sanitize their hands when they leave,” said a medical officer at Sellur CHC.

Title: Kerala Fest to pave way for UN tag for pokkali farming
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The festival is expected to recommend a strategy for the state to safeguard its intangible heritage by gaining... Read More

KOCHI: In a bid to create a road map that would help pokkali farming in the state gain the status of Globally Important Agricultural Heritage System ( GIAHS ), a national intangible heritage festival is being organized here from February 14 to 16.

The festival is being hosted by the Centre for Intangible Heritage Studies (CIHS), Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit, Kalady and National Museum of Natural History, New Delhi, in association with Palliyakkal Service Cooperative Bank, Ezhikkara and department of culture, Kerala.

GIAHS are outstanding landscapes of aesthetic beauty that combine agricultural biodiversity, resilient ecosystems and a valuable cultural heritage. India currently has three such systems recognized by Food and Agricultural Organization under the United Nations. One of them Kuttanad Below Sea Level Farming system is in Kerala. The other two are Saffron Heritage of Kashmir, India and Koraput Traditional Agriculture.

B Venugopal, honarary director, CIHS, said the festival has the theme of ‘intangible heritage and disaster’. “Our idea is to explore the possibilities of providing recognition to pokkali cultivation in the state which has proved itself as a futuristic agricultural practice,” said B Venugopal.

The festival is expected to recommend a strategy for the state to safeguard its intangible heritage. “We need to create a road map for receiving the IH status,” said Venugopal. This would be helpful at the next consultative meeting of the Unesco to be held in New Delhi shortly, he said.

For the first time, an university-level certificate course on intangible heritage would be launched during the programme, Venugopal said. Venu Vasudevan, CEO, Kerala Rebuild Initiative would inaugurate the event. Keynote address will be delivered by Amareswar Galla of Anant National University, Ahmedabad. Field sessions would be held at Ezhikkara on Saturday, followed by presentations by Palliyakkal bank and Chendamangalam grama panchayat. The festival would end on Sunday.

Palliakkal Service Coperative Bank at Ezhikkara had been at the forefront of promoting climate resilient farming, a model now acknowledged by the state government.

The pokkali land lie in 33 panchayats, two municipalities and one corporation area in Alappuzha, Ernakulam and Thrissur. According to a report by the agriculture department, original area under pokkali was estimated to be 25,000ha but is carried out only in 8,500ha. Out of this 5,500ha is under regular pokkali cultivation and the remaining is cultivated only when the climatic conditions are favourable.

Title: HC issues notices to Rajasthan government on illegal mining at village close to STR
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

A division bench of Rajasthan High Court on Thursday issued notices to the state government while hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) on the alleged illegal mining at Baldevgarh village which is situated almost 8 km away from the periphery of Sariska Tiger Reserve (STR).

The bench comprising Justice Indrajit Mahanty and Justice Ashok Gaur issued notices on the PIL filed by one Kirori Mal Sharma. The petitioner stated that Baldevgarh is a village in Rajgarh tehsil of Alwar district in the state and is situated merely 8 km away from the periphery of STR. The petitioner has further prayed for high court intervention by directing the state government to remove the overburden from pasture land and thus remove encroachments.

Title: When work at Moda Goa came to a halt
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

All the work that was being fast-tracked on Wendell Rodricks’ dream project, Moda Goa Museum and Research Centre at Colvale, came to a grinding halt as the news of his sudden passing away hit the workers. Standing around listlessly, they said they had only met Rodricks on Saturday and that he was pleased with their work so far.

“He wanted to throw open at least four galleries on March 27. He knew exactly what he wanted,” one of the workers told TOI. The two-storey house that Rodricks acquired is being converted into a museum with 15 galleries and a library.

“He was always smiling and never had a harsh word. He only had loving words,” one of the carpenters said. tnn

Title: Rajasthan: Four drones of a private firm crash into Pokhran field
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

IAF is holding trials of drones belonging to private firms in Pokhran

JAISALMER: Four drones of a private company fell into a field after crash in Pokhran on Thursday. Indian Air Force (IAF) is conducting trials of drones belonging to private companies under Make in India initiative. One of the drones was found during the search operation by police and IAF officials. Three drones are yet to be found. Police and IAF officials have appealed villagers to inform immediately if they come across with the missing drones.

SP Kiran Kung said that trial of drones is going on at Pokhran firing range in which four drones went missing which was informed by the IAF officials to the police control room. A search operation was launched by police and IAF. A drone was found at 95RD under Nachna police station, while location of two other drones is under Mohangarh police station area where the search operation is going on, he said.

According to officials, during the calamities, the IAF wants to provide immediate help through drones. To use better quality drones, the IAF is organizing a competition at the Pokhran firing range.

Sources said that jury has been formed with experts from air force, Stanford University, South Asia University.

The drone can carry one to two kg items to the pin point affected person and can travel up to 5km in 1.5 hours. Drones are being developed in which antenna has been designed in such a manner that it can track victims along with ACB be used in surveillance, agriculture etc.

Title: Routine notification, no need to panic: Goa CM
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Goa CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Thursday said that the people of the state and tourists visiting the state should not panic over the imposition of Section 144 in North Goa .

Based on intelligence reports specifying terrorist threats to the western coast of India, the North Goa collector has imposed restrictions on cyber cafes as well.

Sawant told reporters it was a “routine notification” which has been issued by the North Goa collector, based on the instruction of the police to keep the force alert. “It is issued every six months,” the CM said.

“No government event including carnival will be disturbed due to the notification,” Sawant said.

Several political parties had expressed apprehension over the imposition of Section 144 in the state.

Title: Rajasthan: Girl’s kin thrash cop for teasing her, cross cases filed
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

The girl’s relatives thrashing constable Mahesh Sharma

KOTA: A Rajasthan police constable, posted at Hindoli police station of Bundi district was held hostage, beaten up and his face was blackened in Sukhpura under Hindoli police station on late Wednesday evening after the family members of a ‘minor’ girl accused him of teasing her on pretext of inquiring about the address of the accused in a case he was investigating.

Police have lodged cross cases — against the constable for teasing the girl and against five members of the girl’s family for interfering into government’s functioning and beating up the constable who was on investigation of a case. The constable was ordered for suspension after the case of teasing the girl was lodged against him and was sent to police line. However, the ‘minor’ girl, after investigation of the documents, was confirmed adult on Thursday morning.

Constable Mahesh Sharma (30), a resident of Tonk district and posted in Hindoli police station, had gone for investigation of a case in his beat area on Wednesday evening when some villagers in Sukhpura village of the area held him hostage, thrashed him and blackened his face alleging that he on pretext of inquiring about the address of the accused in the case, had allegedly teased and behaved objectionably with a ‘minor’ girl of the village, deputy superintendent of police (DSP), Hindoli circle Shyamsunder Vishnoi told TOI on Thursday. The girl’s family held the constable hostage, thrashed him and blackened his face, he said and added that on getting information, police rushed to the spot and released the constable.

On report by the girl, police on Wednesday night lodged a case of outraging modesty of the girl under Section 354 of IPC and Sections of POCSO Act against constable Mahesh Sharma, said DSP Vishnoi and added that however, investigation into the documents of the ‘minor’ girl on Thursday morning revealed her to be an adult.

Meanwhile, on report by the constable, police booked the five members of the girl’s family including her father, brothers and a woman for charges of interfering into government’s functioning and for thrashing, under Sections 332, 353 and 147 of IPC, the DSP said.

Bundi SP Shivraj Singh Meena ordered to suspend constable Mahesh Sharma and to send him to police line after he was booked, he further said and added that SHO at Hindoli police station Shivraj Gurjar is further investigating the cross cases in the matter. No detention or arrest has been made so far in the cross cases, he added.

Title: Government Employees Want State To Clear Backlog Of Promises
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Chennai: Despite the government implementing the 7th Pay Commission recommendations which benefited more than 18 lakh government employees, the state’s directly paid workforce wants more. Various associations of the government employees are looking forward to some of their still pending demands being fulfilled in the last full Budget of this AIADMK government, set to be presented by deputy chief minister and finance minister O Panneerselvam on Friday.

The government decided to implement the pay commission recommendations in October 2017, with retrospective effect from January 1, 2016. The additional burden due to the increase in salaries of all government employees and teachers among others came to nearly Rs15,000 crore annually and this led to increase in revenue and fiscal deficit of the state.

"Despite implementing the pay commission recommendations, we are yet to receive the arrears due from 2016. Around Rs150 crore or a little more is what is needed, but the government is yet to release the amount," said A Selvam, general secretary, Tamil Nadu Government Employees Association.

Lakhs of government employees and teachers went on an indefinite strike demanding fulfillment of a charter of demands in January 2019. The strike lasted a few days and was withdrawn after government threatened action against striking employees.

"The charter of demands includes release of arrears and withdrawal of new pension scheme. But even as we withdrew the strike, action was taken against 5,000 employees, including teachers, under Section 17D of The Tami Nadu Civil Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules. Action under this rule means, the employees will not get any retirement benefit. We have been asking the government to withdraw the action against the employees, but the government is stubborn," said Selvam. More than 1,500 employees and teachers were transferred to other districts and they continue to suffer.

Another demand of the employees is withdrawal of the new pension scheme. "Former chief minister J Jayalalithaa had announced in the assembly about setting up a committee under former IAS officer T S Sridhar. Despite the committee submitting the report, the government has not implemented recommendations," said an employee at the secretariat.

Another grouse of employees is chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami is not willing to meet associations’ of government employees. "After the strike, we have been trying to get an appointment with the chief minister to explain the demands, but he is not ready to meet us. We were able to meet some ministers who could only assure us that our demands will be taken up with the CM," said Selvam.

The association says there are several employees including noon meal workers and rural librarians who have completed 35 years of service. But, they still don’t get any retirement benefit except Rs2,000 pension. "There are several demands of government employees. But, with the present financial situation of the state, it is not possible to implement all the demands. It will take time," said a senior secretary, not willing to be named.

Title: Kanam flays Cong for row over CAG report
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: CPI state secretary Kanam Rajendran has criticized the opposition for trying to create a controversy over the comptroller and auditor general of India ( CAG ) report tabled in the assembly on Wednesday.

“The sanctity the Congress is trying to bestow upon a CAG report is rather ironical,” the CPI leader said, recalling the UPA era ‘when Congress dismissed successive reports of the CAG which pointed out financial anomalies to the tune of crores of rupees’.

“The opposition and the Congress should remember that the people of Kerala have not yet lost their memory power,” Rajendran told reporters here on Thursday.

The findings in the CAG report, ‘which are just allegations’, have to be examined by the public accounts committee of the Parliament or the assembly, which in turn needs to submit a final report, the CPI leader said. “The government has to take action only on such a final report,” he pointed out.

Rajendran also criticized the media for highlighting ‘some shortcomings’ pointed out in the CAG report and hiding ‘the accolades’ the government received with regard to the distribution of surplus land. tnn

Title: Udaipur: Head constable in ACB net for taking bribe
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

UDAIPUR: A head constable was arrested by the anti-corruption bureau (ACB) sleuths on Thursday for allegedly accepting a bribe of Rs 15,000 from a gambling accused.

Head constable Mahendra Singh, a resident of Raipur tehsil of Bhilwara, attached with Ambamata police station, was arrested red-handed with the bribe money which he had taken from the complainant Narendra Sharma, a resident of Krishnapura.

“Sharma was arrested a few months ago under the Gambling Prevention Act by Ambamata police and he had bribed the cops there for bail. The complainant approached us some days ago alleging that the head constable was demanding Rs 15,000 monthly amount for allowing him to continue gambling,” ACB inspector Harish Chandra Singh Chundawat said.

Title: Goa: Cashew zones’ auction begins, up to 40% will see no takers
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Some zones in remote areas, with difficult terrain, are unpopular

PANAJI: Even as the annual auctioning of cashew zones has begun, the excise department does not expect a rise in its revenue collection, this year as well. The expected revenue ranges between Rs 35 and 40 lakh, and has not witnessed any significant rise in the past few years.

In total, 1,675 zones are on auction for the season and it is estimated that 30-40 % of them will not be bid on, as per the trend observed during the past few years.

“The cashew zones in Canacona, Bicholim and Sattari have very few takers,” an excise official said, adding that zones in South Goa were auctioned on Wednesday.

In 2018-19, he said 475 zones were not taken, out of the total 1,671 zones that were auctioned.

For zones thathave no takers, he said, sealed tenders will be invited. If still not bid on, applications are received from interested parties, the officer said.

The department, he said, can hope to get a better price for zones when there is some competition. In the past, he said, certain zones were auctioned even for Rs 1 lakh, but it is no more the case. He said, some zones exist only on paper and hence complete physical verification of the site has to be done. “Some zones have disappeared, for trees may be cleared for commercial purposes or for building homes,” he said.

Some of the cashew zones remain unpopular among bidders as the people who were traditionally into cashew juice extraction and distilling have moved on to other professions. Also, a small zone with just 20 to 25 trees is not an attractive option for it will not help economise the cost of production.

“Large properties have been divided among family members ,and this has resulted in reducing size of the zones,” he said.

In some cases, the department itself has reduced the size of the zones, which has led to a slight increase in the number of zones, he said.

“There will be no takers for zones if the juice extractor will need to travel a distance of four to five kilometres to get the raw material. It is not a viable option if he is a small trader,” the official said. In some zones, the terrain is difficult. No proper access is available, while manual collection is not an easy solution because it is difficult to get labourers. “Due to the high cost of labour, the overall cost of feni production increases,” said a trader.

The department has fixed the rate for selling cashew apples without nuts at Rs 3.5 per kg and cashew juice is to be sold at Rs 4.5 per kg.

The officer said, licensees can’t sell cashew juice at below or above the price fixed by the government.

Title: 3 Ajmer bizmen under I-T scanner
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ajmer: Around 40 teams with 360 Income Tax department officials from Jaipur, Jodhpur and Udaipur landed in Ajmer on Thursday to scan more than fifty places of three businessmen involved in marble and resort sector in the district.

According to sources, different teams led by deputy commandant of intelligence wing of I-T department reached Ajmer. The teams went to different business houses, resorts and marble showrooms in the city and started searching papers and questioning the owners.

Sources said the action was taken after it came to light that the three businessmen purchased a resort for a whopping Rs 35 crore, and the I-T department sensed unfair transaction in the deal . Some teams also went to Kishangarh and Beawar to collect papers and property details. Officials said they are just working and if anything comes out they will share the details.

Title: Lucknow: Janeshwar Park goes to the dogs, visitors on edge
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Stray dogs roam around in Janeshwar Mishra Park on Thursday

LUCKNOW: The increasing number of stray dogs at Janeshwar Mishra Park in Gomtinagar is reportedly keeping visitors away.

On an average, two-three incidents of dogs chasing morning walkers or snatching food from picnickers are reported every day. The ticket contractor hired by Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) claims the daily footfall at Asia’s largest park has dropped by 20% from 8,000 in the past few months.

During a TOI reality check, security guards put the estimated number of canines at “no less than 100” while visitors suggested that the LMC should at least restrict the animals to a corner of the park and not allow them to roam freely.

Vishesh Mishra, a resident of Viram Khand and a fitness regular, said all morning walkers carried a stick nowadays just to be safe. “There are stray dogs everywhere. Who would want to get attacked by one?”

Visitor Vinay Sahu who comes for cycling in the park was chased a few days ago. “In my effort to get rid of them, I lost balance and fell off my cycle. Others shooed the dogs away,” he said. Another park regular Jagdish Verma said he recently rescued three children who were running away from a pack of strays.

Neha Arora who was at the park on Thursday agreed that kids were at a greater risk. “As soon as we opened our lunch boxes, three dogs tried to snatch away food from the children. We complained to the guards, but they did nothing,” she said.

Title: Plea against Kerala DGP Loknath Behera in vigilance court
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Loknath Behera (File Photo)

THRISSUR: A petition was filed at vigilance court here on Thursday, demanding an inquiry against DGP Lokanath Behera , based on the findings in the comptroller and auditor general ( CAG ) report, which was tabled in the assembly on Wednesday.

The petitioner filed by activist P D Joseph demanded that the inquiry must be conducted under the supervision of the vigilance court here. Joseph has demanded the CAG report must be submitted before the court.

A probe must be conducted on all allegations in the report, Joseph said. Chief secretary, the commandant of the Kerala Police Academy , Thrissur and Thiruvananthapuram SAP commandant as well as Behera has been arraigned as accused in the case. The court will consider the case on February 20. tnn

Title: Cooperate with agri survey, appeals statistics director
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Economic and statistics department director has appealed to people to cooperate with the survey conducted by the department. With the campaign against NRC in the background, enumerators fear assault from people, said sources in the department.

The director in a statement made it clear that the survey had nothing to do with NRC. The survey is being done to create the consumer price index as part of the scheme mooted by the Centre for establishment of an agency for reporting agricultural statistics.

This scheme is a component of the main scheme ‘improvement of agricultural statistics’, which is implemented by the ministry of agriculture and cooperation, Government of India.

Department of economics and statistics is the nodal agency of this scheme in the state. Agricultural statistics is collected through sample surveys covering the entire state, excluding regions declared as reserve forests. At present, under this scheme, 811 investigator zones are functioning and 100 clusters are selected randomly from each zone.

The major findings in the publication “agricultural statistics” prepared by this department in every agriculture year are used for implementing various governments decisions. The survey is conducted by classifying land into wet and dry land.

Also, the geographical area of the state has been classified according to 13 different patterns of land use such as bearer and uncultivable land, building and courtyard, other non-agricultural uses. Along with this survey, details for preparing the index for sustainable development and domestic tourism will also be collected.

Title: ‘You’ll always walk by my side’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

I met Wendell Rodricks when he first descended into Goa from the hustle and bustle of Bombay. He was drawn to his roots in the village of Colvale, thanks to his father, Felix, a niz Goenkar. After a chance introduction, we became close buddies.

I was there when he clinched the purchase of Dona Maria Braganza’s picturesque bungalow. Wendell aptly named it Casa Dona Maria. Knowing that I had initiated the Festival of Plants and Flowers in Siolim, he requested me to landscape Casa Dona Maria, which I promptly did.

We got along like fireflies and I even accompanied him to attend his fashion show in Bengaluru. Later, we gelled at the 2008 Goan Convention in Canada.

Wendell was a compulsive world traveller with his partner, Jerome Marrel. I recall illustrating their travel diary and later on, the souvenir of their house, Casa Dona Maria. During an exhibition of my work in Portugal, I visited France and was warmly welcomed into the homes of friends and relatives of Jerome and Wendell.

What Wendell will be remembered for is his minimalistic style. His passion for Goa will forever be etched in his activism for taking up environmental causes and in the popular books he authored.

A visionary par excellence, Wendell will go down in history for his magnum opus — the magnificent transformation of Casa Dona Maria into his dream project, Moda Goa Museum and Research Centre.

I will not say adieu, Wendell, for you will always walk by my side.

The writer is a cartoonist and a long-time friend of Wendell Rodricks

Title: 7,000 litres of spurious ghee seized in Jodhpur
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Ghee jars which were seized from a godown in Jodhpur

JODHPUR: Seven thousand litres of spurious ghee were seized by the team of chief medical & health office on Thursday from a godown in Mandor Krishi Mandi here. The ghee was being sold under two brand names.

CMHO Balwant Manda said that an information was received that Subhash Trading Company at Mandor Krishi Mandi has been dealing with spurious ghee.

“Our team raided the dealer and found a huge storage of packed ghee in the godown of the company,” said Manda adding that the stock was seized and samples were taken for checking the quality. On checking, the ghee was found to be of inferior quality after which a case against the owner was registered.

Manda said that entire material had been supplied from Delhi and the billing was being done at a meagre Rs 200-250 per kg.

The company had been selling this ghee under the brand names of Vanshaj and Mehak and was being sold as pure deshi ghee.

Considering the rampant adulteration and manufacturing of spurious dairy products, the CMHO has been constantly keeping a watch on this illicit trade.

“We had seized 2,798 kg of spurious milk cake from a unit in city area last month, where chemicals had openly been used by the manufacturing the material,” said Manda.

Department had also seized 1000 kg of spices from the same mandi, which also had turned out to be spurious material on checking.

These spices, which included turmeric, chili powder and coriander powder etc. was manufactured and packed at a unit in Beawar and being supplied in entire state.

Title: Five IIT-Kharagpur PhD scholars in quarantine
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

IIT-Kharagpur

KHARAGPUR: Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur , has put five PhD scholars in quarantine — one at B C Roy Technology Hospital, the rest in their hostel room — after they returned to the campus from Thailand on February 10.

Authorities said the quarantine was as per the COVID-19 medical protocol and there is no need to panic as none of the students has shown any sign of unease. Chief medical officer health, West Midnapore , Dilip Chandra Bera said on Thursday, “They have only been kept in isolation since they have returned from Thailand. It is now a standard operating protocol as per the directives of the central and state governments.”

Bera said, “They have their examinations from February 17. They will be writing the exams at the hospital and hostel rooms. We are coordinating with hospital authorities for this,” he said.

The first student was put in isolation immediately after he reached on February 10 while the others were quarantined the next day. “The isolation will continue for 14 days,” a medical officer at the hospital said.

The students are being given normal food and are under observation. Several calls made to institute registrar BN Singh went unanswered.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Ship with Chinese crew ‘isolated’ at Kidderpore
Content:
(Left) A medical officer scans a crew member on the vessel; the ship being berthed in isolation on Thursday

TimesView For Kolkata and Bengal, it is still only alarm; there is not a single person afflicted buy this virus as yet. But things may change with even a small number being infected. So it is essential to carry on with all the precautions for at least some time.

KOLKATA: A Panama-flag vessel with a 19-member Chinese crew that reached the Kidderpore docks on Thursday was berthed in isolation.The crew of the ship has been asked not to be allowed shore leave till they are cleared by a medical team.Earlier, a medical team led by Syama Prasad Mookerjee Port Trust (SPMPT)’s chief medical officer Mukund Kelkar had boarded the 120-metre-long MV Genius Star VII while it was anchored mid-sea near the Sagar anchorage and cleared the vessel to proceed towards Kolkata. The crew will be examined again on Friday.According to NSCBI Airport sources, 21,792 passengers have been scanned. Airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee said no fresh cases were reported to the state health facility on Thursday.The state-run ID & BG Hospital in the city admitted three COVID-19 suspects to the isolation ward on Thursday.The swab samples of the three patients with a travel history to China were sent to ICMR-NICED, Kolkata, for confirmation. The Bengal government in a statement said that no one in the state has tested positive for the infection till date.

Title: Immolation bid lands Arunima kin in custody
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Lucknow: A man tried to set himself, his wife and child on fire in front of Vidhan Sabha on Thursday while accusing police of not lodging an FIR against Gaurav Singh, husband of amputee mountaineer Arunima Sinha, who allegedly assaulted him.

Om Prakash Tripathimanaged to pour kerosene on himself and was about to do the same to his family when security personnel took them into custody.

Tripathi said that his sister-in-law Arunima and he had founded Arunima Foundation in 2014 to support differently abled children. However, the mountaineer and her husband Gaurav ousted him from the foundation in August 2019. He claimed Gaurav and his aides assaulted him on January 25 this year, but police refused to lodge an FIR.

Sarojininagar SHO Pramendra Kumar Singh denied the allegations. “On Arunima’s complaint, Tripathi and his aides were booked for cheating, forgery and criminal intimidation earlier this month for fraudulently withdrawing Rs 1 crore from the foundation’s account,” the SHO said.

Arunima told this newspaper that Tripathi’s immolation attempt as an act to gain sympathy and avoid jail.

Title: Government in process of providing over 1 lakh jobs: CM Ashok Gehlot
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: In just over one year, the state is in various stages of processing over 1 lakh government jobs , chief minister Ashok Gehlot stated on Thursday. He was replying to a debate on the governor’s address in the Assembly on Thursday.

“We have appointed 34,283 people so far. The results of recruitment have been declared or are in the process for another 34,527 posts. Further, advertisements have been issued for 45,773 more posts,” the chief minister said, while replying to a question by Opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria on his party’s poll promise of providing 1 lakh jobs in a year.

Gehlot said the Centre has deprived the state government of Rs 17,000 crore on various counts.

Despite the governor’s address not referring to Barmer refinery, Gehlot said it continues to be top priority of his government.

“So far, work orders worth Rs 20,393 crore have been issued,” he said.

He blamed the previous BJP government of diluting the state’s share in the refinery project.

The chief minister said the ambitious Rajasthan Eastern Canal Project (RECP) to provide drinking water to 13 districts of eastern Rajasthan would be taken up by his government. The Rs 37,000-crore river-linking project was proposed during the previous Raje government.

Claiming credit for the farm loan waiver, Gehlot said that his government had announced a relief of up to Rs 2 lakh on individual farm loans, and waived off all farm loans of the cooperative sector irrespective of the amount.

He said about 9,000 farmers out of the 20 lakh beneficiaries had loans of over Rs 2 lakh.

But the CM said the government was not able to waive loans taken from commercial banks and had sought the cooperation of Centre for a one-time settlement of loans. The Centre though has not given a reply yet. “In Chhattisgarh, the banks themselves had come forward for a one-time settlement and it can be done in the state as well.”

On power tariff hike, Gehlot said 57% of the consumers have been kept outside the purview of the revised rates. He reiterated that there was no tariff hike for agriculture connections in the next four years and the same would be borne by the state.

The government was able to tackle the locust menace and it was appreciated by the Centre, he said, adding that his government had now given Rs 500 crore to agriculture insurance firms for providing crop insurance cover for farmers.

Title: Engineer promoted flouting rules, CMO prods Raj dept to ‘act’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

JAIPUR: Following the intervention of the Chief Minister’s Office (CMO), the financial advisor of the panchayati raj department has red flagged the promotion of one executive engineer to the post of superintendent engineer (SE) in 2012-13, citing violation of rules.

In 2012-13, three executive engineers were promoted to two vacant posts of SEs in the department. After CMO intervened, the panchayati raj department had sought a factual report in the matter.

The three persons who were promoted by the department were Sumit Kumar Agrawal, K K Sharma and Mukesh Maheshwari as per seniority.

Maheshwari, the junior-most among the three, was promoted violating rules to the SE’s post. He is now being considered for IAS promotion (from other services).

On November 22, 2019, the CMO had directed additional chief secretary (ACS), rural development and panchayati raj department, to take necessary action as per rules in the matter. Following this, the department on November 28, 2019, directed two joint secretaries and the financial advisor to prepare a factual report in the matter.

On December 13, 2019, Hari Singh Meena, financial advisor to the department, advised reviewing the promotion of Maheshwari to the post of SE, flouting the rules, by the departmental promotion committee (DPC) and stopping the financial irregularities committed in the case, as per replies received through RTI applications.

Earlier, in August 30, 2018, the finance department too had sought reply from the joint secretary, panchayati raj department, considering the gravity of the matter.

In March 2015, the promotions were questioned in the assembly and the panchayati raj department admitted that only two SE posts were vacant. The department also resolved to correct the third promotion, the RTI reply added.

Even now, there are four SEs working in three posts in the department.

Title: Girl alleges rape, blackmail by 3 in Jodhpur
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

Title: Goa: From designing football jerseys to hosting fashion show, all for a cause
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Wendell convinced Malaika Arora (L) & other models to walk the ramp for Vasco SC

PANAJI: When friends and well-wishers came calling, Wendell Rodricks didn’t know how to say no.

Vasco Sports Club’s golden jubilee anniversary in 2001 coincided with news that one of their most famous footballers, Bernard Pereira, was going through a tough time. His 14-year-old son was diagnosed with leukaemia and needed support.

“What use was a football club if it hadn’t acquired a heart after 50 years,” the club asked itself, and the then president, Noel da Lima Leitao, started planning for a fund-raising event.

The first person Noel contacted was Wendell, his dear friend, and asked him for a favour. “I have Rs 50,000 to spend. Can you do me a small show when we auction a T-shirt for this young boy? Can you get Malaika Arora to model for us?” he asked the fashion designer.

Wendell couldn’t say no, though he knew that a show costs between Rs 8 lakh and Rs 12 lakh and that Malaika’s fee at the time, for an appearance, was over Rs 2.5 lakh.

“My heart said, ‘Wendell, this man is not asking anything for himself. It is for a cause’. Actually, a multitude of causes,” Wendell noted in one of his posts.

It didn’t take much time for Wendell to convince Malaika, a supermodel, and other models.

“Wendell agreed at short notice of less than a week to put together a fashion show to roll out Vasco’s new jersey, designed by him. Wendell’s ideas poured out like a stream of telemetry,” the club said in its publication.

A few years later, Wendell had another knock on his door. This time it was Goa Football Association (GFA) secretary Savio Messias, who asked if he could design jerseys for the state team.

Wendell prepared the design and submitted it to Messias without any fanfare. Goa wore the jerseys for the first time in 2008 when they bowed out in the semifinals. But the jerseys looked so good that the GFA decided to continue with them for the next edition in Chennai as well. This time, Goa went on to edge past arch-rivals West Bengal for its fifth, and last, Santosh Trophy title.

Title: STF registers 25 FIRs in biggest ever gun licence racket in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh special task force ( STF ) has registered 25 separate FIRs in one of the biggest ever gun racket in the state involving high and mighty based in Satna district and the list of ‘beneficiaries’ includes a sitting Congress MLA from Chitrakoot.

STF officials, however, clarified that their probe currently revolves around some government employees who had issued fake weapon licences, increased quota of ammunitions without government’s approval, and extended permits fraudulently and that those named in the list are only ‘victims’ of fraud. Licences issued after 2004 are being examined, said sources.

ADG Ashok Awasthi told media that action is being taken to curb blackmarketing of ammunitions and a case has been registered in compliance with government’s assurance in the cabinet. He said a special investigation team (SIT) led by SP Rajesh Bhadoria was set up to investigate the matter and records were seized from the arms licence wing of the collectorate.

More than 100 gun licences are under scanner. Congress MLA from Chitrakoot Nilanshu Chaturvedi – whose permit was extended illegally – told TOI that he had got documents from the government office. “My area is located on the UP and MP border. We have to go to UP to get petrol. I have followed all rules needed for permit. If they have given me a forged document, how would I know? Let this be investigated,” said Chaturvedi.

ST officials said the licences issued by J&K government were registered and renewed in Satna without government’s approval. It may be noted that J&K arm licences are already under scanner of CBI and linkages between MP-based gangs and Mohammad Zuber gang is also being investigated. Investigators have found that people living outside Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan were illegally shown to be domicile of the state so that they could get ‘All India’ arms licences.

Some J&K authorities are suspected to have facilitated the issuance of these arms licences by presenting civilians in the application forms as either serving or retired personnel of Army and central paramilitary forces having served or are serving in the state.

Title: Thrissur: Charred body of woman found near highway
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

THRISSUR: Charred body of a woman was found in a deserted compound near the highway at Kuranchery near Vadakkanchery in Thrissur district on Thursday.

The incident came to light when police received a call from a councillor after a resident of the area found the body. Police, who reached the spot, conducted an inquest and shifted the body to the mortuary of Thrissur Medical College.

Vadakkanchery CI K Madhavankutty said, “The body was found lying on the ground on Thursday morning and it is yet to be identified. As per primary examination, the body belongs to a woman aged between 45 and 60. The body was in a partially burned and decomposed state and we suspect that she died four-five days ago.”

“A chain was found from the body which is not gold but the traditional ‘thali’ found on it was gold. We also recovered pieces of a blue-coloured dress, but couldn’t identify whether it was a sari or churidhar,” said Madhavankutty.

The CI said postmortem will be conducted once it is identified or after three days if nobody raised claim. “The dog squad also inspected the location. Forensic experts had collected finger prints and other evidence from the spot. The decomposed body also had an ear-ring, but it was not retrieved. We will recover the ear-ring during postmortem,” he said. Vadakkanchery police have registered a case of unnatural death and the probe is on.

Title: Yavatmal: Former Darwha MC chief arrested in cheating case
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Representative image

YAVATMAL: The Yavatmal police on Wednesday arrested the former chief of Darwha Municipal Council and one of his associates who were absconding in a cheating case.

According to police sources, the ex-municipal council chief Haribhau Gulhane (56), a resident of Telipura of Darwha, and his three associates purchased tur from needy farmers at a low price. When NAFED started purchasing through Maharashtra State Cooperative Marketing Federation, they posed as farmers and sold the tur at higher prices.

Amin Malnas (50), a resident of Wadgaon (Gadhwe) village, is the aide who was arrested on Wednesday with Gulhane. Two of his associates Dharmesh Dhole, a resident of Nathuwadi in Darwha, and Maheshwar Bhoyar, a resident of Shelidi village, were arrested earlier.

The complaint was lodged by marketing officer under the DDR, Yavatmal, on October 13, 2018, alleging a fraud to the tune of Rs1.41 crore.

Title: Kamal Nath slams Modi govt for soaring inflation
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Thursday hit out at the Modi government for sharp spike in retail inflation during the last six years. Nath said the Centre should focus on controlling inflation and boost economic growth, instead of diverting attention from real issues.

"The statistics released by NSO show that retail inflation has soared to 7.59%, the highest level in last six years, while unemployment has reached an all time high in the last 45 years. There is an urgent need to pay attention towards curbing inflation, instead of diverting from real issues," tweeted Nath on Thursday.

Expressing concern over soaring prices, the chief minister said, "Vegetable prices have gone up by 50%, while industrial production has declined by 0.3%. Out of 23 industries in manufacturing section, 16 have shown a negative growth."

Nath also hit out the Centre for hike in LPG cylinders. He said, "Rates of non-subsidised gas cylinders have increased by Rs 144.50. The food items have become expensive and employment is decreasing. In which direction, is this country going?"

Nath's reaction after the data was released by the Union ministry of statistics and programme implementation on Wednesday which revealed that retail inflation in the country rose the maximum since May 2014, besides pushing up food prices and telecom tariffs. The Consumer Price Index inflation stood at 7.59 percent in January 2020 as compared to 7.35 percent in December 2019.

Reacting on Nath's comments, leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava said the chief minister should control excessive and overspending on wasteful events. "The state government has decided to spend crore on events like IIFA. It is involved in image branding at the cost of public's hard-earned money," said Bhargava.

He said the state government should stop demanding funds from the Centre and put a check on overspending and corruption. The government should immediately cancel the IIFA award ceremony, he added.

Title: Cutting corners to meet deadline
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

With delays stalking several projects under Smart City Mission, authorities are resorting to shortcuts and reducing their scope and size

MK.SunilKumar@timesgroup.com

Kochi: With the deadline for completing the works under Smart Cities Mission fast approaching, authorities are finding shortcuts for staying on target. The scope of some of the projects have been reduced while some others are likely to undergo changes.

The proposed length of the walkway connecting Metro station at Maharaja’s College ground to Boat Jetty, one of the Smart City projects, has been cut short to avoid further delay.

The project, which started way back in February 2017, and which could have been beneficial to hundreds of commuters, is yet to be completed. Authorities say the project, which was supposed to be completed in six months, got bogged down by land acquisition delays.

“Some agencies whose holdings will have to be taken over for constructing the walkway are not ready to hand over land parcels. We have not been handed over the land owned by Ernakulam Head Post Office and Maharaja’s College Hostel, among others. So, we are planning to complete the stretch till where we have already acquired land. In other areas, we are constructing the walkway on available space,” says an official associated with the project. “The work will be completed in a week,” he adds.

Making matters worse, the stretch along which the works have been completed, are used as parking lots for autorickshaws and motorcycles.

Even while the project faces hurdles, authorities, including the Kochi Corporation, is yet to take any steps to resolve the issue. Officials with the Cochin Smart Mission Ltd (CSML), the special purpose vehicle floated for implementing Smart City projects in Kochi, have also not sought the intervention of people’s representatives for sorting out the problems. “CSML officials haven’t informed me about the difficulties they face to acquire land. Had they informed me, I could have taken up the issue with the Centre as well as the state government,” says Hibi Eden, MP.

Compromises are likely to be made on the project involving the reconstruction of the Ernakulam Market, as well. CSML has earmarked Rs 100 crore for renovating the market. But the authorities have not yet floated tenders for the project as the land required for rehabilitating the merchants who runs the stalls in the market is yet to be identified.

The premises of a school near by the market, which is not functioning now, was identified for the purpose but it was found that a case has been pending before the high court regarding the ownership of the land.

“If we do not get land, we can avoid market reconstruction and just focus on renovation. We have given our suggestion to the CSML in this regard,” sources with Kochi Corporation said. But CSML officials said they haven’t taken any decision so far. Anyway, the project is yet to start rolling.

Contractors unwilling to take up works

Kochi: Though adequate funds have been allotted for completing the projects under Smart City Mission, contractors have been hesitant to take up many of the works. Cochin Smart Mission Limited (CSML) authorities have been forced to retender the works again and again.

The Rs 7.1 crore Marine Drive Walkway project is a case in point. “All the contractors who took part in the tender process quoted above our estimate. We can’t award works at rates above the estimate as Smart City norms don’t allow it. So, we have retendered the project for the fourth time,” an official with CSML said.

“The sidewalls of the walkway need to be protected due to high tide and waves. The contractors claim it is a costly affair. So, no one is ready to take up the work at the current estimate,” the official said.

The same goes for the project to procure sweeping machines for cleaning the streets in the city. “All the firms, which have taken part in the tender procedures so far, are reluctant to take up the work. They are not ready to agree with the condition that they need to operate and maintain the machines for three years. So, we are retendering the project for the third time,” the official said.

The Rs 2 crore project to supply smart portable compactors to store and transport garbage from the city also has met a similar fate. The reason? No firms are ready to operate and maintain the machines.

CMSL authorities had earmarked Rs 32.49 crore for renovation of roads in three divisions of the corporation in Fort Kochi area. But the authorities have not yet been able to award the works to a contractor. As huge amounts need to be spent for bitumen works, contractors are reluctant to undertake roads works, a corporation official said. Now, the CSML is again inviting tenders for the works.

Sewage treatment plant: Another clogged project

Kochi: Another project that has been facing uncertainty is the much-touted vacuum sewer project designed for five divisions of the local body in Fort Kochi and Mattancherry areas. The corporation authorities have not yet been able to identify land for setting up the plant.

The land the authorities had identified earlier for the project is caught in a legal tangle over its ownership. Though the civic body authorities suggested that the plant can be set up on land owned by Cochin Port Trust (CPT), they haven’t conducted any talks with the owners of the holding so far.

At a council meeting held on January 20, mayor Soumini Jain had announced that she will hold a meeting with CPT chairperson for further discussions in one or two days but no progress has been made on that front so far.

The project to renovate Broadway at a cost of Rs 10 crore is also in a limbo. “We had zeroed in on a design. As per the design, there is a roof over Broadway. But CSML authorities want to bring in certain changes in the design. They want to avoid the roof citing chances of fire mishap. But roofed streets can be seen in cities across the world,” sources with the corporation said.

“The roofed design would have attracted more consumers to Broadway. They can park their vehicles somewhere near Marine Drive and walk along the street,” he said.

Title: CAA: Chidambaram for mass movement 'if any Muslim is sent to camp'
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress veteran and former Union minister P Chidambaram said on Thursday that there should be a mass movement if any Muslim was sent to a detention camp in the event of the Supreme Court upholding the Citizenship Amendment Act.

"When they touch the excluded... they will only be Muslims, try to identify and throw them out, declare them stateless, there must be a huge mass movement resisting any Muslim being thrown out or kept in detention camps," Chidambaram said while replying to a question at an event in JNU.

When asked why the Congress brass had kept a distance from the anti-CAA protests and had not visited Shaheen Bagh, he said, "It is not true. I have led a march in Thiruvananthapuram and many other states. We are not going to Shaheen Bagh as it will be falling into the BJP's trap and will be made political."

Chidambaram also said that the only way to oppose CAA was legally and added that he believed in the Supreme Court which is hearing petitions against changes in the citizenship law. He questioned the fact that CAA was passed in just three days and was meant to make up for the "NRC fiasco" which resulted in the exclusion of 12 lakh Hindus out of Assam's National Register of Citizens.

He clarified that Congress was not against those included in the CAA. "We are against the law on the grounds of exclusion. Our opposition is about exclusion. Include all of them. In fact, our demand is not to deny citizenship but to include all neighbours and people of all religions. Let me make that very clear. But BJP goes around spreading lies. In fact, we go a step further, I have written about it, what we need today is not CAA but a law for refugees. We must have a broad, humane law on refugees. Who is a refugee and who will qualify as refugee? We are arguing for a broader law, a larger law on refugees."

Title: ‘Wendell launched Deepika, Anushka’
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Panaji: Tawquir Sheikh, Wendell Rodricks’ master cutter who worked with him for 32 years, has cut materials that have dressed former Miss Universes Sushmita Sen and Lara Dutta, former Miss Worlds Aishwarya Rai and Priyanka Chopra, and other big names. It was in his presence that Rodricks noticed a tall, lithe girl, Deepika Padukone, approached her and invited her to Mumbai.

“We were at a small show at a club in Bengaluru years ago and Deepika was just a model at that time. She was sitting in the audience while we were on stage. Wendell thought she looked lovely and saw that she had the potential of a top model. He talked to her in front of me and told her he would help her with a career in Mumbai and thus launched her,” Sheikh said.

Rodricks similarly spotted Anushka Sharma as a teen and launched her, too, he said.

“In the 32 years I’ve worked with him, he discovered many such models who went on to become actors. I’ve cut materials for most of the designs Wendell has made for them. Yana Gupta, Salman Khan and Arbaaz Khan have also worn Wendell’s designs cut by me,” Sheikh said.

It was the Hindu-Muslim riots in Mumbai in the early nineties that prompted Rodricks to pack up and shift permanently to Goa, he said.

“I used to work at Fatal Attraction in Mumbai, where Wendell would come to do his designs twice a week. He said that I, a Muslim man, would feel safer in Goa and would be able to work well too. I’ve made Goa my home ever since,” Sheikh, who now lives in Colvale himself, said.

Title: Love heals scars of acid attack survivor, she’s ready for V-Day
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

Rupali Kumar with Kuldeep

LUCKNOW: When Rupali Kumar will meet her husband for a candlelight dinner on Valentine ’s Day, the experience will be much more than a romantic date.

The 25-year-old acid attack survivor, who married the love of her life Kuldeep (26) in 2017, has seen years of turmoil before finding her happiness.

Celebrating V-Day for the first time like this, the couple will be reliving the time they lost in overcoming odds to unite.

A Bhojpuri film and video artist from Ghazipur, Rupali was attacked with acid by a colleague who claimed to be in love with her.

The incident of 2015 left deep scars not only on Rupali’s face but also her heart and spirit.

“For a year after the attack, I was in intense trauma and kept to myself. In 2016, I started working in Sheroes Hangout Cafe in Lucknow where I met Kuldeep and slowly, a friendship began,” says Rupali.

Kuldeep, who takes care of all of Sheroes’s outdoor activity, said that in Rupali, he found a friend who understood him like no other.

“Over the months, I knew our friendship had developed into love but I didn’t know how to propose. She was the one who did it, much to my delight. I knew she loved me as a person and not my looks or money,” says Kuldeep, adding that physical beauty does not matter.

For Rupali, it was Kuldeep’s positivity to heal the post-attack trauma that won her over.

“The acid attack now feels like a blessing. It taught me the value of qualities in a person. It also taught me to fight and win the overall struggle,” says Rupali.

While the couple promised to each other a lifetime of togetherness, resistance from the family, Kuldeep said, was expected.

“My family did not accept Rupali until the birth of our daughter in 2018. Till then, my father did not know we had married. But now, they are warming up to us,” he adds.

On Friday, the couple is being treated by a city hotel to an exclusive candlelight dinner as part of Valentine’s Day celebrations to give out the message that love has no boundaries.

The hotel’s assistant manager, marketing, Deepti Kapil said, “We are running a social media campaign called #LoveHasNoBoundaries. The initiative aims to spread the message that true love knows no caste, colour, gender or age. Honouring that spirit, we are hosting Rupali and her husband so that their story becomes an inspiration for others.”

Title: AIADMK seeks action against Congress MLA for taking selfie in assembly
Content:
This story is from February 14, 2020

MLA A Johnkumar take selfie with government whip R K R Anantharaman during the special session of the Puducher... Read More

PUDUCHERRY: The opposition AIADMK has urged speaker V P Sivakolundhu to initiate action against Congress MLA A Johnkumar for ‘lowering the dignity of Puducherry legislative assembly ’ by taking selfies with government whip R K R Anantharaman and others during the special session and sharing the photos on social media on Wednesday. AIADMK legislature party leader A Anbalagan submitted a memorandum to the speaker in this regard on Thursday.

Anbalagan said Johnkumar shared the selfies in a WhatsApp group and they were shared by several people in many other groups even as the session was underway.

“Failure on the part of the speaker to initiate action against ruling party members for their indiscipline has lowered the dignity of the post of the speaker,” Anbalagan said.

He regretted that the speaker failed to prevent AIADMK members from referring members of the opposition in a disrespectable manner during the special session in their absence in the assembly. “It is unfair that the speaker failed to prevent ruling party members from addressing members of opposition in a disrespectable manner in their absence.
